Proposed New Constitution To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we believe that Australia's constitution is undemocratic and should be replaced by a democratic constitution, particularly as regards the new standard for regulation of Vitamin and Mineral Supplements. We believe: 1. This legislation will curb for our own health according to need, environment, mate, et cetera. 2. Plant Variety Rights following extensive public To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government: I. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely: (a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation. (b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers. (c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats. 2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands. 3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia. Speaker: Mr HARRIS
Title: COMMISSION REPORTS
text: My question is directed to the Notice of Motion Prime Minister. When are the Commonwealth Grants Commission reports due? Has the Victorian Premier-elect asked for an extra meeting between the States and the Commonwealth to discuss those reports, and has such a meeting been agreed to?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: COMMISSION REPORTS
text: There has been some doubt about the precise date on which we will have available, not only to ourselves but also to the States, the Commonwealth Grants Commission report examining the relativities of Commonwealth payments to the respective States. As we are advised, it will be available some time in June. On present advice, we will probably have the report in time for people to look at it but not to examine it before the Premiers Conference on 19 June. I think it would probably be agreed that substantive decisions will not be able to be made at that meeting because, clearly, all State governments and the Commonwealth will want to examine the document very closely. At this point, nobody has any idea of the recommendations that might be contained in it, and whether or not they could pose particular complications for some States. As a result of that, Mr Thompson, the Premier-elect of Victoria, asked the Commonwealth whether it would be possible to schedule a special Premiers Conference to discuss these matters. I have told him that I think that is the only way to handle it and that such a conference will have to be held. We will need some flexibility about the date, but it would need to be some time during the winter. NA

Speaker: Mr LES JOHNSON
Title: PERMANENT BUILDING SOCIETY
text: I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction: Has the total value of housing loans provided by permanent building societies fallen from $91m in April 1980 to $57m in April this year? Has the number of building society loans fallen from 2,963 in April 1980 to 1,953 this year? Since permanent building societies provide one-third of all housing loans, does the Minister accept this decline as a serious deterioration in the availability of finance vate home buyers? Is this a major reason why home ownership has fallen to the lowest level for a decade?

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: PERMANENT BUILDING SOCIETY
text: The answer to the first and second parts of the question is yes. When we look at the amount of funds made available to permanent building societies, we see that again the figures are correct, and I congratulate able gentleman for at least doing his homework. However, I question his figure for the percentage of funds to total housing made available by permanent building societies. From the information given to me at 2 o'clock, the figure was 28 per cent, not 33 per cent. I indicate to the honourable member for Hughes that when we look at the totality of funds made available for housing we find that for the March quarter this year, compared with the March quarter last year, there was a slight drop of 3 per cent. However, we must remember that last year was a record year for loans made available to home owners-240,345--and of those people 106,000 were buying their first home. On account of the responsible financial decisions made by my colleague the Treasurer, in December last year there was a return to the traditional lending and borrowing patterns in Australia. Because of a distortion in the money markets more money was made available in 1980 to permanent building societies than to banks. We have returned to the traditional ratio of 63 per cent for banks and 28 per cent for permanent building societies. We have to look at the total picture of finance made available for housing. Again I question the accuracy of the honourable gentleman's figures. The total figures for home ownership in Australia show that this Government can claim a proud record. In 1949, 53 per cent of Australian people owned their own homes or were in the process of purchasing them. In August last year, from the most recen t statistics made available by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 71.9 per cent of Australian people owned their own homes. That is a record that this free enterprise Government can be proud of. NA We are about home ownership for all Australian people. We do not subscribe to the proposition adopted by those who sit opposite. They should recall that one of their previous housing ministers said: 'We do not believe in home ownership. That will make a nation of capitalists'. I sat on the Opposition side of the chamber and listened to a former Minister for Housing say: 'We want to cut costs in Australian housing. We will make Australian people own smaller homes'. We for pri- do not subscribe to that proposition. NA

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE
text: -My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. What is the current situation in regard to the Telecom Australia dispute? Are there any signs of an early settlement or will there be continuing reduction the honour- and disruption of services?

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE
text: Discussions are still continuing. Just before I came into the House, I endeavoured to determine what the prospects were for the breakdown of services. With respect to the international network, I understand that people trying to plug into the Sydney Overseas Telecommunications Commission network switch are finding it a little difficult getting through the trunk arrangements, but, with the exception of a few countries, the international subscriber dialling service is still functioning effectively. Where it is not operating, it is possible through reference to a trunk operator to obtain connection to most countries. However, within Australia there has been a breakdown of a number of trunk systems and that is of major concern to the Government. The Government is very conscious that within the conciliation and arbitration procedures there is a fair and equitable opportunity for the representatives of the two unions to pursue their claims. It is totally opposed to the implementation of bans. A number of personnel have been stood down as a result. The Government is obviously very anxious that services should be resumed at the earliest possible moment. However, it does not believe that in conditions where the service continues to deterioriate it can remain completely at arm's length from the dispute. Therefore, 1I have initiated a number of approaches to Telecom management to try to ascertain the exact state of play. I hope that out of the discussions before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission it is possible for the dispute to be settled. If not, the Government will of course have to consider what measures it needs to take to ensure a resolution of the dispute even if those steps lead to having to close down Telecom. NA

Speaker: Mr VREN
Title: HOVSING LOAN INTEREST RATES
text: Will the Minister for Housing and Construction agree that housing loan interest rates with banks and building societies are now at a record level? Is it a fact that because of the tight liquidity in the banks and building societies interest rates are under pressure to rise again? What action is the Government prepared to take to prevent the housing industry from suffering still further under its restrictive monetary policy?

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: HOVSING LOAN INTEREST RATES
text: Mr Speaker, firstly I crave the indulgence of the House for two brief seconds and thank honourable members for giving me an opportunity to reply to the scurrilous charges made by the Opposition in the debate on the Housing Assistance Bill last night, when it would not give me the opportunity to reply.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: HOVSING LOAN INTEREST RATES
text: Order! The Minister is not entitled to refer to that debate. I will rule him out of order if he does so.

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: HOVSING LOAN INTEREST RATES
text: Mr Speaker, I accept your guidance and am grateful for it. In answer to the series of questions asked by the honourable member for Reid I will itemise what happened when the Opposition was on the Government side of the House. Interest rates for savings banks loans increased from 7 per cent when the Opposition took office to II per cent. For permanent building societies the interest rate increased from 8 per cent to 11 t per cent. How can the Opposition talk about an increase in interest rates? After five and a half years of responsible government interest rates are basically the same as they were when we took office and tried to get this nation back on the rails. If we look at the control of interest rates we find that one of the problems in New South Wales is the New South Wales Government, which is not able to cope with financial responsibility. I remind those honourable members who sit opposite that by world standards interest rates for home loans in Australia are very low. I will fill in honourable members opposite on statistics from the rest of the world.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: HOVSING LOAN INTEREST RATES
text: Order! The Minister is defending himself valiantly but he does not really need so much time. I ask him to draw his answer to a conclusion. Mr MCVEIGHInterest rates in the United Kingdom are 13 per cent, in the United States of America they are 15.5 per cent and in Canada they are 16.5 per cent. So Australia is not doing too badly by world standards. Our housing interest rates are amongst the lowest. Finally, the honourable member [or Reid asked what the movement in interest rates would be. r let the honourable member know that he is not going to draw me into any debate on the likelihood of increased interest rates. One of the problems in containing interest rates in Australia is the enormous demand made on the available resources including household savings by the borrowing programs of State, local and semi-government authorities in Australia. r hope that those who sit opposite will ask their State Premiers, who will be coming to the Loan Council and the Premiers Conference later this month, to show a bit of the infectious enthusiasm for responsibility and financial control that this Government maintains in all its undertakings. If they did that they would at least be doing something for the housing aspirations of all Australian people. SYDNEY (KINGSFORD-SMITH) AIRPORT: CURFEW

Speaker: Mr DOBIE
Title: HOVSING LOAN INTEREST RATES
text: I refer the Minister for Transport to an article in today's Canberra Times wherein its aviation reporter has alleged that Trans-Australia Airlines has made an application to the Minister's Department to have the curfew at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport lifted to allow more efficient use of TAA 's about to be introduced Airbus aircraft. Is the Minister in a position to assure the House that-should such an application from TAA exist-no decision has been made, nor any indication given, to advantage TAA while totally disadvantaging the people who live within the environs of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: HOVSING LOAN INTEREST RATES
text: The maintenance of the curfew at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport has been a policy of this Government for some considerable time. Any application by TAA for an easing of the curfew would be a matter of policy consideration. I can assure the honourable member that no decision has been taken and no decision will be taken without giving very serious consideration to the people living in the region of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE
text: Is the Minister for Communications aware of the survey undertaken by Telecom Australia management and the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association of comparably qualified tradesmen in various areas of public employment and accepted by Telecom management as a representative survey? Does the Minister agree that the survey shows Telecom employees as being amongst the very lowest paid of those employed by the 25 employers in the survey and that, for instance, tradesmen employed by the South East Queensland Electricity Board are paid 16 per cent or $34 a week more than tradesmen with the same qualifications employed by Telecom? Does the Minister agree with the management of Telecom that this is not an acceptable position for Telecom and its employees in this industry which is characthere. terised by high technology and unquestioned financial capacity and which is ance to the Australian community?

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE
text: J am very indebted to the honourable member for Canberra for having demonstrated how generous the tax reimbursementarrangements entered into by this Government have been to the State governments. Indeed, it is true that particularly the New South Wales Government, but to a degree the Victorian Government, for example through the Victorian power authority, and the other State governments have entered into arrangements outside the wage indexation guidelines which have created enormous problems for the 80 per cent of employees who are employed under the private sector in this nation. The honourable lady referred to a specific questionnaire relating to a number of parallel wages paid within selected areas of Public Service employment. Had that survey ranged across the whole breadth of employment, taking into account private sector as well as public sector employers, she would find that there are many areas in the private sector where the wage disparity with Telecom looms in favour of the Telecom employees. The concern we have is for the whole nation and not just for those who work within the public sector. KING'S HALL: REMOVAL OF NA

Speaker: Mr COLEMAN
Title: DEMONSTJUTORS
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services as the Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police. Will he inform the House whether the police used brutality in removing demonstrators from King's Hall yesterday afternoon?

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: DEMONSTJUTORS
text: -I do not think I have to remind all honourable members of the very unruly and, I must say, unnecessary demonstration that took place at the entrance to Parliament House yesterday. To answer directly the honourable member's question, let me say that I believe that the police acted with considerable restraint in the face of a very vigorous, hostile crowd that physically set out to attack the police. I reject utterly some allegations that have been made by members and senators of the Opposition that the police acted brutally or with undue hostility to the crowd. I have taken the trouble to'-Mr Barry Jones-Undue hostility?

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: DEMONSTJUTORS
text: -Without any hostility to the crowd. I make no qualification at all. I have taken the trouble to look at some of the video tapes of the incident. I have spoken to reporters who were They watched the police ask the demonstrators to leave King's Hall and then physically of critical importtry to remove them. Those tapes show many incidents that demonstrate what I was saying about the hostile nature of that crowd. One policeman was having his hair pulled, and was being pushed and pulled headlong down the steps of Parliament House. If they had got him there, there would have been a possibility of quite serious injury. A young woman police officer was being punched in the chest and crushed against the doors of Parliament House by the crowd. The police were acting under the orders of their superior officer on this occasion. They were asked to act with physical restraint. They were acting under the principles of common law. I say once again that I reject the allegations made by some honourable members opposite about the actions of the police. I go further, and commend the police for the most considerate way in which they dealt with these people under undue provocation which mean- physical injury. NA

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. Firstly, did the Acting Chairman of Telecom Australia, Mr May, write to the Minister on 16 April seeking approval to negotiate with the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association in respect of the union's wage claims? Secondly, is it a fact that by the time the matter was called on before Commissioner Clarkson on25 May Telecom management had received no reply from the Minister? Thirdly, I ask whether it is a fact that in these circumstances Telecom, having acknowledged that Telecom employees have a legitimate claim for a significant wage increase, put on record before the Commissioner the following words: The recent decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on wage indexation ready basis for advancing such a claim. Finally, as Telecom management and the unions believe that a significant wage increase should be negotiated and as they, together with the arbitration commissioner, believe that this cannot be achieved appropriately under the guidelines, why does the Minister persist in a course of action which is against the public interest and which Telecom management believes is against the interests of Telecom?

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE
text: The answer to the first part of the honourable gentleman's question is yes. The answer to the second part in respect of contact with the Acting Chairman of Telecom is that verbal discussions were held with both the Acting Chairman and members of the executive of Telecom regarding the details of the basis on which negotiations could proceed. Thirdly, with respect to the whole of the basis of public interest which the honourable gentleman seeks to assert, I point out to him, as I did in answer to the honourable member for Canberra, that it is imperative that the interests of the whole Australian community be taken into account. In this present dispute, while there was a review analysing comparable wage levels between members of some sectors of the Public Service and Telecom, that review did not embrace the private sector. It did not embrace wage levels paid to people in similar wage and salary classifications in areas where people were called on to do similar jobs and where the wage levels do not show the wage disparity which appears in the review undertaken by Telecom and its employees. Fourthly, it is true that within the conciliation and arbitration system there is a capacity to refer to an anomalies procedure through which there is an ability for the genuine public interest and the interests of the employees of Telecom to be properly taken into account. It is in that forum that the Governm mt believes wage negotiations should occur and it is within that forum that the Government has been encouraging both Telecom and its employees to resolve the present dispute. NA

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: SHEEP SHEARING
text: The Minister for Science' and Technology would be aware that a search for a safe, reliable and effective chemical for the harvesting of wool has been carried on throughout the world for decades, particularly in the United States of America and the Soviet Union. Is the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation involved in such research into finding an alternative to the manual shearing of sheep? If so, what progress has been made? guidelines does not provide a Mr THOMSONThe Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has been engaged in research on biological defleecing for some time. This has been sponsored by the Australian Wool Corporation. It has been a most interesting and successful piece of research so far. The research has been aimed at finding a substance which, when injected, will cause a break in the fleece. The fleece can then be pulled off either manually or automatically.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Title: SHEEP SHEARING
text: Round the paddock. Mr THOMSONI hope the honourable member for Port Adelaide will be interested in this great example of Australian science.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: SHEEP SHEARING
text: The honourable member for Port Adelaide will remain silent. The Minister will proceed with his answer and ignore the interjection from the honourable member for Port Adelaide. Mr THOMSONCSIRO has discovered a protein which causes shedding of the fleece in about 48 hours. The protein is a substance called epidermal growth factor which, very fortunately, occurs naturally in body tissues in small quantities. The advantage of this natural occurrence is that there is unlikely to be any drug residue problems or harmful side effects. The next step in this research is field evaluation and development of management techniques which will take some time. I hope that honourable members will join me in congratulating CSIRO on what appears to be a breakthrough in what has been world-wide research. UNITED STATES: NUCLEAR WEAPONS

Speaker: Mr ARMITAGE
Title: GOVERNMENT MEETING
text: I refer the Prime Minister to his remarks in the House last week in which he strongly defended his decision to send five Ministers and six back benchers to deliver personal invitations to 40 Commonwealth political leaders to re- attend the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne in September. I ask: Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to wide editorial criticism of the Government's decision in the Australian Press? In particular, has he noted the comments in an editorial in today's Sydney Morning Herald which describes the decision as an affront and the Prime Minister's public explanation of it as eyewash? Finally, in view of the Government's professed determination to impose in government spending, will the Prime Minister now abandon his expensive and unnecessary scheme and leave the matters of conferof ence invitations and agenda discussions to the Japan Commonwealth Secretariat and our own diplorematic representatives in the various countries?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: GOVERNMENT MEETING
text: I have advised Govern the House on more than one occasion of the reasons for the Government's decisions. Those decisions stand. But, for the benefit of the honourable gentleman, let me repeat the arguments and the reasons. Over the last decade when the Canadian Government or the United Kingdom Government was responsible for holding the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting it adopted the practice of sending people to some Commonwealth countries for the very reasons that we have adopted-to seek the views of other about the nature of the agenda, the senthe sitive issues that might have to be handled and what progress the Commonwealth can make in contributing to a resolution of significant issues. The one difference on this occasion is that instead of sending emissaries to some Commonwealth practice which we believe was not in dethe best interests of the unity of the Commonwealth, in which all members, large and small, have a significant part to play-we are sending fact people to all Commonwealth countries. This is part of the process of building into the Commonanwealth Heads of Government Meeting an agenda which has had an input from all Heads of Governa ment from all Commonwealth countries, wherweapons program. ever they may be. Earlier, I advised the House that at the end of testJuly I will be having discussions in the United we Kingdom with the Secretary-General, Mr Ramphal, who very strongly supports this process of consultation before the conference begins. On this basis the program will continue. I do not think the honourable gentleman has really shown much appreciation of or concern for the importance with which many people regard the Commonwealth and its relevance to modern day issues. There is only one other thing I would like to say. Austerity in government does not mean, and never has meant, that in all things we spend less or are necessarily restrained in expenditure. In programs for the disabled and disadvantaged people within the community the expenditure of this Government is almost double that of the previous Labor Administration. That is because we give it a very high place on our list of priorities. We are able to do that only by being restrained in those matters which are of less importance. A Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, which will take place in Australia maybe once in 50 or 60 years, is something which this Government and, I believe, much of the Australian community will regard as being something of importance, even if the honourable gentleman does not. Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DISPUTE
text: One of the features of a comthat munist society which most of us are' completely appalled to see is the extent to which authorities generally try to direct those who live within their countries to cast their votes in a particular direcbecome tion. I think one of the features not to be commended in current union practice where ballots are called fods the apparent adoption of a somewhat similar tactic. Not only is it to be deplored that the ballot boxes are so identified, that television cameras were played on the individuals casting their votes and that each individual was required to go out and put his vote in box in front of his colleagues. Even where a taken not through the ballot box but through show of hands, one sometimes doubts the extent to which a person holding a genuine and sincere view which might be contrary to the view of majority is prepared to get up and express it. think it is to be regretted, therefore, that cumstances of the present dispute have originated in a ballot which has taken place in somewhat dubious circumstances and in a manner which think most of us in this place would be appalled to see applied to the ballot boxes used for the election of members of this place. Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: PETROLEUM GAS
text: I am not a salesman for Datsun; nor can I explain why that company's liquefied petroleum gas conversion car was not a success. However, I can make some inquiries and advise the honourable member. Certainly it is the Government's policy to encourage LPG as an alternative type of fuel. We have been encouraging people to convert. We have been using Commonwealth vehicles as an example. I know that in some of the capital cities a considerable number of vehicles in the Commonwealth fleet have been converted to LPG. I think all these vehicles are capable of running on either LPG or gasolene. One of the encouraging features about LPG is the recently reduced international price. If this decrease reflects on to the Australian market it means that LPG prices will come down. Certainly, that in itself ought to be an added encouragement for people to convert to LPG. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, n-mely: The inability of the Australian Defence Forces to to the open ended commitment to a Sinai force and at the same time develop basic Australian defence requirements. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: It is not my intention to deal with the foreign policy or political implications of the commitment of an Australian defence force outside Australia. My concern is the effect that such commitments have on the Defence Force, the development of Australian defence policy and the directions of planning for the defence of Australia which, to say the least, is currently inadequate and is rendered even more inadequate by ad hoc commitments which do not necessarily reflect the Government's planning for the Defence Force, nor the capacity of the Defence Force to respond in such instances. It is known that during 1978-79, when a force was requested to serve in the proposed United Nations force in Namibia, the Defence Committee and the Defence Force leaders made it clear to the Government that the capacity to provide a force of the size and type which was being suggested did not exist. Ultimately, a force of 250 non-combatants was agreed upon, with 50 security troops to protect that force. If accepted now, this commitment would place a serious strain on the capabilities of the Australian Army. This commitment was strongly argued against, because of its effects on the Defence Force, by senior defence personnel and members of the Australian Defence Committee. The current offer is not in response to a United Nations commitment and, according to correspondence exchanged between the Australian Government and the United States recently, it does not reflect a necessity. The Government has made it clear in statements that it believes the capacity to supervise the withdrawal in the Sinai exists within the two powers party to the agreement, which are not at this stage seen to be under any threat, or likely to be under any threat from a power other than one of those in agreement to the withdrawal. The force proposed is not a United Nations force, as was suggested. It is to be a United States formed multinational force made up of unknown components. Australia has been requested to make a commitment to provide forces for two years, or, as would be more acceptable to the United States, three years. The minimum period is two years. The countries acceptable to the two parties and of whom a request has so far been made are Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Canada, Equador, Fiji, respond Italy, the Netherlands, Singapore, Mexico, Nepal, New Zealand and Uruguay. A substantial number of those countries will not accede to the request unless some form of pressure is applied or unless they are offered incentives which would make it difficult for them to reject the United States request. These countries do not constitute substantive military powers. The United States has indicated it is prepared to provide up to half of the force requirements. One country of that number is expected to provide a force equivalent to battalion size-in this case a truncated battalion of between 500 and 600 men. It is suggested that the force be lightly armed, which places it in the category of a token commitment, not a real commitment, and in a situation where if any hostilities of any description break out in the area the force will be totany incapable of self-defence. The force will be going into an area where technicany military capabilities are of the highest levels in the world. It is a fact that the highest per capita levels of military expenditure in the world are now taking place in that region. It is also true to say that any force which goes into that area goes into a region of uncertainty and hostility and cannot be guaranteed secure, peaceful tenure during its period of service-and peace is the only thing for which it will be armed. Mr Harris-You want 100 per cent assurances.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: It would be nice to have some assurance. I do not expect the honourable member to have any serious regard for the defence of Australia. An he is interested in is the political mileage he might make out of the commitment of Australian forces but not the risk undertaken by them. The serious question that must be asked-Mr Newman-If you want to be rude about people do not be rude about him. He has done more than you will ever do.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I am not questioning what the honourable member has done. I am saying that in this Parliament the Government is not taking a serious position on the defence of Australia or the security of Australian forces which the Government is prepared to commit for purely base political reasons. If Australia provides a force approaching battalion strength, which would be expected from Australia if it is to make a significant contribution rather than a token contribution, one of the task forces in Australia will be rendered almost totany inoperative. It is reasonable to expect that the members of the force will be taken from the operational battalions at Townsville, although they could be taken from other areas where a different type of training and preparation is currently in hand. But to remove a battalion or a substantive part of a battalion from Townsville would leave not even a skeleton force to provide the reinforcements which must be ready to replace the Middle East force on a reasonably regular basis. We are looking at a two-year to three-year commitment. In the documents, as the Minister would surely be aware, there is a request from the United States for the option of a further commitment beyond the three-year period. The effect on the Australian Defence Force would be to remove the Army's potential for operational activities within its own region and to take away its capacity for training. During the period of our commitment we could not even provide an adequate force to participate in exercises such as Kangaroo II or III, or Kangaroo IV, which is now coming up. We could not provide adequately the force which would be expected of us if the Namibia offer, which has been made by Australia, is taken up. We would be placing at serious risk our relations with a number of Arab countries which are hostile to any force which is United States based going into the Middle East. The matter which is before us for discussion and decision today concerns what the planning for and use of the Australian defence forces is all about. In the priorities the Government has set, and in statements which have been presented by members of the Department of Defence to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, it is clearly indicated that commitment to United Nations forces, whilst an important objective of defence policy, is not a significant priority in the planning of the Defence Force. As far as the Army is concerned, no attempt has been made over the past five years to equip the Army for any form of combat whatsoever. Its priority is nil in the equipment purchasing programs of the Government. As a result of decisions taken on major equipment items and deferment of commitments made in 1976, the Defence Force commitments for the next several years are almost exclusively in the area of provision of major equipment items for the Air Force and, subsequently, the Navy. The major equipment purchases for the Army in the past four years have been in the nature of trucks, not armaments. There is an argument at the moment about whether the Rapier missiles which the Army had acquired for its use will, in fact, be under Army control or will be transferred to the Air Force. The Air Force is certainly making a bid. The Government's own advisers have expressed serious concern at this type of operation. Those advisers include the most senior advisers in the defence area. The Government is well aware of this situation. It is also true to say, and I repeat, that the Government's foreign policy advisers have advised the United States that they are not happy with the request for this commitment, but they feel an obligation to meet it. It would serve Australia's defence interests best if the Government determined what it expects its defence forces to be able to do because within their budget they cannot carry out a multi-role function. The Government certainly has not equipped, or sought to equip, the Army for foreign policy extension operations such as this. That is what we are talking about. There is certainly no real need, other than the demands of one of the parties concerned, for a force to go into the Sinai. The force would not be capable, if formulated even in the maximum form requested, of providing any form of protection should any hostilities break out. It is not an isolated area as is generally accepted. It is not an area where hostilities are currently taking place. But it is in close proximity to those areas in the Middle East where conflict is at present taking place. The force could, by certain parties in that area, be seen to be performing a role of releasing forces of one party to go into operational areas on another border. The Australian Defence Force is being treated in a cavalier manner. Firstly the Government's determinations suggest that the Australian Army should have the last priority in defence reequipment programs, especially in armaments. It then makes commitments for operations of the Australian Army which will make impossible the training and development programs which the Government has announced for the Army, limited as those may be. Certainly, the removal of a substantial number of troops from the Townsville area or from the training areas at Ingleburn in New South Wales will render whichever task force is involved practically inoperable because of the lack of available manpower. Their training programs will be disrupted to an extremely high degree over a long period. If the Namibia proposition is also taken up the Australian Defence Force will be rendered impotent because the manpower commitments to foreign policy objectives of the Government rather than the defence of Australia will be sllch that the defence forces, because of the limitations of finance and other limitations which have been placed on them, will be rendered incapable of providing a capacity for the defence of Australia which is desirable and which is, at least, announced Government policy, although it is not terribly often applied. This proposal could also lead to much more serious problems for Australia, apart from the risk to the personnel involved, who will not be armed to cope with the situation in the area. If we commit a serviceman to an area I believe we have an obligation to ensure that he has both the protection and the military equipment which is comparable, competent and capable of being effectively utilised in the area. It would be ludicrous in this day and age to suggest that we would send horse cavalry into a modern battle, but with the Middle East situation the relevance of the armaments available to the Australian Army is not greatly different from that. If any form of hostilities involving the Australian forces broke out in that area they would be totally incapable of defending themselves with what is available and what could be made available in existing circumstances. It is all right to say 'a light force in a peaceful operation'. Anyone who is prepared to predict that the Middle East will remain peaceful for any period, let alone the next three years, is prepared to take risks with other people's lives. The Opposition believes that a commitment to this type of force, irrespective of the political consequences or the political motivations, will involve a diminution of the capacity of the Australian defence forces to carry out the role which should be their prime objective, that is, the preparation and carrying out of tasks associated with ensuring the security of Australia. This is a commitment by the Government to a reduction in that capacity.

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: Bass-Minister for Administrative Services and Acting Minister for Defence) (3.27)-1 begin by saying that I am surprised that the Opposition raised this subject as a matter of public importance. The suggestion that the Australian Defence Force may not be capable of making the kind of commitment that the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) has been talking about is sheer nonsense. In fact, it is absolutely fundamental to our force structure planning that we do have the capability to respond to a task of this nature. Before I expand on that, 1 think it is necessary to make a few points clear. By implication, the honourable member for Corio made some assertions which are simply not correct. The position was made quite clear by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) on 26 May, when he made his statement on the Sinai peacekeeping force. We have received no request for this commitment. I repeat that: We have received no formal request for this commitment. Obviously it has been admitted that there is suggestion that we might receive a request, and that has not been in any way concealed from this Parliament. The second point that has to be made is that before we agree to the request, when it comes, we have to have a great deal of information before us about what the role and size of this force may be, what other forces it will co-operate with, and so on. There is absolutely no way that the Government will make the commitment, when the request comes, unless we are in possession of all the proper information that would be required for our defence advisers and, of course, the Government to make a proper decision on the request. I make that absolutely clear. Therefore, it is folly for the Opposition to speculate on the level of the force that may be committed if the decision is finally made along that line. I stress again that no request has been made. We would need to have a lot of information before we met the request. Therefore, it is wrong to start speCUlating on what size of force may be involved. I wish to make one other point before I come back to the assertions made by the Opposition speaker, the honourable member for Corio. He mentioned the reaction of Arab countries. That is one of the questions that we are seeking to find out about, to establish, to analyse. I think that has been made clear by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on several occasions. In all, far from treating this proposition that may come to us in a cavalier fashion, the Government makes it clear that it will take the matter extremely seriously. It will assess the information that it receives very carefully. Then it will make a decision. That is far from making a cavalier statement. Let me come back to the technical part of the debate. I said that it is fundamental to our force structure planning that we have a capability to respond to this type of operation. Let us take as an example the force predicated by the Opposition spokesman; that is, a battalion. Let us say that the request is for a battalion and let us say that we responded to that request. I want to stress again that I am simply speculating. I think it is an interesting point to take the example of a battalion deployment because then we can see how correct or incorrect the Opposition is in describing what effect that would have on the Defence Force. The honourable member made several assertions about our request to take part in the United Nations Transition Assistance Group force in Namibia and about training. Let me deal with those precisely. First of all, the deployment of a battalion would not affect the following: The availability in Australia of the operational deployment force, the ODF; the availability of the engineering unit set aside for possible use in the United Nations operation in Namibia; the force specially trained to meet the anti-terrorist operations in Australia; the joint forces exercises which he mentioned and which have been planned with allies and neighbours within our region; the major exercise of our troops of the defence forces planned for this year, Kangaroo 81; the capital equipment program already laid down in Defence Force planning; and the development of Defence Force facilities in Australia would not be affected.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: That is not what the Defence people are saying.

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I made a very precise statement. The Government stands by that statement that I have just made. In fact, arising out of those very firm precise statements that I have made, and I might say, on the precise advice of our advisers, this commitment therefore adds up to this: If we had to make a commitment of the force predicated by the Opposition, that is, a battalion, in fact, far from disrupting the defence forces, it would be a demonstration of the degree of preparedness that we have now in the forces. Not only could we meet this role but also we could meet all the tasks and the activities previously planned and which I have just set out. In fact, this commitment would test our ability to make this kind of deployment, and not only to make the deployment but also to support it properly from Australia. It is the very kind of training, if it is put in that context, that will benefit the Defence Force from time to time. The deployment of an infantry battalion, as the Opposition suggested, would be an illustration of our ability to get our force there and, once we got it to the Sinai, to support it. My colleague, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), will talk about the methods that we would use to get it there. That will demonstrate the ability to move our forces out of Australia and deploy them to operational areas. He will be talking about our capacity with our 707s, C130s, HMAS Tobruk, HMAS Jervis Bay and all the rest. I make the point again so that everybody will hear it loudly and clearly: The support of an infantry battalion to the Sinai as an example is within our present capabilities. Of course, it would not operate independently. It would have to be part of a much bigger multinational peacekeeping force. Perhaps I could take time to answer the point that the Opposition spokesman was making about that force. He tried to suggest that there is already a force in being and countries have suggested that they will go and that it will be on that basis that we will agree to the deployment. Again, I make it very clear that before we would make the commitment, one of the vital pieces of information that we would need to know would be what countries we would be co-operating with and what countries would be subscribing to the force, what their capabilities would be and so on. The point that I think the Opposition is trying to make is that somehow the Army has been left out in the force development; that it is an unbalanced development. Let us look at what the Army is doing. The Army is now preparing, planning and testing its ability to meet a number of commitments. For example, I have already menhonourable tioned the anti-terrorist plan that has place. I think it is now common knowledge that the Special Air Service regiment is training to have a capability to meet the plan. If we are unfortunate enough to have to bear the brunt of an international-type terrorist activity such as we have seen occur around the world where terrorists such as diplomats take hostages in our country then of course,although it would be principally State ot' police action to solve the problem, the fence forces have the capability to back up that police effort if it were requested. So the ability the SAS which principally would meet that quest for additional defence support has been trained to a high capability to assist the police such an action. Those who have been fortunate enough to see the high degree of capability this already reached by the SAS, can only describe as a superb level of training. I suggest, although fortunately, it has never been tested in real battle, it would meet any of the standards that have set by other such forces around the world. That one example of a principal support element of the Defence Force. I have already mentioned the fact that if a battalion, as has been predicted by the Opposition, were deployed, it would not affect the ODF. It simply would not affect it. I am assured by our advisers that our ability to meet contingency plans from that force is not impeded at all.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: That is not what they are saying in their documents.

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I do not care what sort of documents the honourable member has. I am giving him the facts. On many occasions, in this place, we find the Opposition quoting from unnameq documents or documents that it picks out of rubbish tins and so on and it then asserts the Australian people that these are facts. Honourable members opposite do not do this nation any good by doing that. Instead of supportmand. ing the efforts being made by the defence forces and giving the nation some confidence in the training, ability and standards of our defence forces, they go a long way to undermining that confidence which is necessary in our nation. does them no credit.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: You are being childish.

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: Order! The member will not use unparliamentary been put in language. He will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: He has made personal reflections which he is not entitled to make. He doesn't know what he is talking about, that is his trouble.

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I am not making any personal reflections at all. I am merely taking up the false accusations that have been made here today. a If they reflect on the honourable member persondeally, so be it. I am only taking up the points that he is purporting to make in this debate. There are of two other elements that I would like to reaffirm. reAnother question raised was in relation to the nature of the Army and its training to meet a in range of contingencies. Although it is not certain that finally the Army would end up with a force of nature, it has to be accepted that it is training it to meet a number of contingencies with its battalions. Work is being done, for example, to produce a mechanised infantry battalion that would been be able to range and operate in a number of is environments. Likewise, we have just seen an exercise conducted in Tasmania, quite successfully, where a force was deployed from the Royal Australian Air Force base in Townsville into Tasmania. It landed by parachute and conducted the exercise which was very successful and which demonstrated the flexibility of the deployment of a battalion in yet another role. I use these examples to show how the Army is training to meet a range of contingencies and a range of operations. That hardly sounds like an Army that somehow has not the wherewithall to meet this training requirement and to meet new roles. We all know that the roles that the Army has to meet go across a wide spectrum. I summarise what I have been saying. Using the illustration given by the Opposition, I have tried to to demonstrate that if we had to deploy-I only say 'if'-an infantry battalion the Defence Force would be more than capable of meeting that deAt the same time it would be capable of meeting without any detriment to it at all not only its continued planned force development but also other contingencies for which it has been prepared. The deployment would not in any way imIt pair the Government's fundamental plans for the continued development of the Defence Force.

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: 1 was interested to note in the comments made by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who at the moment is Acting Minister for Defence, a back pedalling on the commitment for a force to the Sinai. For the first time he has introduced a number of very serious qualifications. He certainly does not reflect the enthusiasm shown by his colleagues, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). 1 believe that this serves to underline that the defence forces are not enamoured of the prospect of a deployment to the Sinai force. That very concept in the manner in which it has been presented, particularly by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, runs counter to the present planning and the philosophy of Australia's defence. Let me take up one very important point which is reflected in the matter of public importance before the House. The commitment to a Sinai force is an open-ended commitment. I use these terms advisedly. The Minister for Foreign Affairs in his statement said that it would be difficult for the Australian Government to consider an openended commitment but, throughout the speech that he made to this House, he sought to convey the impression that this was only of a temporary nature. Let us look at the realities. There is no cutoff date or fixed term in the Camp David Accords for the force. The commitment is indefinite. According to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the commitment will be maintained as long as either party believes it to be necessary. It could go on for years. I wish to make it very clear that the terms for the presence of a force in the Sinai are indisputably open-handed. What then would be the commitment for the individual participants? What would be Australia's commitment? Again, let us look at the realities. We all know that there is a widespread and understandable reluctance by countries throughout the world to get involved. The responsibility of maintaining the continuity of that Sinai peacekeeping force will be in the hands of only a very small group of countries. That very small group of countries will be left to carry the baby. The Minister will be aware of the discussions that have been going on. The United States of America has made it clear that the commitments of participants to the Sinai force will be for at least two years and, more likely, three years. The Minister will be aware also that the United States has told the Australian Government quite clearly that the forces of participating countries could well be asked to remain beyond that period. The commitment is open-ended but this Government is very likely not to resist United States pressure for Australian participants to stay on and on. The Minister has spoken of our capacity to put a force into the Sinai but he has not spoken about our capacity to maintain a force of one battalion year after year, which is the likely consequence of a commitment to the Sinai force. This can serve only to distort the planning for the defence of Australia. It will become irreparably distorted. Australia is not, as we well know, a superpower and it has limited resources. These resources are most properly devoted to our main defence responsibility-the defence of Australia. 1 thought this proposition had been accepted on a bipartisan basis. It is a singularly sensible statement arising, as it does, from the philosophy and the administration of the Australian Labor Party when in office in the years 1972-75. There is a very distinct and delineated area of Australia's primary strategic concern. I wish to quote from the White Paper on defence issued by this Government in November 1976 which put forward a number of propositions that were carried over from the Labor Party's administration of defence. The White Paper states: For practical purposes the requirement and scope of Australia's defence activity are limited essentially to the areas closer to home. These are our adjacent maritime areas; the south-west Pacific countries and territories; Papua New Guinea, Indonesia; and the South-East Asia region. It continues: Events in distant areas such as Africa, the Middle East arid North East Asia (assuming there were international sanctions for Australia's involvement) are beyond the reach of effective defence activity by Australia. That sums up the standing of Australian Defence Force thinking, not only in 1976 but also through the period 1972-75 and, I trust, now. I want to turn to the role of the Sinai force to which this Government is seeking to commit Australia. On any reading there is an Alice in Wonderland haze about the whole concept of the Sinai force. Does anyone really believe that a put together force of 2,000 lightly armed personnel is anything more than a token, the worse form of plate glass diplomacy? A small force of that nature, if smashed, will bring on to the scene the major insurance policy holders. The concern of the Australian Labor Party is that Australians should not be sacrificed as one of the splinters from that plate glass diplomacy. We all know that the force will be concentrated in two areas-in the north at Rafau on the Mediterranean and in the south at Sharm El Sheikh on the Red Sea. These areas are separated by something of the order of 250 miles of the Sinai Desert. Not even the Israeli Government would regard the proposed Sinai force as anything more than a flimsy security blanket unless-this is the important qualification-United States forces were directly involved. One could well be excused for believing that the repeated references to a UN force in the Camp David Accords are a sham. Israel, for a variety of reasons-undoubtedly it thinks they are good reasons-is insistent that the United States should guarantee its security and, to that end, wants the United States directly involved in the force. As we all know, paragraph 8 of Article VJ of Annex I of the Camp David Accords states that the United Nations force and observers will be drawn from nations other than members of the Security Council. This automatically excludes the big powers, including, of course, the United States. However, we have all noted that President Carter's letter of 26 March 1979 provides the let out by agreeing to provide an acceptable alternative multinational force if a United Nations force did not eventuate. In a recent question addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I asked: As both Israel and Egypt have a direct and significant interest in ensuring that the Camp David Accords are fully implemented, will the Minister urge both governments to assume responsibility for managing forces without the necessity for a multinational force? We should realise that already there has been a major withdrawal from the Sinai area. Israeli troops have withdrawn from over two-thirds of that area. This has all been handled by a Sinai field mission of some 200 civilians. A simple proposition which I think we should put, and which we should urge the Minister to put to the United States, is: Why cannot that Sinai field mission continue to handle the withdrawal processes? It has certainly been successful up to now. I see no reason why it cannot be successful in the future. The important point is that the Camp David Accords are agreements between two governments. Both of those governments have a vested interest in ensuring the success of those Accords. They have a responsibility to themselves, to peace in the Middle East and to the rest of the world to ensure that their conduct under the Accords is such that there is no necessity for a peace force in the Sinai. There is certainly no necessity, as we on this side of the House see it, for Australian participation in a non-United Nations force in the Sinai area.

Speaker: Mr SHIPTON
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: The matter of public importance raised by the Opposition today is an attack on the Australian defence forces. Besides being an attack on the defence forces, it is an attack on attempts in this place to have a bipartisan approach to defence policy. I find that very disappointing indeed. This is an attack on all the forces-the Royal Australian Navy, the Royal Australian Air Force and the Army-and an attack on the institution and morale of those forces. The defence forces must quiver when they hear members of the Opposition in this place carryon the way they do. They only denigrate the defence institutions of this country. They talk down the good things and are negative about the Australian defence forces. It is quite disgraceful to have the Opposition spokesman on defence matters, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), and the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison), a former Minister for Defence, speaking in the way they did, attacking the defence forces of Australia. The whole policy of members of the Australian Labor Party on this matter, as in so many other matters, is to knock, to whinge and to talk Australia down but not up. In their speeches they ought to express pride in the Australian defence forces rather than be puerile about them. The position of the Camp David Accords and the peace treaty is clear. Israel has withdrawn success- from two thirds of the Sinai and, under the arrangements, planned to complete its withdrawal the withdrawal of Israeli by the end of April 1981. Both parties, Egypt and Israel, envisaged United Nations supervision. We did not hear from the Opposition today that the Soviet Union effectively vetoed the proposition to have a United Nations force. The United Nations Security Council has been unable to reach agreement; the Soviet Union has vetoed the United Nations peacekeeping force proposed under the Accords and the peace treaty. The United Nations has failed to fulfil its role under the peace treaty. Israel, whose security is threatened, regards the establishment of an effective peacekeeping force as an integral part of the treaty and a prerequisite for final withdrawal. That is perfectly sensible and reasonable because the security of the State of Israel is involved. Let us look at the Opposition's position. Its members have come into this House today to talk about the capacity of the Australian defence forces, denigrating that capacity. But they have hidden under this smoke-screen their real policy, which is that they are against any peacekeeping force other than a United Nations force. They fail to face up to the fact that the Soviet Union has vetoed such a force. It is a smoke-screen, and an attack on the defence forces. They have put up that smoke-screen for a number of reasons, one of which is the confused ALP policy on the Middle East. They are ashamed of their policy, so they have attacked the defence forces in this House today. They are confused about their Middle East policy and wish to hide their actual policy, which is against peace. They wish to hide behind this smoke-screen a number of things, including the power of the socialist Left in the Australian Labor Party. As well as the battle going on between the socialist Left and the rest of the party, they wish also to hide the leadership dispute in the Australian Labor Party. They are the four or five things they are trying to hide behind the smokescreen they have put up by talking about defence in this House today. The Opposition is against anything other than a United Nations force. One assumes, from the comments of the honourable members for Corio and St George that they are against other peacekeeping forces and bodies in the world, that they were against the Commonwealth heads of government initiatives in getting peace in Zimbabwe. I assume from what they both said today that they are against Australia's contribution to the election peace processes in Zimbabwe. They should have been working for peace at all levels. There ought to be some of that lateral thinking about which the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) talks. Honourable members opposite ought to consider, if the United Nations fails to deliver peace, whether any other bodies or institutions can bring about peace. I would have thought they ought to be interested in peace itself. That is what they should be about. I regret that the bipartisan support that one would hope for in this area, which was inherent in the statement of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) to this House in September 1978, on the Camp David Accords, no longer exists. That is a shame. On 26 May of this year, in relation to the statement made in 1978, the Leader of the Opposition stated: . . . were comments of a somewhat hopeful expectation on the basis of the Camp David Accords as we understand them. That statement was a shame and it also clearly attacks Israel. The Parliament of the people of Australia deserves a clear statement of why the Labor Party no longer supports the Camp David Accords. A possible explanation which emerged after a special meeting of the Labor Caucus on 14 May this year is that the Accords are yet another victim of the policy of the Leader of the Opposition to curry favour with the left wing elements of his party.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 to provide for changes covering: (a) supplementary licences for radio stations; (b) public interest criteria; (c) ownership or control provisions; (d) the Australian Broadcasting Commission's merchandising and contractual activities; and (e) other minor amendments. The House will l'ecall that in a statement on 9 October 1980 my predecessor, the Hon. A. A. Staley, foreshadowed legislation to introduce supplementary licences as a means of increasing the range of broadcasting services available in nonmetropolitan areas. The Government recognised that in those areas where an additional fully competitive commercial station was not a viable proposition an alternative needed to be found which widened the choice of services. The supplementary licence concept was conceived as a means of providing additional radio and television services, while protecting the commercial viability of existsubject ing services in the area and preserving the principle oflocalism in broadcasting. The Bill provides for the introduction of supplementary licences for commercial FM radio in areas outside Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth. While commercial FM services have begun operation in mainland metropolitan areas, no commercial FM services are available in regional areas. Many such areas cannot support fully competitive FM services, and accordingly the only means of providing these services in those areas is through the supplementary licence concept. This will enable an existing mercial AM operator to provide an FM service in any area not able to support a fully competitive service. Honourable members will note that the Bill does not provide for supplementary television licences. The Government has decided not to proceed at this time with supplementary television licences, following extensive discussions with the television industry and following representations by regional television operators that in many cases supplementary television licences would not be commercially viable without a subscription television component. Before any introduction of subscription television services is contemplated, a number of issues will need to be considered, not the least of which is the desirability of such services and the ground rules within which they should operate. Furthermore, the Government believes it WOUld, in any case, be anomalous to introduce subscription television into regional areas without also considering such services for metropolitan areas. Accordingly, the Government has referred the matter of SUbscription television to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for consideration in conjunction with its inquiry into cable television. No decision regarding subscription television will be made until the Tribunal presented its report, which is expected in March 1982. The Government is conscious of the fact that in a limited number of areas supplementary television licences may be viable without a subscription television component. However, the Government is not prepared to make separate provision specifically for those areas at this time. It believes that any introduction of supplementary television licences to increase commercial services should be considered in a wider context. The Government is anxious that large regional cities and the smaller capitals such as Canberra should have the opportunity for increased services at the earliest practicable opportunity. It is anticipated that Government will be making further decisions on the following receipt of the Tribunal's report. In particular, representations have been received from the CTC7 group in Canberra and a station in Hobart in the expectation that two supplementary licences would be provided for their use in those two centres. The Government has considered theil' representations. However, as with the other major sub-metropolitan area of Newcastle, where again the population base and the nature of the commercial television coverage is such as perhaps to justify more than one supplementary licence, it is felt that the introduction of specific provisions to accommodate their com- peculiar circumstances could not properly proceed in isolation from consideration of the matters that will be under debate in this Parliament following receipt of the report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on the cable television and subscription television inquiry that I mentioned a little while ago. The House will also recall that on 9 April 1981 I announced to the Parliament the broad thrust of the conclusions reached by the Government after its review of aspects of the Act. I foreshadowed amendments covering: 1. The machinery and procedural aspects of sections 90 to 92KA of the Act; and 2. inadvertent breaches of the Act by shareholders in companies acquiring interests in radio and television broadcasting licences through share trading on the stock exchange. Necessarily that statement did not express with the same precision as legislation the changes proposed to the Act. Honourable members will note that in some respects the Bill differs from the proposals then outlined. The changes follow from has further consultation with the industry. However, that statement did outline in general terms a package of proposals with two major themes which certainly remain relevant. Firstly, the amendments will maintain the basic structure of decision making that has been in operation since 1977. The amendments will provide the means for more effective administration of the broadcasting system in accordance with government policy. The lack of reference points for the Tribunal in deciding whether a particular licensing decision would be in the public interest has led to some uncertainty in Tribunal proceedings. The incorporation of legislative guidelines for public interest will provide a clearer statement of government policy in relation to the major discretionary powers of the Tribunal. Secondly, the amendments are designed to ensure that the ownership or control provisions will remain effective and appropriate to the commercial environment of the 1980s. Restrictions on the free transfer of interests should be no greater than are necessary to achieve a reasonable balance between the desirability of preventing uncontrolled trading in licences and the need for a vigorous share market. It has become apparent that the present share transaction procedures, which, of course, require the Tribunal's approval prior to any purchase, may operate to prevent a large diversified industrial corporation, for example, from lawfully purchasing shares on the open market in another such corporation, if the second corporation has an indirect interest in a radio or television station of as little as 6 per cent of issued capital. The Government regards such a result as inappropriate for an Act which is designed only to regulate radio and television, and unnecessary to achieve the aims of the legislation. This applies even more strongly in the case of third party breaches of the Act. It is only in exceptional circumstances in our system of justice that a person should be immediately liable for an offence as a result of some other person's actions. In this instance, the circumstances certainly do not warrant such a result. In the Government's view, any person being put into inadvertent breach of the Act should not face possible prosecution, without first being allowed at least six months to comply with the ownership limitations. On 9 April last, my colleagues the Attorney General (Senator Durack) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), representing the Attorney-General, tabled in Parliament a report by the Administrative Review Council on the inquiry procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. In my statement to the House on the same day I said that there would not be any decision as to specific recommendations until the public and the broadcasting industry had the opportunity to comment. I have, through my Department, recently contacted interested individuals and organisations asking for their comments on the report by the end of July. Therefore, I expect the Government to be in a position to consider specific recommendations of the report later in the year. I also point out that during the preparation of the Bill and particularly following my announcement to the House on 9 April there has been considerable public debate. In particular, details of the proposals have been discussed extensively with a wide range of broadcasting and television groups and all those who have made contact with my office. The idea, of course, was to ensure that in the application of the ownership or control amendments those who were immediately affected should have some opportunity of expressing the consequences as they saw them. Certainly, overall the objective was to assess the impact of suggested changes before the details of the Bill now to be presented to the Parliament were finalised. In summary, the intention of the present amendments is to streamline procedures, avoid delays in the Tribunal's consideration of transactions, minimise the necessary number of inquiries and provide clearer guidance in relation to the Tribunal's major discretionary powers. I turn now to the detail of the proposed amendments. Supplementary Licences for Radio Stations The Bill will enable commercial AM licensees, in areas other than Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth, to apply for a supplementary licence to operate an FM radio service in their areas. Provision has also been made to allow licensees, in areas where there is more than one AM station, if they so choose, to form a consortium to apply for one supplementary licence on a joint basis. Because of the different propagation characteristics of FM as opposed to AM signals, provision is also made for the Minister to invite an applicant to apply for associated commercial translator licences. The intent behind this provision is to ensure that an area currently served by a commercial AM station and its associated translator stations will as far as possible be able to be served by a supplementary FM station together with its associated translator stations. Applicants will make their applications to the Minister in accordance with a form approved by him. Applications can be made by commercial AM operators only to provide a supplementary FM service in their own areas. Unlike other licence applications, where applicants apply in response to an invitation by the Minister, applicants for supplementary licences will be able to apply at any time. The Minister will, however, be able to refer the application to the Tribunal or to reject the application on grounds relating to technical matters or to the planning or development of broadcasting and television services. This provision arises from the Minister's statutory responsibilities for the planning and development of these services. There is, after all, only a limited spectrum and it is essential that there is a capacity to regulate the available area within it. In considering applications for supplementary licences the Tribunal will follow similar procedures to those applying to other licences. For example, in considering an application for a supplementary licence, the Tribunal will be required to take account of the criteria applying to the grant of other licences. However, an additional provision will enable the Tribunal to refuse to grant a supplementary licence in any area which can sustain a fully competitive commercial broadcasting station without endangering the viability of existing services. If the Tribunal finds that an additional commercial station would be viable then it will be required to inform the Minister of its determination and the reasons for it. Supplementary licences will be granted for up to five years and renewed for up to three years. The Tribunal shall, in considering any renewal of a supplementary licence not less than eight years after the initial grant of a supplementary licence, determine whether an additional commercial station is reasonably likely to be viable in that area. If it finds that such a station would be viable, it shall recommend to the Minister that he invite applications for a commercial licence and shall give the supplementary licensee three years' notice of its intention not to renew the supplementary licence. A licensee, but not a consortium, will be able in such a case to opt to retain the broadcasting station operated under his supplementary licence and instead forgo the station operated under his commercial licence. This provision is intended to cover a broadcaster wishing to retain his supplementary FM station rather than his commercial AM station. In this case the supplementary licence will convert to a normal commercial licence. I need to comment oil some aspects of supplementary licences which have been the subject of some recent concern by the broadcasting industry. A decision to seek a supplementary licence is entirely a decision for the licensee in the area concerned.
