The ministerial discretion to dismiss applications can be on only technical grounds or for planning and development reasons, for example, where no frequencies are available or where the calling of applications for a fully competitive service is contemplated. I emphasise that the ministerial discretion must be interpreted within the scope, purposes and objects of the Act, which are all laid down and are available for everybody to see and understand. The minimum duration of a supplementary licence is 11 years with no consideration of non-renewal before eight years. The procedures for renewal impose what I believe is reasonable protection for the licensee on the one hand and the public on the other. The Government believes this provides an adequate period for licensees to recoup their investment. Finally, it is not correct to suggest that there are no appeals against decisions by the Tribunal which apply to other classes of licence. The appeal provisions in section 119A apply equally to supplementary licences as to other classes of licences, the only difference being that there is no appeal against non-renewal ability after eight years. Special provisions have been inserted to allow the supplementary licence to continue in operation in circumstances where the Tribunal has decided not to renew the licence but for one reason or another competitive licences have not been issued. The Bill includes a number of special provisions relating to localism and arrangements with other radio stations. Specifically, supplementary licensees will need to seek Tribunal approval for arrangements entered into with other stations for the regular broadcasting of: (i) the programs of a related commercial AM station or other commercial stations; (ii) the programs of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Special Broadcasting Service or public stations. This provision will provide some degree of Tribunal oversight over the simulcasting· of programs-that is, the simultaneous transmission in one area of the same radio program by two or more stations-or the networking of radio programs from other areas. Other provisions intended to preserve the principle of localism are those relating to: (i) the minimum amount of locally produced or originated programs as provided for by licence conditions; and (ii) the encouragement of local advertising. The proposed amendments will provide a legal basis for the introduction of supplementary licences for radio. However, it needs to be noted that substantial lead. times are involved both for the industry and for my Department. This involves giving reasonable notice to those who will be required to vacate the 88-108MHz band, and the determination of station service areas. Substantial costs may also be involved. The decisions required can be made, and the costs minimised, only if all concerned in the process of clearing band are given adequate notice of the Governadequate ment's intention. There is already a considerable backlog of applications to be considered relating to the existing range of broadcasting and telegreater vision services. Planning for supplementary cences will proceed in parallel with the clearing this backlog and the introduction of nontakes metropolitan commercial FM services. Accordthe ingly, at a later date, I intend to make a major statement regarding planning guidelines for stage of development of commercial FM services. For these reasons, the Bill includes a transitional provision that no applications for supplementary licences may be made before a date to be fixed by proclamation. Public Interest Criteria Clauses 13, 16, 18, 19,28 and 38 of the Bill vide for legislative guidelines for the public interest component of the major discretionary powers of the Tribunal in relation to licence this grant, renewal, suspension, revocation or transfer and in relation to the approval ture, transactions. Although the words 'public interest' do not currently appear in the Act in respect of licence grants and transfers, the High Court of Australia has confirmed in the 2HD case that the concept of public interest is a relevant factor in the exercise of the Tribunal's discretionthe ary powers even where it is not explicitly stated. The Bill provides a consistent codification of lic interest for all the major discretionary powers. Dependent on the type of application, the public interest criteria will be established according to the following guidelines: (i) whether the applicant will meet or has met an undertaking to: (a) compJywith the conditions ora licence; (b) provide an adequate and comprehensive service in pursuance to: be served; munity;and vices which may be received in the same area; (c) encourage the provision of Australian produced programs and the use of Australian creative resources; (ii) whether a person or company is fit and proper to hold an interest in a licence; (iii) the financial, technical and management capacity to undertake the operations of a licence; (iv) in non-metropolitan areas (Le. outside the six State capitals) the degree of concentration of influence of radio or television stations; and (v) the commercial viability of stations in the area. the The undertaking concerning the provision of an and comprehensive service in pursuance of the licence provides a focus for public input at licensing inquiries. It is also intended to generate awareness in the public and the industry liof the need to provide programming which not of only complies with general standards, but also account of the particular characteristics of audience served. With regard to the concentration of influence on radio and television in rethis gional areas, honourable members should be aware that the principal Act already applies much stricter limits on ownership in metropolitan areas than in regional areas. It is not possible for any in. dividual to hold prescribed interests in more than one television station and one radio station in any one State capital city within the overall limit of two television or eight radio stations. On the other prohand it would not be illegal for one person to control up to two television stations and four radio stations in a regional city such as Newcastle. In latter case, it is clearly desirable that the Tribunal should be able to limit undesirable of share, or debenconcentration. Ownership or Control Provisions NA NA The current ownership or control provisions of Act provide that it is an offence to hold prescribed interests in more than two commercial pubtelevision licences or more than eight commercial radio licences. The acquisition of a prescribed interest or an increase in a prescribed interest, as defined in the Act, is currently subject to prior approval by the Tribunal. The provisions restrict the opportunities to purchase shares or debentures in a company if they would confer on the purchaser a prescribed interest in a licence. It is proposed that the requirement for prior approval of such transactions be relaxed whilst preserving the prinof the licence, having regard ciple that changes in the ownership or control of the nature of the community served or to licences be subject to effective public scrutiny. Most importantly, the Tribunal is being given the diversity of the interests of that comeffective powers to collect information on the nature of other radio/television serproposed transactions and to give directions to avoid irreversible adverse effects on the licensee prior to approval being given. Sections 90J and 92F of the principal Actclauses 27 and 37 of the Bill-are being amended to provide for the notification to the Tribunal of any intended transaction and the lodgement of an application for approval of either an intended transaction, or a completed transaction. Failure to lodge a notice or application prior to a transaction will be an offence on each day until a notice or application is lodged. However, such an offence will not preclude ultimate approval by the Tribunal of a transaction provided an application is lodged within 28 days. These amendments will allow the Tribunal to receive applications for approval of share transactions after, as well as before, transactions have taken place. New sections 90JA and 92FAA-clauses 28 and 38 of the Bill-make provision for the approval of share and debenture transactions. In summary, these sections provide: (i) for the Tribunal to approve an application in respect of share transactions after, as well as before, a transaction has taken place; (ii) that the Tribunal may disapprove an application made before or after a transaction provided that it first holds an inquiry into the intended transaction; that inquiry may at the Tribunal's discretion be: (a) a separate inquiry into the transaction; or (b) an inquiry into both the transaction and the renewal of the licence; (iii) that any inquiry may be required by the purchaser, in his application, to commence within three months after the application and if the inquiry does not commence within three months, the transaction is deemed to have been approved; and (iv) that the Tribunal shall take all reasonable steps to complete an inquiry within three months of commencing the inquiry. Where a transaction has taken place without prior approval the Tribunal may give directions to prevent any action it considers will have an adverse effect on the ability of a company holding the licence to comply with the conditions of the licence or on the operations, management or the selection or provision of programs by the licensee company. These powers are conferred by clause 40 in new section 92M. Clauses 28 and 38 of the Bill also provide the criteria which must be taken into account by the Tribunal in considering whether to approve a transaction. In particular, the clauses provide the grounds on which the Tribunal may refuse an application for the approval of a transaction, in whole or in part where an application is lodged in accordance with section 90J or 92F. These are: (i) in the case of a purchaser acquiring or increasing a major interest in the licence, the Tribunal would be empowered to refuse consent to the transfer of that licence to the applicant; This provision recognises that a major share transaction affecting a licensee and a transfer of the licence are, in practical terms, similar and the Tribunal would consider the same public interest criteria and other criteria as are provided for in clause 19, that is, section 89A dealing with transfers; (ii) in the case of a purchaser acquiring any interest in the licence, where the licence has been granted within the previous two years, this provision is intended to preserve the integrity of the licence grant process, by preventing an unsuccessful applicant for a licence from taking over the company of the successful applicant. (iii) in the case of a purchaser acquiring a minor interest, or any other applicant acquiring an indirect interest through the purchaser, where the applicant does not comply with public interest criteria, this provision applies the criteria in a more appropriate way to minor and indirect interests than if these were considered under point (i) above and take into account: (a) the effect the transaction will have on the capacity of the holder of the licence to comply with the conditions of the licence and the written undertakings given to the Tribunal in relation to program services; (b) whether the applicant is a fit and proper person to hold a licence and, as far as is relevant, has the necessary financial, technical and management capacities to carry out the requirements of a licence; and (c) the degree of concentration of influence either directly or indirectly, on commercial radio and television stations, in a nonmetropolitan area. These streamlined procedures and guidelines will provide adequate controls on the ownership of radio and television. The Tribunal's approval will be necessary for the acquisition or increase of a prescribed interest, and the Tribunal will retain a discretion to consider an acquisition in the context of a public inquiry. At the same time the share market will be freed from unnecessary restrictions, but adequate checks will remain to discourage trading in licences per se. I should like to make one further point. The Government has decided that the new provisions relating to approval of share transactions will apply only to transactions taking place after commencement of this legislation. Clause 50 gives effect to this decision. NA Under the existing Act, loan interests in a television station may result in a lender acquiring a prescribed interest in a licence. In some cases this will restrict opportunities to obtain tinance, except by bank overdraft, to which exemption already applies, when in practice the investor might only be able to influence a licence where a licensee defaults on a loan. New section 91 cclause 31 of the Bill-empowers the Tribunal to register approved lenders and so exclude them from the prescribed interest provisions of the Act provided the Tribunal is satisfied that a person will not be in a position to exercise, directly or directly, a significant influence on any company holding a licence. In circumstances where a registered lender used a loan interest to exercise undue control over a licensee the Tribunal could deregister the lender. The lender would then be subject to the prescribed interest provisions applying to loan interests. VARIA nON OF LIMITS ON NA New section 91D-c1ause 31 or the Bill-addresses the problem of breaches of section 92 of the Act by third parties acquiring excess prescribed interests as a result of share transactions by other persons. Experience has shown that an investor can be put in breach of the Act through the purchase of shares by another party in which the investor is a shareholder, because of the tracing provisions of the Act. Problems of third party breaches of the Act have arisen particularly with institutional investors because of their large and diversified portfolio shareholdings. New section 91D provides that any person holding an interest of from 5 per cent up to 10 per cent-on any test-in a television licence without its being considered as a prescribed interest, may apply to the Tribunal for a certificate permitting him to hold that interest. However, the benefits of the section will be extended only to persons acquiring an interest in a television licence operating in an area where there is at least one other commercial television station-that is, the five mainland State capitals-and then only if those persons can satisfy the Tribunal that the interest in question will not give rise to a person exercising, either directly or indirectly, a significant influence on the licensee company. Clause 31 of the Billincorporating both section 91 and section 91D--will commence on a date to be proclaimed. Some preliminary work by the Tribunal is necessary to enable introduction of these provisions. However, the Government will be looking to proclaim this provision as soon as practicable. NA NA The existing sections 90G and 92D of the Act restrict ownership of shares, but not voting rights, in licensee companies by any individual nonresident to 15 per cent, and by the aggregate of non-resident shareholders to 20 per cent, of issued share capital. The interpretation of the provision has presented difficulties because of the lack of definition of 'resident' and the meaning of 'control'-that is, whether it is commercial control, up to 50 per cent of votes, or control as defined in the Act; that is, 15 per cent of votes and in- shares. These sections have been redrafted to provide a redefinition of restrictions on foreign shareholdings to provide that only Australian citizens and companies in which Australian citizens hold more than 50 per cent of the votes and/or shares, may be 'in a position to control' a licensee company. Clause 53 is a transitional provision for non-resident shareholdings, enabling residents who are not Australian citizens to retain any interests they hold at commencement which comply with the existing provisions of the Act. NA NA NA The changes proposed by the Bill to the ownership or control provisions will produce a system which gives considerably more flexibility to licensees and persons acquiring interests in licences. The Government expects strict compliance with the new provisions. To this end existing sanctions and penalties have been strengthened substantially. Clause 40 provides for the Tribunal to give directions for the purpose of securing disposal of excess interests if it is satisfied that a person has breached the provisions of Division 2 or 3 of Part IV of the Act by the acquisition of shares, debenture or loan interests. Directions given under clause 40 will be enforceable in the Federal Court of Australia. Additionally, the Bill provides in clauses 40 and 46 that non-compliance with directions will attract substantially higher penalti- than those presently in force. NA NA NA Clauses 7 and 8 of the Bill amend merchandising and contractual provisions relating to the operations of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. These provisions will enable the ABC to make, promote, circulate or sell non-literary matter associated with its programs. Clause 8 allows the ABC to enter into contracts for the sale of its programs without ministerial approval. This delegation is essential for the quick negotiation of contracts. NA The Bill contains a number of other provisions which are either consequential to the changes outlined or are minor changes which update and standardise provisions to accord with current legislative practice. In 1965 when the ownership provisions were last amended special provision was made for persons holding interests in excess of the new limitations, such that these interests could be retained as long as they were not increased or restructured. The effect of this 'freezing' provision or the 'grandfather' clause as it was known, which today applies only to a few companies, has been to inhibit their ability to adjust their corporate structure to the present commercial environment. These companies will require time to restructure their interests. I take this opportunity to foreshadow a Government amendment which I will be proposing to move during the Committee stage of the debate on the Bill which will make appropriate transitional arrangements for these companies in relation to the new share transaction procedures. The proposed changes I have outlined to the ownership or control provisions will be the first major alterations for 16 years, yet there have been significant developments in the industry over that time. These changes, together with the introduction of supplementary licences for radio stations, will provide a sound basis for the continued development of broadcasting in the coming decade without undue constraint on commercial activity. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned. NA FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1981 Bill presented by Mr Sinclair, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill makes consequential amendments to the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act 1964 to extend that Act to supplementary licences for radio stations. References in the Act to commercial broadcasting stations, licences and licensees are applied to supplementary broadcasting stations, licences and licensees. Provisions have also been inserted to deal with licence fees payable by a consortium of commercial broadcasting licensees holding a supplementary licence. The Bill provides that the supplementary broadcasting station will be regarded as a separate operation for the purposes of licence fees assessments. The effect of these amendments is to place supplementary licensees on the same basis as commerciallicensees in respect of the imposition and calculation of licence fees. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned. NA AMENDMENT BILL 1981 Bill presented by Mr Sinclair, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: lmove: That the Bill be now read a second time. The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946 to allow the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) to form or participate in the formation of a company that may be established to own and manage the national communications satellite system. On 18 September 1980, the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications informed the House that tenders were to be called for the supply of a communications satellite'system, and that the Government was considering the possibility of establishing a company to own and manage that $ystem, the public sector to hold 51 per cent of the share capital in such a company and the private sector to hold 49 per cent of the shares. A committee of officials was requested to report on the interest of the private sector in participating in such a company in which OTC would have a major interest on behalf of the Government, the company to operate' as a commercial tax-paying ertterprise. As an interim measure, OTC had been designated as the authority to own and manage the communications satellite system. For this purpose, licences under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 had been issued to OTC to provide telecommunications services by way of a satellite system. The request for tenders for the satellite communications system was issued in October last year. The request for tenders is a comprehensive set of documents inviting tenders for the supply of the space segment of the satellite system, the major city earth stations and minor earth stations to access the satellite, and earth stations required by Telecom Australia for telephony services as well as to receive only earth stations for regional and remote area national broadcasting services. Also included in the request for tender was the supply of earth terminals for the Department of Transport's air safety and navigational services. Twenty tenders were received for the space and earth segments of the satellite communications system and evaluation of tenders is now taking place. In introducing this Bill I make it clear that the Government has not taken decisions on what the final ownership arrangements will be. The report of officials on their discussions with the private sector on participating in a company to own and manage the satellite communications system is now being considered by the Government and I hope to be able to announce the outcome of these considerations in the neal' future. Honourable members will appreciate that if the Government decides to proceed with the concept of establishing a company with public and private sector involvement, there will be a need for further discussion and negotiation on the detailed arrangements which might apply before the company, as a legal entity, is established. The visions of the Bill in this regard should therefore be seen as a contingency measure only. Whether there will be a need for recourse to the provisions of the Bill will depend on Government decisions regarding the organisation or authority which will be the ultimate owner of the satellite communications system and the timing for implementing those decisions. For this reason the Bill provides that action by OTe to form or participate in such a company requires the approval of the Minister. Other objectives of the Bill are to enable OTe to provide technical services, on a commercial basis, to such a company, and to enable OTC to provide consultative services to the governments of neighbouring countries on the use of the satellite system for their own purposes. Again the Minister's approval is required before OTe can take action along those lines. The provision for OTC to provide consultative services of this nature to neighbouring countries reflects the Government's policy of assisting less developed nations in the region to develop their own telecommunications services. Provision has been made in the design of the system for the satellite to provide telecommunications services for the Government of Papua New Guinea. This is an optional feature in the system design, and the Papua New Guinea Government has yet to make decisions regarding its use of the Australian satellite system for its own needs. For technical reasons, it has not been possible to provide in the first generation satellite system for services to be available to other countries in the South West Pacific region. The Government has offered, however, to participate in a study of the telecommunications needs of those countries, and a formal invitation has now been received for Australia to take part in such a study. The results of that study will be taken into account when planning later generations of communications satellites. The Overseas Telecommunications Commission has had considerable experience in the provision of telecommunications services by satellites. It now provides tracking, telemetry, command and monitoring facilities for the Intelsat satellites in orbital locations over the Pacific and Indian Oceans. It will provide similar services for satellites to be launched by the European Space Agency. The OTe also provides the major facilities at Moree, Ceduna and Carnarvon for receiving and transmitting by satellite of international communications. Since the taking of the decision to invest OTC with the interim responsibility for pro- developing the satellite communications system, that authority has built up its technical resources on satellite communications. The skills and experiences of OTC officers in satellite communications systems will be of major benefit in pursuing the Government '8 policy of extending modern telecommunications services to all people in Australia. In seeking the support of honourable members to this Bill 1 would emphasise that the development of the na tiona I communications satellite system is a major project. The evaluation of tenders will be one of the most critical aspects. It has to be undertaken within a time frame which would allow contracts for the supply of the system to be entered into in early 1982, so that the space and earth segments of the system are available to coincide with reservations which have been made with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, or NASA, and the European Space Agency to place the satellites in their Ofbital positions. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by MI' Scholes) adjourned. BOUNTY (PRINTED FABRICS) BILL Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to pay a bounty on the printing in Australia of certain lightweight woven fabrics weighing less than 120 grams per square metre. The decision to adopt this form of assistance follows the Government's consideration of the recommendation by the Industries Assistance Commission contained in its report No. 240 of 30 April 1980 entitled 'Textiles, Clothing and Footwear'. This bounty proposal is part of the Government's broader program for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, intended to encourage the development of a more efficient industry structure. It is expected also to provide substantial benefits to user industries such as clothing manufacturers. To this end, the proposal is in agreement with the broad objectives of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendation. The Bill provides for the bounty to be payable at the rate of 70 per cent of the additional value added to the fabric by the printer. The value added will be based on the factory cost of tl>e bountiable printed fabric less the costs of materials used in the printing process. The scheme is to operate for a period of seven years from I January 1982 and bounty payments for the tlrst full year are estimated to be $2.5rn. The bounty assistance is designed to offset the effect on printers of another Government decision to grant import entry of certain fabrics at mini .. mum rates of duty and free of quota that is, those printed fabrics weighing less than 120 grams per square metre, and destined for garment use. Bounty is payable on fabric printed at registered premises during the bounty period, if the fabric is used or is sold for use in making up into garments in a registered clothing factory. Clothing factories will be treated as being registered for the purposes of the bounty scheme if registered under a State law or, in the case of internal Territories which do not have laws suitable for these purposes, such places used for the production of garments and approved by the Comptroller·General of Customs. This approach is consistent with exclusions from the proposed tariff concessions of certain lightweight woven fabrics which I mentioned earlier. The exclusions will protect the interests of 1981 manufacturers of other lightweight cloth, such as pocketings, linings and curtains. At the same time, the Bill makes provision for an extension by regulation of the uses to which bountiable fabric may Second Reading be put, if the Government decides that such an extension is desirable. The Government expects that the assistance proposed by this Bill will enable the local industry to compete adequately against printed fabrics of a similar nature which will be able to be imported at minimum rates of duty and free of quota after 1 January 1982. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Scholes) adjourned. BOUNTY (TEXTILE YARNS) BILL 1981 Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to provide bounty assistance to the production in Australia of certain yarns. The decision to adopt this form of assistance follows the Government's consideration of the recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission contained in its report No. 240 of 30 April 1980 entitled 'Textiles, Clothing and Footwear'. This bounty proposal is part of the Government's broader program designed to encourage the development of a more efficient industry structure for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. It will also provide substantial benefits for industries using bountiable yarns in manufacturing textiles or textile products. User industries will benefit from reduced costs of material inputs and greater flexibility of sourcing. To this end the proposal is in agreement with the broad objectives of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendation. The Bill provides for the bounty to be payable to producers of most yarns at rates calculated as specified percentages of the value added to the yarns, on a factory cost basis, in their production. The yarns eligible for the bounty are specified in clause 2 of the Bill and the rates of bounty proposed for each type of yarn are specified in clause 6 of the Bill. The Government in August last year established the bounty rate for several yarn types, including yarns, spun on the cotton system, at 33 per cent. Following extensive discussions with industry sectors, and based on an assessment of up to date information, it has become apparent that assistance for cotton system spun yarns at this level would be likely to result in a degree of disruption that could not have been foreseen at the time the Government took its original decision, particularly in some regional locations. For this reason the Government has decided to set the bounty rate for these products at 43 per cent. From 1 January 1982 imported yarns similar to the bountiable yarns will be quota free and subject only to minimum rates of duty. Wool carpet yarns and yarns for handcrafting and sewing thread will not be eligible for the bounty. Sewing threads and hand craft yarns are to be assisted by import duties from 1 January 1982. The processes and expenditures eligible for bounty are specified in clauses 2 and 3 of the Bill. In general, the 'additional value' provision excludes materials such as fibres and polymers, dyes, yam additives, and some packaging materials. It also excludes other costs such as general administration, selling and distribution. The bounty scheme is to operate for a period of seven years from 1 January 1982, and it is estimated that bounty payments during that period will be $47m for 1981-82 and $71m per annum thereafter. Bounty eligibility will be restricted to yarns produced in premises registered under this Act and used in registered textile factories. Textile factories will be treated as registered for the purposes of the bounty scheme if used for the commercial manufacture of textile products and if registered as a factory under a State or internal Territory law. In the case of internal Territories which do not have laws suitable for these purposes, buildings used for the commercial manufacture of textile products and approved by the Comptroller-General of Customs will be recognised as registered factories. The Government expects that the assistance proposed by this Bill will encourage further improvements in the efficiency of this industry, reductions in cost, and responsiveness to changing consumer needs. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Morris) adjourned. AIRLINES AGREEMENT BILL 1981 Second Reading Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by MrHunt: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill and the Airlines Equipment Amendment Bill as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: The three Bills in this legislative package contain some advances on existing arrangements for the provision of airline services. I will, at appropriate stages in the debate, move amendments designed to shorten the life of the two-airline agreement that is proposed, to provide greater participation by the public and consumer interests in air fare fixing procedures and for oversighting of the profits of the two parties to the agreement, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines. The major purpose of the package of Bills is to ensure the profitability of Ansett Airlines for at least the next eight years. Some provisions of the legislation have been included to appease dissidents in government ranks concerning what they rightly saw as undesirable aspects of the preference and protection afforded to Ansett Airlines under the terms of the now discarded 1980 airline agreement. The position, therefore, is that any benefits to the public that have arisen from this legislation are incidental to those two main purposes. Airline services are one of the few profitable areas of our public transport system. The objective of the Australian Labor Party Opposition is to ensure that the people of Australia have maximum access to safe, convenient airline services at a minimum cost to the users. There can be no justification, in the provision of airline services under the airline agreement, for the operators of those services, Ansett Airlines and Trans-Australia Airlines, to earn profits commensurate with trading operations in the general commercial environment. That was a point made very strongly by the recent Holcroft Committee of Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares in its recent report. The fact is that the public transport system of which the airline service is a major part is there to provide a service to the community. It is not there to earn rewards for risk-takers. In fact, under the provisions of the airline agreement there is little risk involved because the system is a cost-plus system. Only the profits have not been spelled out in specific terms. .Before discussing provisions of the Airlines Agreement Bill let me quickly recall the origins of the two-airline policy. Honourable members will remember that it was introduced in the early 1950s to prop up the failing private enterprise operator, Australian National Airways. It was amended subsequently in 1957 to meet the desires of its successor, Ansett Airlines. The policy has entrenched a rigid regulatory control of domestic airline services and has been supported by successive conservative governments. The great contradiction in the behaviour of honourable members sitting opposite is that despite their constant claims as to the efficiency and efficacy of free enterprise and how it can be done better by the private sector, the two-airline policy, by its very nature, is the antithesis of free enterprise. It provides to two private multi-millionaire operators guaranteed protected access to half the capacity of major airline services in this country. On the basis on which they are protected from any competition, there can be no danger of a competitor pushing them out from their share of the traffic or of endangering their commercial position. As I mentioned, they are protected by a cost-plus pricing system. The present proprietors of Ansett Airlines seized control of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd in a gigantic stock exchange coup in late 1979. They paid heavily inflated prices for AT!. The new proprietors then had to set about finding ways of increasing the financial yield for Ansett Airlines. They did not have great difficulty because they had a compliant government. They had a captive government then and they have a captive government now. It stands ready to do their bidding. Today we saw the introduction of the Murdoch amendments in respect of the Broadcasting and Television Act. The two-airline agreement was to be re-negotiated and changed to assist further the multi-millionaire proprietors of Ansett Airlines. The new agreement makes no reference to a limitation on profits despite the exclusive right of the parties to provide major domestic airline services. It is designed to help achieve that higher financial yield now required by Ansett Transport Industries to fund the inflated prices and to help pay for the tax free profit that Mr Robert Holmes a' Court gained from the sale of his shares to the present proprietors. As I have pointed out, because the fare structure is based on a cost-plus system and the agreement requires the operation of only two operators over the entire trunk route network, Ansett cannot fail. There is no risk or danger from competitive forces over the entire trunk route network. Again, that is a point which was made by Mr Holcroft. In effect, the two airline policy is a licence to print money. That is the point that has been made by editorial writers around this country on a number of occasions. The editorial writer of the Australian Financial Review of7 December 1979, at the time when the coup was in progress, was correct when he wrote: The major asset of A TI is the entrenched rights and privileges it possesses under the two-airline policy. Television licences are public property which may not be freely bought and sold. So is the position of ATI within the two-airline policy. Government policy does not have to remain unchanged on either. It certainly has not. The present multi-millionaire proprietors of ATI bought into that company and organised that stock exchange coup on their own initiative. Let their risks be on their own heads, but let not their risks be an imposition upon the air travellers of this country under the masquerade that they are providing a public transport service, a better service and that they would not have entered into contracts to purchase new aircraft if they did not have knowledge of the new agreement which was negotiated and which was not made available to this Parliament. The travelling public has no obligation to ensure an inflated rate of return on the investment the proprietors of Ansett have made in their airline. The incredible subservience of this government to the Ansett proprietors is shown by the surrender of its sovereign power to determine aviation policy. It is an incredible performance. I could not find anything in parliamentary history which showed a sovereign government handing over its power finally to determine policy in the appropriate area to a private organisation which, in this case, is two multi-millionaires. The granting in clause 2 of the agreement of a 90-day power of veto to Ansett and TAA is without precedent in parliamentary history, but it also indicates the level of distrust. This is very important because this legislation has come before the Parliament after several months of dissention, disarray, backroom brawling and attempts to overthrow the leadership within Government. Out of all that disarray has come this second version of a two-airline agreement within 12 months. The distrust that is indicated in clause 2 of the new agreement goes to the distrust between the Australian National Airlines Commission, Ansett Airlines and this Government. In effect, Ansett has said to the Government: 'We do not trust you to legislate in the manner you have indicated in the agreement. We do not trust you to legislate along the lines you have indicated in respect of the Independent Air Fares Committee. We do not believe you can trust your own back benchers'. That is the climate in which this legislation has been brought before the Parliament. Mr Hyde-We are getting on very well.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: I have noticed, but they are mopping up the blood outside at the moment. The removal of freight from the agreement is supported by the Opposition. The introduction of wide-bodied aircraft and specialised cargo aircraft should result in a higher level of efficiency in the industry together with improved services to air freight users. Accordingly, we do not oppose the Airlines Equipment Amendment Bill. However, the continued restrictive definition of trunk routes will continue to give Ansett and TAA exclusive right to those routes, thus severely limiting opportunities for the development of regional operators such as East-West Airlines Ltd and any other future developments as population patterns and market patterns change. East-West has rightly expressed its concern at the dangers it sees arising from the limitations being placed on operators in the new agreement. Clause 6 of the new agreement in the Schedule attacht'd to the Bill spells out in clear terms the unfettered right of Ansett and TAA to be 'the only two operators which provide scheduled domestic passenger air services over trunk routes within Australia'. Clause 6 (1) (e) nominates 18 trunk route centres in which an air link between any two of such nominated centres comes into the category of trunk route. There are in excess of 150 such combinations, of which 20 per cent are intrastate centres requiring a State government licence. The questions that must be asked are: How many of these trunk route centres are commercially viable now or in the foreseeable future? Why were they included in the agreement? Which party instigated their inclusion? Once a centre has been nominated as a trunk route centre now, or in the future, there is no machinery whereby the airlines can drop the status back to that of a prescribed route. This agreement effectively closes up all route centres in Australia where there is even the remotest possibility of an economic air service. Over 50 per cent of the proposed trunk route combinations are not practicable or commercially feasible to the airlines. However, they are effectively closed to any other air passenger operator unless such operator develops specialised sched.uled passenger air services over such routes for which the Commission and the company are not providing an adequate service to the satisfaction of the Minister or unless either of the two major operators should withdraw from the service. Clause 7 deals with consultations mainly between the Commission and the company. Clause 7 (2) (a) relates to the efficient and. economic operation of passenger air services. It does not set out objectives or standards by which one may analyse the efficient or economic operation of the airlines. One cannot but form an opinion other than that the Government is totally incapable of evaluating an efficient or economic air service. The report of the Holcroft inquiry supports this contention and sets out various formats by which these objectives and/or standards may be judged. Clause 12 deals with the replacement of rural services. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) has now publicly acknowledged that TAA and Ansett will have the right to opt out of rural airline services under the provisions of the new agreement given that, after a specific procedure, they can prove that total costs exceed total revenue. The Minister and his National Country Party colleagues representing country electorates have again thrown their constituents to the wolves. The Fraser Government has given to its friends the profitable air routes, and the marginal and loss routes will be reduced to a lesser standard of service. There is a need for the operator opting out of a rural service to make arrangements-Mr Hyde-Are you calling for crosssubsidisation?

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: No. I will go on to explain. There is a need for the operator opting out of a rural service to make arrangements with other interested operators to provide an adequate air service. Ansett and TAA should, under the provisions of this agreement, be compelled to operate rural services until continuity of such services is guaranteed. Clause 13 of the agreement requires provision of financial information generally in compliance with the Victorian Companies Act. I ask honourable members on the other side of the House who have corporate experience to enlighten the Minister on what the provisions of the Victorian Companies Act can provide in an analysis of financial matters relating to the airlines. Ansett has for some time complied in its annual' report with the provisions of the Victorian Companies Act. Under the agreement the Minister is to be presented with accounting information specifically, with airline operations in total, not specific, terms. Why could the Schedule not provide for accounting information from Ansett and TAA set out in a standardised format so that a meaningful analysis and comparison between the two operators could be made? There is a great need for financial information on each individual aviation section of Ansett. The Airline Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Act requires this information to be furnished each year by Ansett. All the Minister has to do is extend this information to be available to be tabled in Parliament. If TAA has to furnish similar financial information in a standardised format then members of this Parliament and members of the public will be aware of what is going on in this highly protected industry. In the 24 years since the 1957 airline agreement Ansett has not had to produce a detailed set of accounts for examination by anybody. The Demum partment of Transport may have had access to those accounts. I do not believe that in recent years the Department has exercised its prerogachanging tive to require that information. If it did the infortourist mation was not provided to the Parliament. In the recent Holcroft committee inquiry the proprietors of Ansett were not only able to dictate the inquiry how it should conduct its affairs also were able to elude providing necessary detailed financial information on the airline's activities. That information is absolutely necessdent ary. If other operators in the industry are required to produce information so should Ansett. But it necessary so that the parliament and the people can assess the efficiency and the financial results of the airlines on a comparative basis as part the offset for the heavy level of protection that provided to Ansett and TAA. Clause 15 of the agreement deals with the role of Qantas Airways Ltd, TAA and Ansett. In the 1980 agreement this clause, despite recent Press coverage, still retains for Ansett a power of over direct Qantas participation in the provision of domestic air services. I have noted in recent weeks stories which gave the impression that the clause had been modified. It has been modified to require the Government to consult with the board of Qantas. But the modification has not altered the fact that Ansett, as one of the parties to agreement, has a power of veto over whether Qantas should directly participate in the provision of domestic air services across Australia. Again the consumer is discriminated against for the benefit of domestic operators. The contrast to be made is that recently, when there was a strike within the domestic aviation industry and the Government wanted to do something about it, it was quickly able to overcome the facilitation problems the Minister for Transport is so fond of quoting as the reason the capacity of Qantas across Australia cannot be used. In that strike situation, where it suited the Government's own political purposes, it moved in quickly to utilise Qantas capacity. Clause 15 (2) sets out that any change in Government policy in the future in the respective roles of TAA, Ansett and Qantas will need only the approval of the parties to the agreement. That confirms what I have just mentioned in respect of Ansett having the final veto. The consultation process for Qantas is a little bit of window dressing. Another undesirable feature of the agreement is its term of five years, plus three years notice of termination, which is in effect an eight-year miniperiod. Its result will be to deny to Australians the benefits of new generation aircraft, adjustments that may be required flowing from market patterns, population shifts and development. I will deal with these aspects in more detail in the Committee stage of the Bill. Because of time limitations I turn briefly now to to the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill. This but legislation is a partial acceptance of the Australian Labor Party's policy canvassed at the last two elections for the establishment of an indepenair fare tribunal, to which I referred on those occasions as the Prices Justification Tribunal or a is similar body. Such a tribunal would be given the power to assess and determine air fares. Despite the deficiencies of this Bill, it is a step in the right of direction. Those deficiencies can be remedied in is the Committee stage with the support of some honourable members opposite. One major deficiency in this Bill and the Airlines Agreement Bill is the absence of a finite and precise financial objective for the airlines which would be available for consideration by the Independent Air Fares veto Committee. The Preamble to the agreement to which I referred earlier refers, in association with paragraph (a), to the need to ensure 'the efficient and economic operation of air passenger services within Australia'. As I said earlier, they are vague words, public service jargon, with the meaning being in the mind of the utterer. Clause 11 of the the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill lists the items to which the Committee shall have regard in conducting major air fare reviews. Clause 15 (11) (d) contains almost the same words as clause A of the preamble to which I have referred; the same vagueness and the same generality. However, clause 15 (11) (g), which relates to operating on a competitive basis, is almost in conflict with clause 15 (11) (d) because the two objects cannot be compatible. On the one hand, the legislation involves operating on a competitive basis and, on the other, it involves ensuring economic and efficient operation. Clause 15 (11) (d) of the legislation would be improved if the financial objectives were specific. From my assessment and interpretation clauses 3 and 5 of the air fares committee legislation create serious problems for East-West Airlines Ltd, the major regional operator, in that that company's fare over a trunk route sector must be treated by the Committee as a discount fare. The fact that its fares will be treated in that manner imposes upon the company an obligation to supply information to which it would not have access, and an obligation to make forecasts or produce evidence that certain events may not happen. Again, that is information to which the company would not have access and which it would not be able to provide. We will examine that matter in more detail when we come to the Committee stage of the Bill. Whilst the legislation picks up a number of the Holcroft committee's recommendations, it is regrettable that it has not adopted those in respect of profit limitation, full public disclosure and, very importantly, reconciliation of airline accounts with the overall activities of the organistions concerned. Some Government members like to criticise the non-airline activities of Trans-Australia Airlines from time to time without following the argument right through or without providing full information. After all, they are members of the Government and it is their responsibility to ensure that full information is provided. It is not the responsibility of the public; they are the Government. In the case of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd, I have often had the complaint from surface transport operators that there are ways and means that can be followed by Ansett Airlines of Australia and ATI in the preparation of accounts, in inter-company transfers and inter-company baJances in the establishment or conduct of operations, airline and non-airline, which conceal the true movements of funds between those companies and which place the airline company always in the position in which, when it is purchasing new aircraft, it needs the benefit of Government guarantees to obtain loans abroad. Mr Holcroft, a major figure in the private sector of the transport industry; Professor Hogan, an economist; and Dr Bell, who is an economist in the investment field, were skilled and able to assess and determine the importance of proper reconciliation. Unfortunately, a provision to deal with such a practice is not contained in the Bill. Similarly, the Bill does not provide for public dissemination of comparative information on the efficiency of the financial and technical results of both airlines. I am restricting my time because of a request from the other side. I have outlined the Opposition's general approach to the three Bills before the House. In view of those time restrictions I will reserve my further remarks for the Committee stage of the Bills.

Speaker: Mr SHACK
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: The three Bills the House is debating cognately this afternoon-the Airlines Agreement Bill, the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill and the Airlines Equipment Amendment Bill-together with the Australian National Airlines Repeal Bill which will be debated in this chamber later today, are the result of over two years of extensive consideration of domestic aviation policy by the Government, by private members of parliament, by the airlines themselves and, importantly, also by the pUblic. Some of the decisions that have been announced by the Government to date, and to which I will refer shortly, ensure that this consideration will be an ongoing process; a process to evaluate the appropriateness of the two-airline policy, which is to be perpetuated by the Airlines Agreement Bill, and perhaps to examine some other options such as a greater or lesser degree of deregulation in the future. As the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) mentioned, there is a limitation of time for this debate. I know that several of my colleagues would like to speak in the Committee stage. I propose to keep my most detailed comments for that time. I now want to speak broadly, but briefly, on what I think has been achieved over the last couple of years. Over the last two to two and a half years consideration can be perceived as beginning with the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee Report, which came out in 1978. That was an important report because it came out in June 1978, when the Airlines Agreement Act of 1973 terminated. After December 1977 the opportunity existed to provide for termination of previous airlines agreements with five years notice. I believe it was an important report. It came to numerous conclusions designed to improve the regulatory environment. It was on the basis of this report that the Government proceeded to negotiate with the airlines to come up with the airlines agreement which was signed towards the latter part of last year. That agreement was designed to incorporate the improvements and changes that were recommended in the report. Although it was a valuable report, it had two weaknesses. Firstly, it proceeded from the basis of the maintenance of the two-airline policy. The two-airline policy was not brought into question. Secondly-I do not think this is unfair criticismthe review was conducted largely by the Department of Transport. I think it can be shown from the report that the interests of the regulated and the regulators became enmeshed. It was not an independent study in that sense. Because of that there grew in the community, and certainly inside the Parliament, a level of disquiet which recognised that this was a valuable opportunity to reassess domestic aviation and to reassess our needs for the future. It was felt that perhaps the reassessment in this report was not as full as needed. Wisely, the Government recognised that disquiet and moved to set up the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. I want to place on public record my opinion as to the valuable contribution to the study and understanding of domestic aviation made by the Holcroft report. I want to pay tribute to Warwick Holcroft, Harold Bell and Warren Hogan for the work they did in the course of the committee's investigations. The focus of the committee was on fares but, without repeating old arguments that I have voiced in this place, the terms of reference of the committee gave it wider scope. The committee was able to bring into focus and into question the two-airline policy itself. The Government has had the Holcroft report since the early part of this year and now we have this legislative package reflecting some of the findings in that report. As I stated at the outset of my remarks, I would like to catalogue what I believe has been achieved. I refer firstly to fares. It will be remembered that the Holcroft committee, among other things, identified gross cross-subsidisation between routes, deficiencies of the present air fare setting formula and procedure and, in the committee's opinion, a lack of desirable accountability which is necessary in the regulated environment due to the absence of the disciplines of market forces. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), in his 1 April statement to the Parliament, gave an initial response to the Holcroft report. One of the most important elements of that response was that the Government accepted the need for a national cost-based formula with the elimination of crosssubsidisation as far as is practicable. To date we have seen a first step readjustment of the fare relaits tivities between the long haul and short haul routes in an effort to eliminate cross-subsidisation. The Government rightly recognised that Holcroft did not go far enough in terms of his figure work and that more cost allocation work was required. The Minister announced in that statement that the Government would be enlisting independent assistance to help in that work. As I understand it, a tender has been let to some accountants. I would be grateful for the Minister's explanation, in his responses during debate on these Bills, of how that further work is going. I hope that that cost allocation procedure can be concluded so that when we next face a new fare rise, and if that new fare rise comes before the Independent Air Fares Committee is in place, it will be based on the Holcroft formula. I mention the Independent Air Fares Committee because it is the second major initiative of the Government in response to the Holcroft report. There is an intention to establish the Committee, which will be given the sole responsibility of periodically reviewing the cost allocation methodology. It will be independent and separate from the Department of Transport, and it will have the further responsibility of adjudicating on future fare rises, be they minor or major. An important point I make about the Committee at this stage is that its personnel will be important, absolutely crucial. They must be men who can be seen and shown in the public arena as possessing the absolutely highest integrity because in a regulated environment they will have the sole responsibility on behalf of the public of adjudicating on what the fares should be and of explaining to the public why they have arrived at such findings. I hope to make an input to the Government as to who should be on that Committee. I merely stress that the Committee's personnel will be absolutely vital to its success in the public eye. The second most important thing about the Committee is that its findings will be public. Not only will it announce a fare rise but it will also publicise its reasons for that determination. This initiative is an attempt by the Government to pick up that element of accountability that the Holcroft committee identified to be lacking in the regulated environment, and I think that is especially important. I have my own personal view that if that is done, and done properly, more and more Australians will come to appreciate the ludicrous nature of a regulated air fare setting environment. However, for the moment, and for the purposes of this debate, that is by the by. The third major initiative of the Government is decision on Trans-Australia Airlines. I do not want to run the risk of referring to a debate that will take place in this chamber later today. I simply say that the 1 April statement by the Minister contained an in-principle announcement of the establishment of TAA as a public company, to free it from the same sorts of bureaucratic controls that Qantas has complained about. It is an initiative that has been welcomed by TAA. It will make TAA more competitive, and I believe the regulated environment will be all the better for that decision. I am mindful of the Government's own interdepartmental committee study into the future of TAA. The report of that committee, which was given to the Government on 14 March 1980, stated: However, the committee concluded it was not possible to make Trans-Australia Airlines fully commercial while the Government was a majority shareholder. What we are doing now, in my view, is taking the first most important step. We have to take the next most important step before we arrive at a final decision as to the future of TAA, that is, to investigate the structure of TAA. To look at TANs superannuation liabilities and other liabilities, its asset value and so forth. We can then arrive at an answer to the question which at present we cannot answer, that is: What is TAA worth? We have heard a lot of hysteria from the Australian Labor Party on this matter, which is central to its socialist ideology. I believe that if the Australian Labor Party shook off its blinkers and looked at the matter it also would come to the conclusion 1 presently hold that a more competitive TAA will be achieved if there is direct public shareholding. 1 believe that the regulated environment would be all the better for that. The fourth initiative that has been announced by the Government is the intention to establish a deregulation inquiry, and again I refer to what Holcroft said. In simple terms, he said: '1 determine faults in the regulated environment and I list by way of recommendations ways in which I think you can improve it. But even if you do everything I say you should do to improve the regulated environment, you will end up only with second best.' In my view, the Holcroft committee's most important conclusion was that we should be proceeding down the road towards progressive deregulation. The Minister in his 2 April statement to this Parliament, when dealing with the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantees) Bill, announced the intention to set up the inquiry. Again I say that the two most important aspects yet to be determined are the terms of reference for that inquiry and the personnel who will conduct it. I can see no reason why those matters should not be decided later this year when Parliament returns for the Budget session. As the Minister announced, the inquiry will be asked to report within five years. If the inquiry is set up properly, with dinkum terms of reference and with people who have open minds on the question of future aviation policy for this country, 1 can see no reason why it cannot bring down progressive reports. The Government will have before it the benefits of that inquiry within five years. For the first time since the two-airline policy was brought into play, we will be in a position to consider where we should be going-not from the basis of maintaining the status quo but by comparing the status quo with perhaps some other options. Fifthly, ] come to the proposed two-airline agreement itself. The agreement takes into account the Government's decisions on the independent air fares committee and on TAA. Before dealing with that in a little greater detail, I would like to summarise the stage we have reached. In my mind, there has been definite progress. There have been air fare reductions on long haul routes and we have seen a foreshadowing of further changes in the relativities between fares for long and short routes. It is intended to establish an independent committee separate from the Department of Transport to determine future fares, to monitor the cost methodology, and to provide that public accountability that is so necessary in a regulated environment. A new two airline agreement has been negotiated to take into account the decisions of the committee and the decisions on TAA. It is intended to establish an inquiry to investigate whether deregulation is a viable objective for our future domestic aviation needs. These are all significant undertakings and statements of intent which, in my view, mark important and welcome shifts in Government policy. Honourable members will recall that only a little while ago that policy did not really accept that the fare relativities between long and short haul routes were inequitable or unjust. Only a little while ago that policy was firmly committeed to the reins of regulatory control being held exclusively by the Department of Transport, which was committed to the continuance of TAA as a statutory corporation. It was based on a seemingly unshakable commitment to the long term maintenance of the two-airline system. [ believe that we have progressed, that we are taking steps in the right direction, and that further progress can be expected as we move down the path that has now been chosen. In my last five minutes I want to turn to the two-airline agreement. I oppose the two-airline policy. I have opposed it in the Parliament for as long as I have been here, and my opposition is well known outside the Parliament. I accept that the proposed agreement contains improvements over previous agreements-improvements with respect to freight, the air fares committee, and public accountability. But for every improvement we can find complaints and criticisms, such as the legitimate concerns of East-West Airlines Ltd, the concern that Qantas Airways Ltd will not be able to play its proper role, and so on. I remain opposed to the two-airline policy as such because I believe it denies entrepreneurs freedom to enter the market, it denies the Australian travelling public significant carri-r choice, and it offers the public little realistic price value choice in terms of fares. I accept that the policy does have some benefits, such as flight frequency and a very high standard of in-flight service, but I do not think that they outweigh the disadvantages, and they are certainly benefits that are provided at an inflated cost. In the past I have called the two-airline agreement a piece of economic madness which is costing Australia dearly. I believe the present system is based on an inflated cost due to operational inefficiency. It is my view that a deregulated system would open up the system to competitive market forces and would see all features-price, frequency and service-based on and responsive to consumer demand. I have to accept the possibility that I may be completely wrong. My prejudice against the two-airline policy and in favour of progressive deregulation may be completely wrong. In that light, I congratulate the Government for opting for the only responsible course available to it, that is, to investigate the situation. The deregulation inquiry is a first-class initiative. welcome it with all the support I can muster. For the first time in 20-odd years we will look at other possibilities and make a decision as to whether they can be applied to Australia. We will look at the American experience, not only from the perspective of the airlines but also from the perspective of those people we too readily forget-the passengers. The deregulation inquiry will report within five years. Given that fact, what bothers me most about this legislative package is the life of the new agreement. I believe we should put ourselves in a position whereby we will make a decision on the deregulation inquiry at the end of five years. The airlines agreement as it is presently drafted and the Bill which gives effect to that agreement places no requirement on anybody to do anything after five years. We cannot do anything before five years, but after five years we do not have to do anything either. If honourable members doubt that I ask them to look closely at the terms of clause 22(4) of the agreement. Over the last few days we have heard a lot about whether five plus three makes eight, whether three from eight equals five and so forth. I want to try to reduce the whole issue to this fundamental point. As clause 22(4) is presently drafted, it provides for a five year minimum plus an indefinite period during which we mayor may not give notice of something. It then has a three-year period of termination. Effectively we have a minimum of eight years but a maximum that is indeterminate. I have advocated strongly in the past that we should have a five-year maxamum. I will save my comments on that matter for the Committee debate because I am running out of time. I foreshadow that I will argue that we should opt for a five plus three situation but that we should make the minimum of eight years as provided for in the agreement a maximum of eight years. Amendments to be moved in my name have been circulated. I will leave my further remarks for the Committee stage of the Bill.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: OVERSEAS TELECOMMUNICATIONS
text: 1 will support in the Committee stage the Opposition's amendments. I will now range over the Airlines Agreement Bill, the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill and the Airlines Equipment Amendment Bill, though not as broadly as the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) ranged in the course of his remarks. He was extremely provocative, introducing at this stage of the debate the question of the future of Trans-Australia Airlines. That matter is not before us at the moment. He protrayed a picture of sweetness and light in the progress to the point at which we are now, which I I do not think the history of this issue justifies. This debate today concludes a sorry tale, not only for the Government, although mainly for it, but also for the Government's revolting back bench. The Government's performance for over a year now has been one of vacillation and deceit-a misleading not only of the Parliament but also of the Australian people in a general election. These points were made quite clearly during the various debates on this matter to this point. Most particularly misled have been the citizens of Western Australia. They have also been ill-used by a selection of Liberal back backbenchers from that State. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey), the honourable member for Tangney, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and the honourable member for Perth (Mr MCLean) have never been able to work out whether their main task has been to lower air fares for Western Australians or to conduct an ideological tribal dance on the question of the abolition of the Government's airline, of interest only to the wretched coterie of neanderthals in the local Liberal Party organisation. They will be put to the test on these Bills. Several honourable members opposite are on record as supporting a five-year maximum period on a non-negotiable basis for the operation of this legislation. We shall be moving an amendment in the Committee stage that will give them the opportunity to display exactly how far they will go and how nonnegotiable that position has been. The Labor Party's amendments are designed to resurrect something for the Australian and Western Australian people from this morass. To do this we must resist the Government's attempts to make the two-airline agreement election proof and the operations of the Independent Air Fares Committee public proof. This Government does not trust people because, left to themselves, the people do not trust it. Therefore, a popular view, in the view of this Government, must be resisted at all costs. Despite the fact that there are some improvements as the Opposition shadow spokesman said, referring to the Air Fares Committee, I suggest that these are way short of the requirements of the Holcroft inquiry into domestic air fares. They are short at least of what some honourable members opposite have said on the public record to this point. It will be extremely interesting to see how they come across on the amendments we will be moving. Our intentions through the amendments we will move will be two-fold. The first will be to stop the victimisation of the Australian travelling public by preventing their having to carry the burdens of excess and uncontrolled profits. Secondly, our amendments will render the airlines' economies publicly accountable. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) wrapped himself, as far as he possibly could, in the Holcroft inquiry flag in his second reading speech on this Bill. However, throughout that speech and throughout the negotiation of this agreement he frustrated at every point the purpose of that inquiry and the recommendations it made. Fundamental to the inquiry and ignored by this agreement and the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill was a limitation on excess profit. In chapter 16 of the Holcroft report the question of profit was assessed at great length. Many constructive suggestions were put forward. The Holcroft inquiry stated: The attention given to profitability in relation to of air fares requires a careful appraisal of the ways in which an equitable return in a regulated activity should be assessed. This is all the more important when so little attention has been given in Australia to what this means in practice. Neither in the agreement nor in the terms of reference for the Air Fares Committee' is this made fundamental to the process. The Holcroft inquiry concluded with four recommendations on profit levels. One of them was quite clear on amounts. It stated: Profit before interest and tax, excluding extraordinary items, should as a proportion of revenue not exceed 6 per cent, given a continuation of present levels of interest rates and income taxation in Australia. We can interpret many things in the Holcroft inquiry in many ways, but one thing we cannot do is interpret that recommendation out of existence. It is quite clear. It is also quite clear from the Minister's second reading speech and many of the contributions from honourable members opposite so far that this limitation simply will not be imposed. It should be imposed. We have every right to expect that it should have appeared in the Minister's statement and in the legislation. An indication of that was given by the Minister when he spoke on this matter on 1 April. He said: In addition, the report's recommendations advocating the adoption of a profit target must be more fully examined. More fully examined by whom, if it is not to be directly more fully examined by the air fares inquiry to this point? Not only is there no limit on profits but also there is no requirement to make public airline accounts so that people may judge the extent to which they are being justly or unjustly treated. This is evident from clause 13 of the Schedule to the Airlines Agreement Bill which has already been mentioned by the Opposition spokesman on this matter. I think it is worthwhile to refresh our memories. The Bill is before honourable members so I will not read the clause to them. They should contrast the clause with what the Holcroft inquiry recommended. Recommendation (1) in the section on profit stated: There should be public disclosure of balance sheets and profit and loss accounts for those activities subject to special regulation and these accounts should be shown separately from those for the company as a whole. There should be reconciliation statements for such accounts stating the results for regulated activity together with the overall accounts. This should be supported by sufficient information to show the methods used for allocating relevant items between the two sets of accounts. How far short of that very desirable objective does clause 13 of the Schedule fall? It falls a very long way short indeed. It is no particular credit to the Government that it has chosen not to adopt the setting that recommendation of the Holcroft inquiry. There is a half-baked comm-tment right down the line to the Holcroft propositions. This is a110ther element of that half-baked commitment. The House is not only misled by ministerial protestations on the level of government compliance with Holcroft recommendations but also misled on the undertaking by the Minister to permit the use of Qantas Airways Ltd seats on domestic flights between east and west. I will quote in full an answer to a question asked of the Minister by the honourable member for Tangney on 29 April 1981. The Minister said: I think the events of the last few days have indicated that the proposition-That concerned the suggestion on the permanent use of Qantas on east-west fiightsput forward by the honourable member is certainly a feasible one in terms of administration. In the longer term, however, I understand that there would for Customs, quarantine et cetera, in order to cope with the mix of passengers on such aircraft. I have initiated between the airlines to ensure that there is a way through the problem that has been concerning the Western Australian people for some considerable time.
