text: Clause 4 prescribes the constitution of the Independent Air Fares Committee. It is to be made up of three members. Amendment No.1 standing in my name reads: Clause 4, page 5, after sub-clause (2) insert the following sub-clause: '(2A) At least one member shall be a person who is a member or officer of a body having functions in relation consumer protection. ' The purpose of the amendment is to ensure that there is direct consumer representation upon the Committee so that there is a direct link from some 11 million persons who use domestic passenger air services each year to the deliberations of the Committee and there is a channel and means by which the problems experienced by members of the public in the utilisation of air services and the views as to the adequacy or appropriateness of the types of fares offered to the community can be processed AYES through to the Committee. At the same time, having direct consumer representation on the Committee would ensure that there is a link both ways-between the Committee's activities and NOES the public and then between the public in its expression of views and the Committee. Not wishing to delay the chamber at this stage, for those reasons I move: Clause 4, page 5, after sub-clause (2) insert the following sub-clause: '(2A) At least one member shall be a person who is a member or officer of a body having functions in relation to consumer protection. '

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: AYES
text: The Government notes the view of the Opposition in regard to this matter. The Government intends to leave the clause in its present form. I assure the chamber that we will obtain the best people possible whatever the qualification. There is not the slightest doubt that the quality of the people who are chosen for this task is very imShack,P.D. Shipton, R. F. portant to the functions of the Independent Air Fares Committee. The Committee has a very important task in ensuring that it sets the fares according to the guidelines that have been adopted which are consistent with the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares recommendations of setting a nationally consistent cost related fare. Every effort will be made to ensure that we will obtain really top people who NA will take into account the consumer requirements. Amendment negatived. Clause agreed to. Clauses 5 to 12-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Clause 13 (Cost Allocation Reviews).

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: PAIRS
text: by leave-I move amendments No. (2) and No. (3) together: Clause 13, page 9, sub-paragraph (2) (a) (i), line 4, omit '3 years', substitute '6 months'. Clause 13, page 9, sub-paragraph (2) (a) (ii), line 6, omit 'at least 2 years, and not more than 3 years,', substitute 'not more than 2 years'. to The purpose of the amendments is to ensure a cost allocation review of the two .major trunk operators at least within six months. If we examine the record of public analysis of the operations of the airlines since the commencement of the two airline policy we see there has been no public examination of any nature either of the costs and fare structure or of the cost allocation procedures in establishing fares other than the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Airfares which was truncated by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), who is at the table. Given the new arrangements under the Airlines Agreement Act which has just passed through this chamber tonight, and assuming that it passes through the other place, and given that both the major airlines have embarked upon major reequipment programs and that the aircraft that each airline is purchasing are of different style with different characteristics, different sizes, it is important that as soon as possible a cost allocation review of both airlines be conducted. In the Holcroft inquiry I referred to, only Trans-Australia Airlines lodged a substantive submission. As Mr Holcroft said in his report, the bulk of that inquiry's recommendations was based upon the submission of TAA. The fact is that since 1957 some 24 years have elapsed, almost a quarter of a century, and the accounts, financial performance and efficiency of Ansett Airlines of Australia have not been analysed publicly in that time. Those on the other side might say that the Department of Transport has done that. The Holcroft committee showed that it has not done that. The committee showed that, in fact, the Department of Transport, the regulatory authority, had engaged in a rubber-stamping exercise over a number of years. The Department in the domestic aviation policy review, noted that it had been unable to determine the extent of non-airline activities by Ansett Airlines. It also noted that it had been unable to get adequate information. Again, the Holcroft inquiry came to that same conclusion about lack of information, that the Department had not carried out its task. If we are to develop a system of airline services that has some relationship to an accurate measurement of efficiency, to an objective of giving a safe, convenient service at the cheapest price, then we need to have the data that would be thrown up by the cost allocation reviews. As the notes to the Independent Air Fares Committee Bill point out, the cost allocation review deals specifically with apportionment of airline operators' costs and how they should be attributed to the flag fall and the distance components of an air fare formula. It will also determine the first class fare differentials. Under the provisions of the Bill such reviews are to be held concurrently for Ansett and TAA but the first cost allocation for both those airlines, again under the provisions of the Bill, is to be conducted within three years of the enactment of this Bill. That involves well over a quarter of a century before there is any public analysis. I cannot see any substantial reason that could be advanced in support of this situation by the Government. The Government is picking up the Australian Labor Party's policy of establishing an independent body to determine fares. We commend the Government for that. We would like to see it go further, as these amendments show. I cannot see any reason, that will stand the test of responsible examination, why the Government cannot accept this amendment. It will give the Government a good base from which to assess changes in the distribution of costs as between flag fall charges, onground charges, overhead charges, and the distance component, the cost of keeping an aircraft in the air from the time it is airborne until it gets down. Let me refer to the importance of that matter. As 1 mentioned before, with the airlines going on to use different aircraft fleets-a Boeing fleet, an Airbus and DC9 fleet, with some Boeing 727s of Trans-Australia Airlines-that decision means a departure by the two major airlines from the past practice of utilising the sharing of spare parts stocks, maintenance equipment, flight simulators and so on. Let me quote again from the remarks of Mr Lyn MCKenzie on 12 September last year. Referring to the new fleets, he said: The two different major aircraft types provide the consumer with a choice, but the consumer will have to pay for the privilege. The choice of different aircraft is unfortunate from the national point of view. It will prove costly because of the need for expensive duplication of spare parts, engine test cells, flight simulators, engine overhaul and in the provision of various facilities. He went on to refer to the costs that will be incurred by passengers in being able to have the choice of flying in a Boeing aircraft, an Airbus, or whatever make of aircraft comes on the scene, particularly in the next few years. It is important, with this Committee being established, that there be a proper data base and a proper analysis of existing cost allocations of the real costs involved in flag fall and in the distance component, so that as aircraft changes come along there will be an accurate base from which to work. Finally, let me make the point that while both airlines are operating similar fleets over similar routes, with schedules having similar characteristics, irrespective of the comments we make from time to time about the lack of public analysis of accounts and the paucity of information on the operations of each airline, a rough kind of comparison can be made. Both airlines have been doing roughly the same thing with the same kind of aircraft fleets. With this change, that position will no longer pertain. Unless there is an accurate base on which to compare future performance with present aircraft fleets, again it will be a case of the Committee accepting the word of the airline. I strongly urge the Minister and the Government to accept these amendments in the spirit in which they are moved, that is, that within six months of the enactment of this legislation there should be a cost allocation review of TAA and Ansett, and that future reviews be no further apart than two years, rather than the three years provided in the Bill. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: PAIRS
text: The amendment is not necessary because the Government intends to request the Independent Air Fares Committee to conduct a cost allocation review within six months of its establishment. Mr Morris-For the major airlines? For Ansett and TAA?

text: For both, to establish the faresetting formula. The Department of Transport is engaging consultants to evaluate the formula so far established by the Department following the Holcroft report. One of the very contentious points of the whole two-airline policy was brought out very clearly by Holcroft in his report, and it a point that I have made over and over to the liament in the last three or four years. Where have a situation in which two major operators have exclusive access to the provision of a public transport service, and where they operate under legislative protection on a cost-plus basis that ensures they have to be profitable, and under legislation, as in the Schedule to the Airlines Agreement Bill, which prescribes that there be only two operators over the entire trunk network, it is a nonsense to suggest that they suffer from a risk of disclosure of information. me record in Hansard an extract from page 175 the Holcroft report. Paragraph 10.23 states: The Inquiry has observed a number of features of the administration of air fare pricing which it believes should be altered as quickly as possible. these is the lack of public disclosure of financial and performance data by the airlines. The matter of public disclosure overriding importance in the regulation of air fare pricing. A moment's reflection will recognise the irrationality of creating a protected joint monopoly, and then affording the members of that joint monopoly secrecy in relation to costing and pricing. Paragraph 10.25 states: The Inquiry points out when a company accepts a place in an industry into which competitorsSuch as East-West Airlines Udare precluded by law from entry and in which prices are set by law so as to recover costs, including profit, and in which long term government policy prescribes that there shall remain only two firms, each capable by implication that they shall survive that competition, for each airline then to adopt the stance of being a firm in a highly competitive environment, jeopardised by the slightest disclosure, is plainly ridiculous. So too is the toleration that has been Duffy,M.J. displayed over a long period by the regulatory authorityIn this case the Department of Transporta stance, apparently without asserting its right to be properly informed as surrogate for the pUblic. I could not put it in better words than it has been put in the Holcroft report. For this reason we beit is the responsibility of the two airlines to provide information to the Committee in the conthe duct of major fare reviews, so that those two airlines give full public accountability to the public and to the Parliament that gives them legislative protection in the conduct of air fares. For those reasons we believe the major fare reviews should conbe conducted in public. The effect of my amendlater ment is to bring about that result. I commend the and here in the amendment. To have a public inquiry every time there was a major fare review would result in extended inquiries. It is very necessary to have a is public inquiry for the cost allocation review to set Parthe formula. Needless to say, there would be very lengthy delays in reponses to applications if there were to be a public hearing every time there was an application for a fare increase. When one takes account of the scope of responsibility-it covers not only the trunk operators, but also the regional route operators and the commuter operators-the Committee would hold, on average, one inquiry Let each working day. E. perience in the commercial world, with a wide experience of the type of return that is available to the various industries within Australia, whether in investment, manufacturing or transport. Mr Holcroft is from the transport field, Dr Bell is from the investment field and Professor Hogan is an economist from Sydney University. I will not go into the report and the detail of the matters they considered, the kind of ratios they compared and the comparisons that they made of the NA different measures used to establish what is a satisfactory return up on funds employed upon capital or upon revenue, but those three gentlemen came to the conclusion that, in the light of all the evidence available, the most appropriate measure would be to write into future legislation a requirement relating to profit before interest and tax. Paragraph 16.82 sub-paragraph (3) of the Holcroft report states: Profit before interest and tax, excluding extraordinary items, should as a proportion of revenue not exceed 6.0 per cent, given a continuation of present levels of interest rates and income taxation in Australia. given a continuation of the present in Australia;'. Sub-paragraph (4) states: The rate of return and the rate of profit before interest and tax should be reviewed whenever there is a significant shift in the criteria by which they were previonsly established. I will not take the time of the Committee going through the detail of the background to that recommendation. I have read the recommendation and I am satisfied that it is an appropriate recommendation. I leave it to honourable members to refer to the report. Before 1 sit down I wish to repeat the point that I have made before. When two operators are given a protected and privileged position in the provision of a public transport service-a guaranteed profit through a cost plus system-in the public interest, that arrangement must carry with it a heavy responsibility for public accountability. Neither of the major operators is exposed to the degree of risk that exists in other commercial ventures in the economy. They are protected. There can be only two operators; there cannot be a third operator in the field. They are not entitled to the kind of return that could be justified in a venture or a commercial operation with a higher risk component. Airline services should be predicated upon the assessment that they are part of the public transport service. For those reasons the Opposition moves the amendment which I have outlined to the chamber. 1 commend that amendment to honourable members.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PAIRS
text: 1 want to reinforce some of the remarks made by the Opposition spokesman for transport, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) and point out that in fact the Holcroft committee considered the question of profit at very considerable length. In fact it saw it as fundamental to its whole examination of the air fare structure. The figure of 6 per cent was arrived at after extremely detailed consideration. A second feature upon which it is worth commenting and upon which the Opposition spokesman did not comment is that because of the experience of the Holcroft committee and the general tenor in which the negotiations for the two-airline agreement were conducted, it is possible that we will have some trouble ensuring full disclosure of the accounting procedures of the two airlines that will be party to this agreement. I refer not so much Trans-Australia Airlines, which was relatively blameless in its performance before the Holcroft committee, but to the other airline. The point I wish to make about this 6 per cent profit margin is that as well as being appropriately calculated by persons capable of making such a calculation and as well as being right, given the regulated nature of the airlines and ensuring that there is no exploitation of the travelling public, it would also have the very distinct advantage of concentrating the minds of the accountants of the two airlines wonderfully and ensuring that the figures which they come up with are accurate and the sorts of figures that we could subject to some form of public scrutiny. Thus [ hope, we arrive at a situation in which the airline travelling public is not exploited to the extent to which it has been to this point.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: PAIRS
text: In brief, the Government does not accept this amendment. The airlines have made an $800m investment in new generation widebodied aircraft, which will be of tremendous benefit to the travelling public generally. They are a more efficient and less noisy aircraft, and will help to stabilise the fares of passengers because of their efficiency, so long as we can maintain a sufficiently high utilisation level. Work done indicates that if the 6 per cent figure were established there is no way that either airline could operate at a profit. [n fact, they would operate at a loss. Of course, Holcroft made the point that the figure could be varied, so the question of the making of a profit will be a matter for the Independent Air Fares Committee to decide, having regard to its guidelines. The figure mentioned in the Holcroft report certainly was not one of the soundest aspects of that report.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: The AusAustralia tralian National Airlines Repeal Bill deals with the conversion of Trans-Australia Airlines from statutory authority to a public company. Obvisupport ously it is the first step by the Fraser Government in the sale of all or part of the airline. When the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) stated as and reported in the Melbourne Herald on 3 April, that shares would not be sold to Ansett Airlines Australia, he clearly did not state to whom shares would be sold. If it was proposed that the shares were not to be sold then he would not have said they would not be sold to Ansett; he would have said they would not be sold to anybody. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) agrees with the and view of the Australian Labor Party and the ma63,583 jority of Australians that the lead inevitably to the formation of a private monopoly in major domestic airline services, higher fares for travellers and the abolition of country services. We heard from two Queensland Let members of the National Country Party earlier this evening, the honourable member for Kengovernment nedy (Mf Katter) and the honourable member interesting for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), of their concern about the possible abolition of country air services in your State, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let us look at the history of Trans-Australia Airlines. It was established at a time when aviation was in its infancy. There was a very firm beThird Reading lief in this country, held by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Menzies, and also by the United Kingdom Government, that the provision of transport services should be carried out by a public utility. It was the decision of the government of BILL 1981 the day in 1946 that the most effective way to proSecond Reading vide a national system of safe, regular airline services was with one major airline. The total investin that airline, Trans-Australia Airlines, was some $14.8m in 1946. Not one dollar has been put into that airline since. It has developed and grown upon the basis of the service provided, on the reserves it has developed and on the profits it has made. We know that the two-airline policy Third Reading devised by the Menzies Government in 1952 was aimed at protecting Australian National Airways-later Ansett Airlines of Australiafrom the growth of TAA. In other words, it was devised to protect the private enterprise operator from the rigours of competition from another operator-as I said earlier, that is the very antithesis of what private and free enterprise is supSecond Reading posed to be all about. Despite the handicaps and the obstacles of the two-airline policy and despite the impediments and obstructions placed in the way of TransAirlines by successive conservative governments, Trans-Australia Airlines went on to a become a leader in market innovation, to gain the of the majority of air travellers and to hold that support year after year, establishing itself as a national symbol of endeavour, of spirit of identity as a successful public enterprise, as a successful Australian enterprise and as a symbol of of achievement by the Australian people. It has been supported by generations of Australians and generations of Australians have contributed to the development of that airline. Since 1946 the airline has carried some 71 million passengers, it has paid $35m in dividends to Consolidated Revenue, it has paid government charges and taxes of $423m it has established a national route network of unduplicated kilometres servicing some 53 sale of TAA would towns and cities. Let me put to rest the claim often made by air opponents of TAA because they see the airline as air a danger, that TAA does not pay the same taxes. me state, and the Minister will confirm this, I am sure, that TAA pays the same taxes and charges as any public company. It is to note the value put on TAA by those honourable members opposite who seek to snipe, undermine and sabotage this valuable public asset. Senator Peter Rae said in 1979 that the value was some $30m; $55m said his friends from IPEC-the Employees Share Ownership Plan people; Mr Murdoch was a little more realistic and said about $15Om. It is probably worth in the vicinity of $170m. What is the Government's case for forming TAA into a public company? The clear purpose is that it wants to appease those members of the back bench who are disputing with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and want to see successful public enterprises sold off to the public sector. By forming TAA into a company the task of proceeding to dispose of the airline is simplified. The interdepartmental committee report provided by the Minister shows that the prime demand of Ansett was that TAA should be sold to commercial interests. It is the view of numerous people of standing in this country that if TAA were sold-be it in two, three, four or five years' time; it does not matter-inevitably it would become part of a major private monopoly of domestic airline services. Mr Rupert Murdoch and Sir Peter Abeles made the demand that TAA should be sold during the negotiations for the new two airline agreement. The reason for that demand was that TAA has always been a thorn in the side of Ansett. In the absence of proper monitoring of airline costs and performance, it has acted as a monitor of the airline industry. It has acted as a barrier to higher profits in the provision of what essentially public transport. The free enterprise fanatics in the Government ranks claim that the sale of TAA would mean greater competition and cheaper fares. They say that the public could buy shares in TAA. That is a quite spurious claim even if one assumes that greater competition would result in cheaper fares and the public could buy shares in TAA. The situation is not that TAA is a barrier to greater competition. The barrier to greater competition is the legislation that earlier this evening was enshrined for eight more years by those who sit opposite. That is the barrier to competition because this Government is committed to ensuring a higher level of return to the proprietors of Ansett in return for past services rendered in relation to elections. So the barrier to competition is not TAA. It is quite spurious also to suggest that competition by itself or the presence of more than one firm would create greater competition. If one looks at the history of the two-airline policy one finds that the Menzies Government settled upon a two-airline policy because it would not have been able to say there was any competition with a oneairline policy. Two was the minimum number they could have and still give Ansett the inside running. For that reason Australian National Airways, as it was then known, was kept alive and not sold up in 1952. As I stated earlier, the two-airline policy protects Ansett, and it is the real barrier to greater competition. Changing the form of ownership of TAA will do nothing to lessen air fares. All Australians now share in the ownership of TAA. Those who have passed on, those who have worked with airline services since 1945, those who have used the services, the taxpayers who have made contributions to the development of this country in those intervening years, those who presently use TAA-and that is the majority of air travellers-are all shareholders in TAA. Under the proposals of that segment oppositethe free enterprise fanatics-TAA is to be formed into a public company. We are asked: 'Would you not want to buy shares in TAA?' There is a very short response to that. As a taxpayer, I already have shares in TAA, and I am quite happy with that arrangement. To form TAA into a public corporation-Mr Ruddock-Tell us about the dividends you get.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: The dividends are in social benefit and service and in the knowledge that TAA acts as a monitor on the industry, provides is service throughout Australia, and also provides, as two members of the National Country Party pointed out earlier, services to outback Queensland that otherwise would not be provided in the absence of TAA. That is part of the dividend I get, and I am quite happy to see those services provided to other Australians. It could be that such dividends do not suit the honourable member or that he is unhappy about such an arrangement. I am not here to deal with my pecuniary interests; that is more the concern and ambition in life of the honourable member. The fact is that the sale of TAA and its listing on the stock exchange will mean that 90 per cent of Australians who do not hold shares in public corporations, who do not buy and deal on the stock exchange, will lose their share of the ownership of TAA. The other point made by the proponents of the disposal of TAA is that TAA has some disabilities. I cannot make the point too strongly that in my view the people who make that kind of claim forfeit their right as members of Parliament to speak on this area. They are members of the Government. TAA is a creature of the Government. TAA must operate in the commercial environment created for it by the Government. So whatever problems and financial disabilities TAA has, we must remember that honourable members opposite are the bosses. They must db something about it. They cannot have the luxury and the hypocrisy of opting out and saying: 'They have problems; they should provide more information; the superannuation scheme is wrong'. They have been sitting on the Government side of the House for five years. Those honourable members who sit opposite have had longer than five years to remedy those disabilities and they cannot enjoy the luxury of complaining about the conditions under which they require the airline to operate. But they are selective criticisms. They are only criticisms of the public enterprise operator.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: We are trying to fix it up, Peter.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: That is more than some of the Minister's colleagues are trying to do. I think that even the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), who is sitting at the table beside the Minister, is trying to send it down. Again, this is chaos in Government. The Government is trying to get its act together. The financial disabilities suffered by TAA are the result of Government decisions, and the remedies lie with the government, whether it is in reporting, in entitlements to the scheme, or in funding of the scheme. The Government cannot have that luxury of then blaming the problems on the management of the airline and saying that the airline is not efficient. I would like to quote what the Minister for Transport said on 18 September 1980 when introducing the Australian National Airlines Amendment Bill (No.2) 1980. I described this Bill as an act of grovelling by the Government before the proprietors of Ansett. I want to refresh the memories of honourable members opposite about what the Minister said. He stated: Paramount amongst these changes was the need to place TAA on a more commercial basis. Since the Government aims to create a more competitive environment for the two airlines, is amending the ANA Act to ensure that TAA operates on a similar basisI underline those wordsto a privately owned airline. At the same time the Govern· ment is anxious to ensure that the ANA Commission as a statutory authority is not advantaged over its competitors. This approach is consistent with the Government's overall policy that publicly owned business undertakings should, as far as possible, be neither advantaged nor disadvantaged as compared with their competitors from the private sector. Is the Minister to tell us this evening that that was a falsehood, that what he told us on 18 September last was not true, or substantially was not true? The challenge is there for the Minister. Let me compare those words of 18 September with the Minister's words on 25 May. The Minister in his second reading speech on the Australian National Airlines Repeal Bill 1981 stated: I now acknowledge the contribution of the Australian National Airlines Commission to the development of aviation since its establishment in 1946. TAA is an airline with a great reputation. This is due to its management and staff, the people who have made and are making it a great airline. That is a pretty paltry kind of epitaph when the Government wants to send an airline down the drain. I thought that the airline would have deserved something better than four lines. The Minister went on to say: - I firmly believe that by making it a public company and freeing it of many bureaucratic controls it will go from strength to strength. Which version is correct? Is it the first speech or the second speech? I believe the first one is correct. I have looked at those amendments. The Minister was acting on the basis of fact. He had information and he spelt out in the Bill the proposed amendments, the purpose of the amendments and the reasons they were being made. The second is simply a propaganda document brought up to quieten those poor fellows from Western Australia who have been conned about the deregulation inquiry and who have now been further conned by the words 'We will make TAA into a public company. That should satisfy them. We will have a look at selling it'. The task that faces the Minister is to detail specifically the many bureaucratic controls that were not evident to him or his Department when the legislation of 1980 was submitted to the House. The major issue at stake in this whole exercise and in the thinking of the free enterprise fanatics opposite is the profit stripping of profitable public enterprises. The Government is concerned about selling off only profitable public enterprises, not the loss incurring public enterprises that are regarded as necessary services, such as railways, schools and hospitals or any other handouts to give as tax deductions. It is concerned with selling it only those services which Australians of several generations have established. This airline has been brought to a stage of development where it can be profitable. Now that the risks have been borne by past generations and taxpayers over the last 35 years, the Government says: 'Now it is profitable let us give it to our friends, the wealthy investors and stock exchange speculators'. The Government has no mandate for that action. Some Government members may feel that they would like to do that, but let me make it crystal clear to them that they have no mandate. They have a mandate to do the opposite. They said in the election campaign and have said over and over in the last few years that TAA was not for sale. This Minister for Transport, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the previous Minister for Transport are on the record as saying that TAA would not be sold. The decision to convert TAA into a public company, as I mentioned earlier, is related to a further desire to sell off the company. The Prime Minister said on the record during the election campaign that TAA was not for sale and that it would not be sold. Yet on 3 April this year in a Press interview in the street outside Parliament House he was asked by Laurie Oakes about Trans-Australia Airlines.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: What did Laurie ask him?

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: I will read it for the Minister. It is nice. The Minister will enjoy it. Mr Oakes said: It was my impression in the election campaign, Prime Minister, that you promised that TAA would not be sold. Well, was my understanding wrong? Mr Fraser said: That had been the policy of the Government, yes. We've reexamined that over recent times what changed circumstances. Mr Oakes said: Do you think it's fair Prime Minister, to make a promise in an election campaign and then say five months later, well we've changed our mind? Mr Fraser said: Oh, I think if circumstance is different, Governments have to adjust to that. Yes I do. There it is. I knew that the Minister, as a supporter of public ownership-l 00 per cent government ownership of Trans-Australia Airlineswould enjoy that. This interview reminded me of the words of the infamous Richard Nixon--'That promise is no longer operative'. In Australia we have our own Richard Nixon in politics, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. The simple fact is that this Prime Minister will do anything or say anything to get into office and to stay in office. He is the most disbelieved politician in Australia. He and his Government cannot be trusted. It is the policy of the Liberal Federal Council, arrived at in April last year, that TAA should be sold in five years. The Prime Minister and those opposite, when I raised this in debates all through last year, said that that was not the policy of the Government; it was the policy of the party. It is clear that a substantial number of those who sit opposite, who are concerned only with private gain, have adopted it as policy. Another move by the Prime Minister in this issue has been to appease the selective free enterprise fanatics on the back bench whose support he needs to hold off the honourable member for Kooyong (Mf Peacock). As I said, this Prime Minister is prepared to sell off one of oUi most successful public enterprises-a symbol of Australian enterprise and achievement-to try to save his political neck. I do not believe he can be saved. I believe he is a temporary Prime Minister. He is prepared to allow almost any dishonesty to try to justify his actions in his manic desire to get his own way. The Melbourne Sun of 1 June contains a report of his address to the Federal Liberal Council meeting of last weekend. The report states: Selling TAA shares to the public would be regarded as a provocation by any future socialist government . He said a socialist governmentI suppose he means a Labor government--would seek to bankrupt both TAA and Ansett and thus have the option of nationalising them. No one in my memory has made that statement, certainly not since I have been a member of this place. It is not the policy of the Labor Party. It does not appear in the policy of the Labor Party. There is no reference to it. It was another fabrias a result of, T think, somecation by the Prime Minister, Australia's Richard Nixon. The report continued: Assuming TAA was sold, a socialist government would regard it as the greatest possible offence to its principles and would do what it could to re-nationalise TAA and take over the other airline as well. That is another fabrication. It was not said or heard by anybody else. It was heard only by those people who heard it out of the mouth of this Prime Minister, Australia's Richard Nixon. It is not the policy of the Australian Labor Party to nationalise the airlines system. It is the policy of the Labor Party to ensure that TAA remains a 100 per cent government owned enterprise. It is the political reality that at the moment at least two major airlines operate in this country. I do not see any way that that number can be reduced unless the Government proceeds with the sale of TAA. That would produce a private monopoly in the provision of major air services. It is important to note the sniping campaign conducted against TAA's financial account by Government members. They never criticise Ansett which produces meagre financial accounts on airline operations. They never criticise the superannuation scheme, the provisions or the lack of data in Ansett's accounts. As I mentioned earlier, the solution to whinges about TAA is in the hands of Government members. TAA is a creature of government. It operates in an environment that the Government creates for it. The purpose of the Bill as set out in the second reading speech is to enable the conversion of TAA into a public company which is to be 100 per cent owned by the Commonwealth and to repeal the Australian National Airlines Act 1945. It vides for all assets, liabilities and arrangements the Commission to be transferred to the public company. It provides transitional arrangements for conversion of the Commission to a company respect of liabilities and other arrangements, areas, employees rights and service, superannuhonourable ation, et cetera. The formation of TAA into public company, as I mentioned earlier, is marginally different from the proposal contained in the Australian National Airlines Commission Amendment Bill (No.2) of 1980. It is important to note that in this Bill or the Minister's second reading speech no details are provided of the memorandum and articles of association of the proposed public company. The memorandum, as some of us will recognise is the document that describes the objectives and purposes of the company. This Bill is a blank cheque, a blanket approval for the conversion of TAA into a public company with an undefined memorandum and articles of association and in the absence of a financial directive from the Government to indicate what its purpose will be. The Minister has said that a firm of private consultants is to be appointed to advise the Government on the practicality of selling some or all of the shares in TAA, including how this might be done in the light of the Governdorse ment's aviation policies. If anybody can undercompany stand the Government's aviation policies he has big task in front of him in carrying out the work that will be given to him by the Minister. Why a firm of private consultants? Who will the firm private consultants be? As I said, the legislation gives a blank cheque to the Government to conTAA vert TAA into a public company. We have no tails of what is proposed. Let me make the point that changing the Commission's status will not mean that it will be more efficient or have greater freedom. Qantas Airways Ltd is a public company. Its major problem has been petty interference by this GovernAmendment ment's bureaucracy. The Chairman, Mr Jim year, Leslie, is on record on numerous occasions testifyclause, ing to the problems of the airline caused by government bureaucracy and government interobjectives ference. I challenge the Minister to detail specifically and precisely the improvements in the day to day management of TAA which he would expect from forming it into a public company. His theory has not worked for Qantas because the Department of Finance, the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Transport can still, and do, interfere in the operations of the company. I mentioned that a firm of private consultants prowas to be commissioned - to advise the Governof ment on the practicality of selling all or part of the shares in TAA. I ask: What firm of public consultants is to be engaged? Is it to be MCKinsey and in Co., the bosom pal of the beseiged and discredited Prime Minister and the former employer of the member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), a who is not here at the moment. The honourable only member for Mackellar, who is one of the arch proponents of the sale of TAA, the former bagman of the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party-as he is generally reputed in this place to beand a man well known to Sir Peter Abeles of Ansett Airlines. If TAA is to be examined, then as it belongs to all Australians and to all members of this Parliament, let the examination be carried out by an all party parliamentary committee, as was the case with other statutory corporations such as the Australian Industry Development Corporation and as is the case at the moment in respect of the Australian National Railways Commission. The airline belongs to all Australians and should be looked at on a non-partisan basis along with Ansett Airlines. The ultimate sole objective of this legislation is to free up TAA to provide better service to the public. Therefore, it can be understood that it would be irresponsible of this Parliament to enconversion of the airline into a public in the absence of a detailed memora andum of articles of association, especially when the policy of the major coalition partner is for the sale of the airline within four years and given the of total lack of trust in what this Government and Prime Minister say and do. The formation of into a public company is an ill-conceived, deexpensive and unnecessary gimmick. The legislation constitutes a squandering of public resources by the Prime Minister in his latest manoeuvre to head oft' yet another rebellion by Government back benchers. The Australian National Airlines Commission Bill (No.2) of 18 September last with the exclusion of the profit objective clause 17, would be supported by the Opposition. This would achieve all the important that the Minister claims this Bill will achieve. The Government has a mandate to ensure that TAA is not sold, which is the opposite of the real purpose of this legislation. Changing the form of ownership will not reduce air fares by one cent for one traveller. Converting TAA into a public company will simplify its sale and it meets the prime demands of this Government's backers, the multi-millionaire proprietors of Ansett. As I have said, the sale of TAA will result in a private monopoly and a withdrawal of country air services. This legislation was born in infamy. It should be rejected outright by this Parliament. It will be opposed at every opportunity by the Opposition, the Australian Labor Party and the majority of Australians. MI' JULL (Bowman) (11.43)-The hour is getting late and I will confine my comments to very brief statements indeed. I listened with interest to the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris). I think we have to realise that this legislation fits in as part of the whole package of legislation which the Government has brought into the House tonight. I sincerely believe the package can lead to a fairer and more equitable pricing system for air fares in Australia and ultimately cheaper air fares in Australia. It would be interesting to ponder what my philosophical commitment would have been in 1946 to the establishment of Trans-Australia Airlines. Perhaps I would have found some support for it at that stage. That is 30-odd years ago and the whole of the domestic as well as the international aviation scene has changed very much indeed. We have to be careful to avoid the situation that has developed in a number of overseas countries. I will cite just two examples. One relates to New Zealand and its Government owned domestic airline, and the other relates to Britain where British European Airways virtually acted as the country's domestic carrier. I am scared that if we do not have a full investigation of TAA and a proper look at its financial setup we will have such a situation. I am not denying that TAA has been operating on a shoestring for many years.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: And doing it well too.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: It has been doing it well. If we get to the stage at which BEA was at the end of the 1960s we could have an absolute disaster. The British Government's answer was to amalgamate BEA and the British Overseas Airways Corporation to form British Airways. Domestically and internationally that airline is now losing $235m a year. Those Government owned airlines got out of control. If Australia is not careful it could well have the same situation. I dare say that in some respect the Australian taxpayers might be contributing to the situation that has developed in British Airways. The airline is saying quite openly that the Kangaroo route to London is one of its major profit earners and if it does not have exclusive or semi-exclusive rights it will be in all sorts of trouble. Qantas recognises now that we are paying some of that heritage. I think it is important that we look at TAA. I think the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) has been very wise indeed to be quite open-minded about the matter. He has taken TAA into the realm of being a public company. He is going to arrange for a full and complete investigation of the whole financial structure. I do not think there is one honourable member who will deny that at the moment it is almost impossible to find out through the access we have in our everyday operations here in Parliament what really has been going on with TAA, its superannuation scheme, its restrictions on expenditure and its relationship with the Department of Transport. All these matters are adding up. This is really one of the wisest moves that could be made for the sake of TAA, whichever way it might go in the future. As I said the Bill is part of a total package lining domestic aviation up for the 1980s. The days of 1946 and the early 1950s are long gone. If we can look at the legislation in that respect and with the positive feeling that TAA will be owned by all the people of Australia, then we have to make sure they get value for money and that their investment is sound. This is the only way we can do it. I have every confidence that the Minister will follow the matter right the way through. If in fact his proposition is that part of the shareholding of TAA be sold, to the ultimate benefit of all Australians, so be it. But we do not know yet whether that will be so. We have a long way to go down the track before we know the true nature of the future of TAA. I speak very briefly tonight in support of the Bill. I am confident in the knowledge that the Bill is part of the legislative package that will lead to a much fairer and more equitable air fare arrangement for each and every Australian.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: [n my view the Australian National Airlines Repeal Bill is one of the most iniquitous Bills brought into this House by the present Fraser Government. In some respects it is a sale of the Australian people's birth right. As the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) said, Trans-Australia Airlines was established in 1946 by the Chifley Labor Government. Since that time TAA has carried over 71 million passengers and has paid $35m in dividends to consolidated revenue. It has also paid taxes and government charges to the Commonwealth amounting to $423m. That is not bad for a company that a number of Government members are saying is on its last legs. Indeed, in the last financial year TAA showed an improvement in its passenger growth of 7.1 per cent. It carried more freight than Ansett. TAA carried about 57 million tonnes of freight and Ansett carried about 55 million tonnes. That is not bad for an airline which the Government says needs to be deregulated. When looking at the Bill one should ask why the Government is to sell an enterprise that in 1979-80 made $2.9m profit for the Australian taxpayer. In looking at the evidence before us and even the Press statements made on the subject, it is quite clear why the present Liberal-National Country Party Government-even over the National Country Party's head-wishes to sell TAA or set it up in such a fashion that the Government, at some later date, can sell it off. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and a number of speakers in previous debates here this evening have said: 'But of course we do not have any real intention of selling the airline. We are just trying to set it up in such a commercial fashion that it will be competitive'. Indeed, the Minister said in his second reading speech: The Government intends that the new company be fully commercial with the powers of the Government restricted to rights of shareholders to appoint directors. If the facts are, as I put them to Parliament just now, that TAA is making a profit, that TAA is getting more traffic than it had in the past, that TAA is doing better than Ansett, why does the Government need to set it up in such a different fashion? I put it to the Parliament and to the Australian people that the reason is that in the long run this Government intends to try to sell TAA despite the fact that many of its own supporters say that it should not do it. Indeed, one of the Government's most influential members, the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Country Party (Mr Anthony), said at Echuca at the Country Party's Victorian branch conference that the Government must run TAA. It is very interesting that since 10 April 1981 he has not said that it must not sell it. One might ask: Why is the Government wanting to sell TAA ? Why is it setting it up in such a fashion? It is quite obvious that it is because Mr Murdoch and his friends wish to buy the airline and wish to try to dominate the airline industry in Australia. A number of Government members are obviously in league with this plan-the gang of seven that voted against the Government this evening, the deregulators who wish to see the airline industry in Australia destroyed so that there can be control of the industry by Mr Murdoch and Sir Peter Abeles. That would be to the great detriment of the people of Australia. Indeed, the people who will be the great losers will be the people of Queensland and the outlying areas of some of the States.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Does the gang of eight include the Labor Party too?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: Mr Millar)There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: I am very interested to see the behaviour of one of the Tasmanian members who so supinely agreed with the Government today that we should set up TAA in such a fashion so that it could be done away with. The Government allowed East-West Airlines Ltd to be done over in the negotiations about trunk routes. East-West Airlines, which provides a cheaper link between Tasmania and the mainland has been done over by these supine people who 'say that they stand for Tasmania. They stand for Tasmania with about as much sincerity as a person who is willing to sell out all of his or her electors. The Government has sold out East-West Airlines which was trying to do something for the Tasmanian people.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: Here he comes. The honourable member is going to try to make an excuse for what he has done.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: The mainlander wouldn't understand anything about Tasmania.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: Order! There is no point of order. I remind honourable members that frivolous points of order are not accepted by the Chair, especially at this late hour. The honourable member for Grayndler will keep his attention to the subject matter of the Bill.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I thank you for your protection from these frivolous points of order by people with very guilty consciences here this evening. As I was s-y­ ing earlier on, the reasons the Government Intends to set TAA up in such a fashion that it can ultimately be sold are quite clear. Look at the Liberal and Country parties' election promises when they went to the people last year. How many of them are still in existence? A promise by this Government is operative until the Minister can make another statement cancelling it. I put to the Parliament tonight that it is obvious that in the near future the Government will attempt to sell TAA. It will attempt to sell what is one of the great assets of the Australian people. The conversion of TAA from a statutory authority to a public company is the first step in the sale of all or part of the airline. It is interesting to see the people who do not agree with the Government. Indeed, Sir Robert Law-Smith, the Chairman of TAA, an appointee of the present Government and a man who one might think is close to the Government's line of thinking, said that he did not see any advantage to the travelling public in the sale of TAA. Indeed, he went on to say at other stages that he does not see any advantage to the Government in changing the arrangements in the way it is at present. So said the Government's own appointee as the chief executive of TAA. It is interesting to see that the Government has even fallen out with its own people. We have seen also a proposal of the Government to put consultants into TAA. The consultants, of course, as the Labor Party spokesman on transport has said, have been put in there with only one purpose in mind and that is to bring up a report which will be favourable to the line that proponents of the sale of TAA are taking in the Government. I have no doubt that the Minister for Transport, who is sitting at the table tonight, feels that he is in a rather difficult position. He knows that the people who will be the great losers in any attempt to change the arrangements that TAA has will be the people of rural Australia, the people in Queensland represented by the Minister's party. I recently had occasion to go to Charleville on a TAA Fokker Friendship. One can only wonder what would happen if TAA gave up that route. There were many women with young children on that flight. It was a very hot day. As the Minister would be aware, air turbulence in Western Queensland is very bad. Most of the people on the flight developed air sickness. Where would we be if TAA went off that route and we had some little commuter airline operating without a hostess service? Where would those people be? They would be in rather disastrous circumstances. It was interesting to hear the member for that electorate involved saying here this evening that the Government was making a very wrong decision. For once in my life I would be happy to stand here and say that I hope the Country Party wins an argument between the Government parties. It is unfortunate that the Country Party has been run over as the people of Tasmania also have been run over. Mr Humphreys-We have a Country Party Minister.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: The Minister, as I said earlier-my colleague the honourable member for Griffith mentioned him-must be very embarrassed to be sitting at the table this evening handling this Bill. Other honourable members wish to speak in this debate. I assure the Parliament that the Federal Labor Party\ when it is returned to power, and even before that, will use every means at its disposal to block the sale of TAA. If by any mischance this Government is able to sell part or the whole of TAA the next Labor Government will restore it to its rightful owners-the Australian people-so that TAA can continue to provide the service to the Australian people that it has been providing since 1934. I hope TAA will continue to provide those services for a long time in the future and that we will not have part or all of it sold to people who would try to stifle the development of one of the great institutions of this country.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES
text: The Government's real meaning and purpose with the Australian National Airlines Repeal Bill is clear. It aims to sell off Trans-Australia Airlines to the private sector and thereby effectively emasculate the quality of the air services provided in this country. However, the Bill also achieves another goal. It exposes the contradictions and incoherencies of the present Government's policies and its so-called philosophy. When looking at the policies of this Government on domestic airlines one does not know whether to laugh or to cry. Is it not contradictory and hypocritical for this Government, which has just rammed through three Bills designed to reduce competition in the airline industry, to be trying to justify this action by claiming that the Bill ensures 'that TAA operates as a competitive, commercially oriented airlines'? Thus with the Bills last before the House we were told that regulation of the industry was essential. With this Bill we are told that TAA must be made into a company, . which would deregulate its activities and free it from bureaucratic control. Why can we not get some consistency from this Government? Why does it present us with this hogwash about noble principles when what it is really out to do is to destroy the publicly owned airline altogether and to create monopoly control for a small group of rich individuals who want to control this industry? As a result of the two airlines agreement which the Government has just pushed through it is virtually impossible for TAA to compete effectively with Ansett Airlines of Australia. Yet the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in introducing the Bill before us said: By making it a public company and freeing it of many bureaucratic controls it will go from strength to strength. In other words, the Minister in the previous Bills imposed an ad hoc set of controls yet in relation to this Bill he claimed that it is necessary to make TAA a so-called public company in order to free it from ad hoc bureaucratic controls. Simple logic and coherence of principle is abandoned in the tush to sell off public, profitable assets. What is really happening is this: The Government simply determines what is in the best interest of vested interests which support it and then concocts so called philosophical arguments later. This Bill and the previous Bill, which are in blatant contradiction of each other, clearly expose the so-called philosophy as a sham.. Why is TAA to be made into company? Why is the Australian National Airlines Commission to be disbanded? The only that even resembles an argument that TAA will be subject to fewer restrictions from the Government if it becomes a so-called public company. Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Title: NOES
text: This legislation constitutes a repudiation of firm election promises given by the Government at the last election. This legislation is grounded in conspiracy. It is legislation that is utterly opposed by the Australian Labor Party. I have already MCVeigh, D. T. outlined our arguments against the legislation, but because of the late hour I will not hold the House further by dividing on the issue. The only reason for not dividing is to save the time of the House at this late hour. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a third time. KOONGARRA PROJECT AREA BILL 1981 Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by MrWilsol1: That the Bill be now read a second time. Ml' WEST (Cunningham) (12.16 a.m.)-The purpose of this Bill is once again to confuse the Northern Territory Aboriginals, by allowing uranium mining at Koongarra to proceed in the Kakadu National Park which has already been submitted for inclusion in the World Heritage List. This Bill amends the proclamation of the Governor General of 5 April 1979 which was made under section 7 (2) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 by which an area was excluded from the Kakadu National Park far the Kaangarra mining lease area. Ranger and Jabiluka, the two other major uranium mines, which border the Kakadu National Park, have Australia's largest uranium reserves. Ranger, if it goes ahead, would produce an estimated 110,000 tonnes of yellowcake, and Jabiluka about 206,000 tonnes of yellowcake. Mining at the Ranger proposal would be open cut with an annual production initially planned of 3,000 tonnes of yellowcake with a capacity to increase to 6,000 tonnes. It currently employs 1,560 workers. The permanent jobs are estimated to number only between 250 and 400. Jabiluka plans to use the underground mining technique, with an annual production of 3,000 tonnes of yellowcake. Permanent jobs are expected to number about 880. No other deposits approach the vastness of these reserves. The fact that these mines border the national park poses grave threats to the environmental safety of the park. Despite these threats at least one can say that these mines only border the Kakadu Park. Koongarra, on the other hand, with only 13,300 tonnes of mineable yellowcake, is geographically situated in the middle of the park. The open cut method for the No. 1 orebody is expected to be used in a rapid short term program lasting 18 months to two years. This is a considerable change from the original proposal which expected total production of Koongarra yellowcake to be about 28,000 tonnes. The original estimates aimed to produce 1,500 tonnes of yellowcake annually, but this estimate has now been dropped to 1,000 tonnes annually. Similarly, employment was expected to number 150 permanent jobs, but this has dropped to only 100 permanent jobs. The whole history of this deposit reveals shonky wheeling and dealing. The wholly owned Canadian company, Noranda, originally leased the deposits in 1970. When the Kakadu Park was declared in April 1979 the deposits were excised Second Reading from the park so that it actually became an enclave within the park. Just before the October election last year it was announced in this Parliament that Noranda had sold its interest in Koongarra to another wholly owned Canadian company, Denison. The timing of the announcement was deliberate, to avoid the inevitable uproar and debate about Australian resources being swapped around amongst foreign companies without Australian participation. Denison is still 100 per cent foreign owned. What is happening with the Government's 80called foreign investment and Australian equity policy? The machinations have not stopped there. This Bill represents the worse of these manipulative and deceitful dealings and amounts to a betrayal of the Australian public. Honourable members may remember that the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, as amended in 1978, provided for the declaration of the Kakadu National Park and for leasing of Aboriginal land, granted to traditional owners under the provision of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, by the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to become the Kakadu National Park. The disgraceful exclusion of certain areas from the park, including Ranger and Koongarra, for uranium mining purposes then occurred. Of course, at that time amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act provided for the leasing of former unalienated Crown land then held in trust for the traditional owners· by the Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust to the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. By November 1978 these legislative actions had resulted in the traditional owners leasing their newly acquired land to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service minus, of course, the Ranger and Koongarra uranium bearing areas. Then we saw a succession of events. We saw stage one of the Kakadu National Park proclaimed. In April 1980 we saw the draft management plan for the Kakadu National Park released for public comment. By August last year the final management plan was tabled in this Parliament. Only in April of this year the plan of management came into effect. It required 20 days in the Parliament and should have been valid for five years. We now find that Denison Mining wishes to alter the plan of its proposal to provide for the evaporation ponds and the dam to be sited inside the park area. So the purpose of the Koongarra Project Area Bill is to alter the boundaries of Kakadu National Park retrospectively to accede to the demands of Denison Mining. The Government has chosen a particularly dishonourable manner of so proceeding. The Government really had three options and it chose the most heinous and despicable option. Let me explain the three options in case the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) and the Government do not know about them. The original Parks and Wildlife Act 1975 provided for boundary changes under sections 7, 8,9, 10, 11 and 12. Under these sections 60 days should have been allowed for public comment on the proposed boundary alterations. The Director had to consider any comments and make a report to the Executive Council. Then the Executive Council had to consider the Director's report and commend a resolution to this Parliament which then should have been passed by both Houses of Parliament to become effective. The second option for the Koongarra project to proceed involved no boundary changes to the park under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. Either the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and the Northern Land Council had given their approval in writing for uranium mining or the Governor General had declared that it was in the national interest for uranium mining to proceed. Then the Governor General could have given his approval for such operations to be carried out in the Kakadu Park under the plan of management. But if mining operations were allowed in the park under those conditions then several of the conditions would have applied as set out in the management plan and the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service would have determined the environmental standards and would have had control over the operations. But the Government chose a further optionthe most dishonourable, cowardly and precedent setting action as outlined in this Bill. The Government loses control of the Senate on 1 July. The proper option, as provided in the 1975 Act-the Government's own Act; its method and its own mechanism-was eschewed because there was no hope of concluding the arrangements for the alteration before August next. If the Government chose the next option-the mining operation inside the park without a change of boundary-of course, mining would have been under the auspices of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. I know that this was recommended by the Service as the preferable option if mining was to proceed-something, however, which the Opposition does not and never will accept. Let me restate the situation. The Government, through this Bill, is retrospectively changing a Governor General's proclamation which defined the park boundaries under the Act and excluded the Ranger and Koongarra areas. The Government is changing that proclamation in retrospect. It would not even abide by its own mechanism set up in the 1975 National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. What a cynically cowardly exercise! The Government and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment will not even abide by their earlier legislation or conduct themselves according to their own rules. Mining should not proceed in Kakadu National Park. The Koongarra area is one of the most scenic places inside the park. What environmentally conscious nation could nominate an area for World Heritage listing and then proceed to mine its most scenic attraction? Only this Government-a bunch of environmental frauds if ever there were-would propose such outrageous nonsense. It is placing the Kakadu Park outside the definitive guidelines as set out by the International Union of Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources and it could be placing the success of the nomination at risk for the listing has not yet been formally accepted. This Government could be putting it at risk. It is going outside the guidelines set by the World Heritage Council on these matters. Mr Hodges-What about some energy for the Third World countries?

Speaker: Mr WEST
Title: NOES
text: -I ask the honourable member to wait. Now the Government tells us that we should support this undercover move to change the parameters of Kakadu National Park. It says that the legislation results in a smaller Koongarra mining area which now excludes the Nourlangie escarpment. The Minister points to clause 2 sub-clause (2) of the Bill, which requires that the measures must have the consent of the traditional owners of the Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust. This is no concession at all. I hope that the Aboriginals concerned understand this. To be precise, under the existing leasing arrangements arising from both the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, this Aboriginal consent is already required. Any amending proclamation which excises an area from the park will, since the whole park is Aboriginal land, therefore, terminate the leasehold interest of the Director of National Parks and Wildlife Service in that area. Then this area would revert to its original owners, that is, the Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust and the traditional owners. The particular excised land would then become subject to sections 40 and 41 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. As this is quite important and exposes the Government's subterfuge in this matter I ask leave of the House to incorporate those sections in Hansard, which will save me reading them out and save the time of the House. (2) Where the Minister and a Land Council, after considering proposals placed before them by an applicant for an exploration licence in respect of for the exploration for minerals on that land and the recovery of any minerals found as a result of the exploration, have; for the purposes of sub-section (I), consented to the grant of that licence, that sub-section does person of other mining interests in respect of that land that are in substantial accordance with those proposals. (5) Sub-section (I) does not apply to the grant to a person of a lease in respect of Aboriginal land under the Petroleum (Prospecting and Mining) Ordinance 1954 of the Northern Territory, as amended from time to time, if that person applied for the grant of such a lease in respect of that land the land became Aboriginal land. (6) If the land, or part of the land, described in Schedule 2, being the land known as the Ranger Project Area, becomes Aboriginal land, sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to that land, or that part of the land. (7) Sub-section (I) does not apply in relation to the land described in Schedule 3, being the land known as the Eastern Areas on Groote Eylandt. 41.
