(2) If the land, or part of the land, deScribed in Schedule 2, being the land known as the Ranger Project Area, becomes Aboriginal land, sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to that land, or that part of the land.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Title: NOES
text: 1 thank the House. Honourable members will understand that sections 40 and 41 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act are the Aboriginal right of veto sections which require the consent of Aboriginal owners to all mining except for land for which petroleum leases were issued before the land became AborOPERATIONS iginal land, the Ranger uranium mining project area and the eastern area on Groote Eylandt. Of respect of Aboriginal land shall course, Koongarra is not included in any of these areas where the veto does not apply. So the Aboriginals have the power of veto anyway, as I have explained. There was no need for the Government to put into this Bill clause 2 sub-clause (2). It is simply a means of trying to persuade the Aboriginals that the Government is giving them something. But I am sure that they will not fall for it. It is history that the Aboriginals were not conAboriginal land, being proposals sulted until after the decision had been made; neither was the National Parks and Wildlife Service consulted. not apply to a later grant to that I wish now to refer to a statement issued by the traditional owners of the Koongarra project on 2 or 3 May this year. To save me from reading out all the statement. I seek the leave of the House to incorporate this statement in Hansard. Leave granted. The document read as follows·-NA PROJECT: PRESS RELEASE On Friday I May, a large meeting of traditional owners and the Gagudgu Association Incorporated was held at Patonga in the Kakadu National Park. The meeting was held in response to a letter sent by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, to the Northern Land Council which advised that the before Federal Government had decided to excise a further area from the Kakadu National Park in response from Denison (Australia) Pty Ltd. Denison for some time had been negotiating with the traditional owners of the area through the NLC for the right to mine Koongarra 20km south of the uranium mine at Jabiru. Denison declared that the existing mining lease was unacceptable for their purposes. Denison asked the Federal Government to excise a further area from Kakadu, thereby excluding any control over their mining lease by the ANPWS which presently manages Kakadu Park under a lease from the traditional owners. On 28 April, the NLC received a letter from the Minister which advised that the Federal Government would implement Denison's request. At no time were the traditional owners of the area, the Gagudja Association (the Aboriginal owners of the entire area of the Park) nor the NLC invited to give an opinion about the application of the new lease, although the NLC was aware that a submission was to be made to the Federal Government. Indeed for the owners of the area the very first they heard of the lease question was already implemented. The day after receipt of was held at Patonga to discuss the issue. The meeting lasted two days and was attended by the traditional owners of the mine site, representativcs of the Gagudja association, members of the NLC negotiating team and representatives of the NLC. The traditional owners after considering various options decided to ask the NLC to write opposition to the granting of the new lease. They demanded that the Minister revoke his decision until such time as the traditional owners had been fully and until they had had the opportunity of having advice from their own advisors as to possible effects the excision would have on the management of the Kakadu Park. They also resolved to immediately suspend all negotiations until further notice with Denison in respect of the Koongarra project. They further demanded that Denison cease having any contact with the Aboriginal people of the area. The traditional owners expressed their absolute disappointment with the Minister regardless sultation by himself, his office and those who went before them could again make decisions about what would happen about Aboriginal land. As the traditional owners asked "How can it be that the Minister can give our land away to a mining company without asking what we want". This is not self determination. This is the same as always. White fellahs making their own decisions about what is good for Aborigines.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Title: TRADITIONAL OWNERS OF KOONGARRA
text: I thank the House. I would like to quote briefly from that statement. It states: The traditional owners expressed their absolute disappointment with the Minister regardless of the rhetoric about consultation by himself, his office and those who went before them could again make decisions about what would happen about Aboriginal land . As the traditional owners asked 'How could it be that the Minister could give our land away to a mining company without asking what we want'. This is not self determination. It is the same as always. White fellahs making their own decisions about what is good for Aborigines. r trust the Aboriginals will continue to latest Government manoeuvre. After all, as I have explained, they have the power to prevent this extremely dangerous precedent from being established. 1 trust the Aboriginals will not be bamboozled by slick lawyers or Government members saying they must accede to this outrageous denial of their rights-for reasons such as that uranium mining is inevitable anyway, or that the new area is less environmentally sensitive than the current leasehold and so on. They will say anything to confuse and bamboozle the Aboriginals into accepting what the Government decided before it even consulted them. Even if this latter point were true, I trust the Aboriginals concerned-the traditional owners, the Northern Land Council and the Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust-will rethe Denison application had been alise that next time the Government wishes to change the park boundaries to accommodate the lctter by the NLC a meeting overseas mining companies the area concerned may be an area of intense sacred significance to them. That will not prevent the Fraser Government from interfering with Aboriginal land by the introduction of further legislation. In short, T think the Aboriginal traditional owners will and to the Minister and declare their should remember Noonkanbah. The Opposition also opposes this legislation beconsulted regarding the matter cause of the obvious precedent it sets and the poor example it gives to future Federal and present State governments. What a great example to give to Mr Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland who now threatens Moreton Island with sand mining and the Great Barrier Reef with oil drilling! The Queensland Premier knows this Government will not stand up to him. That is why he has refused for so long even to name his Ministers-although of the rhetoric about conhe may have just done that-to attend the time wasting ministerial council meetings on the Great Barrier Reef so he can prevent any more of the reef being declared a marine park. What a wonderful bonus this Bill is to the enemies of national parks in the Northern Territory and Queensland. We do not tamely accept the Minister's statement that the new area will be less sensitive to damage; not at all. Concerning the revised open cut mining and rapid short term program, it states: I quote the report on the project circulated by the Denison mining company: A number of environmental advantages are involved, such as the reduction of the permanent workforce on site, reduction of radiation doses received by pitworkers; reduction of pit dewatering time and thus reduction of quantities of waters to be stored allowing reduced evaporation pond areas and flexibility to the water management scheme. There we have all the horrors exposed, and the bland remarks by the company as to how to reduce them. How nice it is to know that the workers' doses of radiation will be less because of resist this the reduced time scale and that the threat of water contamination is slightly reduced for the same reason! The report entitled 'Development of the Alligator Rivers Uranium Deposit', compiled by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission in January 1980, assessed the Koongarra area as being 'of high national park value'. The report states: Any water pollution arising [rom the operations of Koongarra would be a potential threat to the very valuable wildlife of the W oolwonga wetlands. The proposal to build the tailings dam in a natural drainage system gives further ground for concern since it means that, over the long term, as the dam wall and other protective works deteriorated the tailings would probably be subject to erosion. Do honourable members opposite realise that tailings from uranium mining can give off radon gas, which is carcinogenic, for 100,000 years? Yet the people involved expect to store this material in clay dams in a wetlands area of the Northern Territory. How long will it stay there? Where is their responsibility to future generations? We cannot take any comfort from the statement in the Minister's speech that the most important feature of the new mining plan outlined in the environmental impact statement is that it provides for a system of water management which has a no release objective. He is talking about an area with one of the highest rainfalls in the world. Similarly, his assertions that the project has undergone comprehensive analysis in line with Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act requirements are meaningless. Such so called analysis has never yet prevented dangerous projects from proceeding. Neither can we take comfort from the Denison mining company's report on the water management system being based on this famous no release objective. The objective is fine; the question is whether such an objective can be achieved. In the words of that company's report, the objective is: There will be no intentional release of waters from the milling and run-off waters from the disturbed areas of the project to the environment. The problem remains, what if there is an unintentional release of contaminated waters? The protection offered to the environment is based entirely on the supposition that there will be no accidents and no unforeseen hazards. Of course, the answer to that assertion can be seen by everyone. We need only look as far as the Three Mile Island accident in the United States. The authorities still have not been successful in cleaning that up. Again, the report states: The water management system does not rely on the establishment of water quality standards as there will be to the environment. All this means is that there are no safeguards and no environmental protection in the case of the unexpected. Theoretical models provide no guarantee for reality. Koongarra, as I have said, is in one of the highest rainfall areas in the world. What happens if contaminated waters are released? Not only is Koongarra an enclave in the national park but also it is upsteam of the Woolwonga wildlife sanctuary. Koongarra is situated in the Nourlangie Creek catchment in a great and beautiful valley upstream from the sanctuary, in the second major catchment area in the national park. Any contamination in this area threatens, to quote the Fox report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, 'the most important refuge and habitat for aquatic wildlife in the Northern Territory'. Justice Fox opposed mining at Koongarra on the following grounds: We would oppose in principle any mining development upstream of itThat is, the Woolwonga areauntil it had been demonstrated by experience that it could take place without environmental damage. What sort of experience has been gained? None; there is no experience at all. I turn now in my concluding remarks to the economic and market effects of what is happening in Australia. Last year the United States produced over 11,000 tonnes of uranium, one and a half times domestic annual consumption, in excess of its needs for nuclear power generation. This is indicative of the overproduction throughout the world. In 1978 the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development estimated world surpluses between 1982 and 1985 of almost 24,000 tonnes each year, and overproduction will continue until the year 2000. World demand has not increased at the rate forecast in the mid-1970s. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission predicted in 1975 that world demand would be 107,500 tonnes in 1985 and 157,500 tonnes by 1990. Yet in 1980 the Commining. mission revised the estimate downwards by almost 65 per cent to 39,000 tonnes in 1985 and 54,000 tonnes by 1990. The reduced project demands coupled with a crash in the price of uranium from $43 a pound in mid-1979 to $25 a pound in January 1981 have put an economic cloud over many of these projects touted to proceed in Australia during the 1980s. Already it looks as though the Mary Kathleen project will be folding due to the drop in prices. If the nine mines which may proceed in the 1980s get the go ahead-I refer to Ranger, Jabiluka, Yeelirrie, Koongarra, Beverley, Honeymoon, Lake Way, Ben Lomond and Roxby no release Downs-Australia could be producing at least 14,200 tonnes a year, at a conservative estimate. Yet even the AAEC expects Australia to be able to capture only 20 per cent, or between 8,000 and 9,000 tonnes a year, of the world market by 1990. What will we do with the extra 6,000 tonnes of uranium produced in Australia each year? Will we stockpile it or simply flog it on the world market at bargain basement prices with the Australian public picking up the tab to subsidise the mines if necessary? Of the multiplicity of projects proposed, which ones will be approved; which ones will proceed? No doubt the States and the Northern Territory would allow them all to proceed but the companies may not be happy to proceed without guaranteed markets. The Northern Territory Minister, Mr Tuxworth, stated a few days ago that if Jabiluka and Koongarra did not go ahead by 1985 they would not be goers at all. If Jabiluka cannot proceed, what chance will projects such as Honeymoon, Beverley, Ben Lomond, et cetera have? These three aforementioned projects, as well as Koongarra, are also environmentally damaging as well as being commercially dubious. Beverley and Honeymoon use the environmentally dangerous method of in situ leaching of uranium ore, which may contaminate the water table and affect the quality of the water of the artesian basin. Koongarra, as I mentioned earlier, is in the Nourlangie catchment area upstream of the most important wildlife refuge and habitat for aquatic wildfowl in the Northern Territory. As I said, Justice Fox specifically recommended that it not proceed.Irrespective of the environmental hazards of the various projects, their economics make them millstones around the neck of Australia. Since they will have problems finding markets, their uranium may be sold off at cut rate prices, with the Commonwealth providing subsidies to cover the costs. The reduction in world demand for uranium can be attributed mainly to the problems of nuclear safety and a general turn away from nuclear power. The Japanese nuclear power industry is reeling from the disclosure that this year there have been four or five major leaks from the Tsuruga power station which were not reported by the company. Several tonnes of radioactive water leaked into the sea and caused abnormally high radioactivity in the seabed. Measurement of this heightened level of radioactivity led to the discovery of the spill and revealed the cover-up by the company. Officials believe that the ground under the plant could be contaminated and that 278 workers may have received excessive radiation. The Tsuruga reactor has been closed for six months, but its effects, like those of the more famous Three Mile Island plant, will be felt in the world's uranium market and will seriously affect the viability of new Australian projects coming on stream in the 1980s. I conclude by pointing out that the Government is not pressing for Koongarra on economic or environmental grounds, but rather to maintain its face as agung ho 'development at all costs' government and to keep in step with like minded State governments. Justice Fox recommended against Koongarra, the Aboriginal traditional owners are opposed to it, the markets are not there, yet the Government is proposing to disregard provisions of its legislation to achieve boundary changes to allow Koongarra to proceed. This is a travesty of the parliamentary system and must be condemned. Koongarra should not proceed. The Opposition will stand by its anti-uranium mining policy and will vote against this despicable legislation.

Speaker: Mr TAMBLING
Title: TRADITIONAL OWNERS OF KOONGARRA
text: The Koongarra Project Area Bill is ofimmense importance to the Northern Territory. It is a progressive step for the Government to take in its uranium policies. Because the Bill relates to uranium mining it has engendered much emotional debate in the community-debate on issues that are far removed from what this Bill sets out to do. For that reason, I would like not only to place the Koongarra development in its context but also to dispel some of the more fanciful myths that have been peddled to belittle this legislation. This Bill has one objective-to alter the boundaries of the Koongarra project area. It does not give approval for mining to take place. It does not change the status of Aboriginal land. It does not supersede Commonwealth environmental legislation. I will deal with those matters later. Exploration for uranium in the Northern Territory first commenced in 1947. The first important discovery was made in 1949 at Rum Jungle, 64 kilometres south of Darwin. This find initiated a short but intense prospecting boom that resulted in the discovery of 12 small but high grade uranium-gold deposits in the South Alligator River area 220 kilometres south east of Darwin. Treatment plants were established in both Rum Jungle and the south east Alligator Rivers region. The latter operated between 1959 and 1964 and produced 800 tonnes of uranium oxide. The Rum Jungle plant operated between 1954 and 1971 and produced 3,500 tonnes of U 30 S' In 1967 the Government announced an export policy for uranium which was designed to encourage exploration for new uranium deposits. Subsequent exploration revealed significant new deposits at Nabarlek, Jabiru, Jabiluka and Koongarra. Those four sites contain over 330,000 tonnes of U 30 S and there is potential for further discoveries in the region. Indeed, only last week Energy Resources of Australia raised its probable and possible reserves at its No.3 ore body at Ranger by 24 per cent, or 13,800 tonnes. To gain an idea of the importance of the region and the magnitude of these projects, suffice it to say that the total estimated capital expenditure in the uranium province on these developments is in excess of $1 ,000m. In 1968 Noranda Australia Ltd began exploring for uranium in the Northern Territory as part of a wider program of mineral exploration it had begun several years earlier. In 1970 the company discovered in the Alligator Rivers region the uranium deposits now known as Koongarra. By mid-1971 investigations showed that the deposit was a major energy resource and that development was technically feasible and economically viable. In May 1972 Noranda and other companies with exploration rights in the region joined the Commonwealth in commissioning the Alligator Rivers study-a series of investigations undertaken during 1972-73 which provided a valuable inventory of the environment of the region. In 1976 Noranda applied for a special minerallease of 12.5 square kilometres, which was considered appropriate for the then proposed project area. The following year the Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development directed Noranda, pursuant to the administrative procedures under the Environmental Protection Act, to prepare and submit to him an environmental impact statement. This was published in December 1978. In its environmental impact statement the company presented a revised concept requiring the tailings and evaporation ponds to be located outside the lease application area. One of the reasons for this was the reservations expressed by Mr Justice Fox in the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry about mining in this area. It certainly intrigues me that opponents of the Koongarra development are obsessed with quoting Justice Fox's reservations as a means of defeating this proposal. They completely ignore that it is partially in response to Justice Fox's reservations that the proposal to alter the boundaries has come about. The proposal contained within the Bill is to alter the boundaries of an area which has already been excised from the park following the whole review process entailed in the Ranger inquiry. Therein lies the most important feature of the new mining plan. The new boundaries provide for a system of water management which has a no-release objective. Being a self-contained system, it would not affect the Nourlangie Creek catchment or the Woolwonga Wildlife Sanctuary. Such a proposal can hardly be described as 'environmental vandalism', as the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) would like us to believe. It should be pointed out that the revised project area is actually smaller than the area now excluded from the park. Furthermore, the area to be added to the park will include the area adjacent to the Nourlangie Rock-Mt Brockman massif. Not only is this area environmentally important, but also it has great traditional significance to the Aboriginal people of the area. Critics of the Koongarra project are touting this proposal as a gift of Aboriginal land to a mining company. There is no question of this Government giving away Aboriginal land to mining companies. It should be understood that, regardless of whether the project area is in or out of the national park, it remains Aboriginal land. Moreover, no lease can be granted over the area to Denison Mines Ltd until the Aboriginals have concluded an agreement with the company. It is worth stressing that this Bill contains a specjfic provision that the changes will not take place unless Aboriginal consent to the project is forthcoming. The only confusion in the whole area is that which has been induced by the honourable member for Cunningham. As I mentioned before, this Bill in no way supersedes environment legislation, nor does it bypass the foreign investment guidelines. If anyone has any doubts about this I refer him to a question answered in this House on 24 February by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony). He said: . . . the object of the environment protection legislation had been met and complied with in relation to the Koongarra project . . . On Australian ownership he said: It will be necessary for 75 per cent equity participation. On this matter where does the Australian Labor Party really stand? On 29 April this year the Northern Territory Opposition Leader, John Isaacs, issued an apology for a public statement on Koongarra, ostensibly opposing all forms of mining in the Kakadu National Park. It is the most wishy-washy statement that the Northern Territory Opposition Leader has come up with to date. He said: It's the location we object to, not mining per se. The ALP would rather write off the expected $1,OOOm capital investment in the region. That is the only conclusion I can draw from Mr Isaacs statement. He also said: The exclusion of Kakadu from any form of mining development would have an insignificant effect on the predicted value of this boom. He then apologised for such stupid ALP policies. He said: . . . the economic impact of the decision not to mine would, fortunately, be less severe. The ALP in the Northern Territory spends most of its time nowadays trying to dissociate itself from the embarrassing anti-uranium mining policies which it knows the electorate will not buy and which its federal colleagues have adopted. The Northern Territory ALP must really cherish its colleague, the honourable member for Cunningham, the alternative Minister for Environment when he says: A Federal Labor government will repudiate any commitments made by a non-Labor government for mining, processing or export of uranium and we will demand a moratorium on uranium mining. The Koongarra Project Area Bill is a sensible piece of legislation and a major step forward for the uranium industry. I urge that it be passed without delay.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: TRADITIONAL OWNERS OF KOONGARRA
text: It is regrettable that the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Tambling) in defending this legislation has established himself primarily as an exponent of uranium mining. Not once in his speech was he concerned to deal with the environmental factors that this proposal involves. Not once did he concern himself with the rights of traditional owners. Of all the legislation that has emanated from the Fraser Government this is the saddest and the most contemptible. It is contemptible because it contemplates a gross abuse of the legislative process. It is the saddest because it constitutes one more betrayal of Aboriginal hopes and aspirations. This Bill contemplates the Parliament's not complying with the procedures of its own legislation at the request of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson). The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act contemplates parks and reserves being established by the Governor General by proclamation. Once proclaimed, any exclusion of any area shall not be made except by resolution passed by each House of the Parliament by a motion which must be before each House for 15 sitting days before being moved. It seems to me to be extraordinary that the Parliament in its wisdom has decided the course which must be followed by this House and the Senate in dealing with any additions or alterations to the Governor General's proclamation in respect of the creation of a national park. It is extraordinary that from time to time the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and other Ministers say that trade unionists must comply with the law and that parliamentarians are pledged to uphold the laws made by the Parliament. Yet in this situation the very procedures which have been established by this House have not been adhered to, nor has there been any attempt to adhere to them. This is a Bill by which the Minister asks the Parliament to deem that those procedures have been followed. What a novel concept that is. Every member of this House knows that the procedures established by the will of the Parliament have not been followed. If members of parliament are not prepared to comply with the spirit and, indeed, the letter of their own legislation, how can they command respect from the rest of the community? This legislation has all the worse defects of retrospective legislation. It has one more defect. Not only is it retrospective but also it asks the Parliament-it seems to me to come very close to being a contempt of the Parliament-to support what the Minister knows is a retrospective lie. He knows that the procedures established by the Parliament have not been followed. We all know that. So we have this device by which all the members here will say to the community at large: 'Although we know the procedures established by the Parliament for dealing with this legislation have not been followed and have been deliberately ignored what we will do is deem that they have been followed'. That is a very dangerous precedent. I believe any parliament which adopts that approach on any form of legislation is bound ultimately to hold itself up to public ridicule and contempt. We cannot as parliamentarians require the average citizen to comply with the laws of the Parliament, we cannot ask the average COl'POTation, trade union, trade unionist or company director, to comply with laws which we have passed but, when it suits the Executive or the Minister, introduce a Bill and simply tear up Acts of the Parliament. What is the purpose of this? Not only does the Minister choose to legislate in this way; but also we have to ask ourselves why, when the procedures are so clearly established, does the Minister choose to legislate in this way. The answer is very simple. His purpose is simply to ram this legislation through both Houses before the political composition of the Senate changes to reflect more accurately the views of the Australian people. That in itself is a thoroughly bad principle. The honourable member for the Northern Territory referred to the environmental impact statement produced on behalf of the Koongarra project. If he had looked at that November 1977 impact statement he would have seen at page 2-180 and page 2 208 a map which accords, in all respects, with the boundaries proposed by the Bill. That is to say, in November 1979 in respect of the submission and environmental impact statement, what was contemplated by the Koongarra people was the very outlines of the very map now before this Parliament. I find it extraordinary that in the nomination dated May 1980, which goes from this Parliament to the World Heritage List, the old boundaries are indicated on the map on page 12 of the accompanying submission. Of course, that is the old map. What an extraordinary situation! Koongarra in November 1979 used the map shown in the Bill but in the submission on behalf of the Government to get the Kakadu National Park listed in the World Heritage List we are using the map which is about to be changed if the Bill is passed. I believe that that also is ation which needs some explanation. J believe that the Government's actions in regard to this legislation must put in jeopardy the seri-,)Us consideration of the Australian application for the inclusion of Kakadu in the World Heritage List. It is indeed novel that while specifying the uniqueness of the environment-the habitat of flora and fauna and the fact that this area contains one of the world's great prehistoric art collections-the Government produces legislation which must be unique-in order to extend mining within that very area. Of course, if the honourable member for the Northern Territory had been completely frank with the House he would have pointed out that the Koongarra submission concedes that if this proposal is passed three important art sites will be directly affected. They will be covered by dumped waste material. Another nine sites will be indirectly affected. It is a strange thing that the honourable member for the Northern Territory, who quoted from the environmental impact statement, misstated those very facts. My colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) will enlarge upon aspects of the Fox report. I will leave that matter to him. However, I will now turn to what I believe is the very serious treatment of the traditional owners. By legislative enactment this Parliament gave the traditional owners of the land their rights in fee simple. They are the owners of the land. Their rights are as enforceable in law as are the rights of the Prime Minister in respect of his property at Nareen. Earlier this week the Parliament was told how the Minister for Communications (Mf Sinclair) was not only concerned to discuss with Mr Murdoch and the Packer interests important legislation dealing with communication but was also happy to give them the draft legislation. We were told that that discussion was continuing. Those people made suggestions to the Minister and the Minister made suggestions to them. Pieces of draft legislation were floating around. I suppose the Prime Minister would justify that action on the basis that it involved consultation with interested and affected parties. Can there be any more serious interference with the rights of an individual-particularly by a government which prides itself on preserving the rights of the individual and talks about the rights of private property-than a situation in which the rights of an owner of property are affected by legislation of this kind without any consultation? What is it that gives the Packer and Murdoch interests the a situright to an ongoing and very considered consultation and the capacity to affect legislation that the Parliament has not even seen? On the other hand traditional Aboriginal owners can have their rights to property affected by legislation without discussion, consultation or any involvement. I refer the House to the Press release of the traditional owners of the Koongarra project. To save time. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard. Leave granted. The document read as followsPRESS RELEASE. BY TRADITIONAL OWNERS OF On Friday 1st Maya large meeting of Traditional Owners and the Gagudgu Association Kakadu National Park. The meeting was held in response to a letter sent by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Baume) to the Northern Land Council which advised that the Federal Government had decided to excise a further area from the Kakadu Park in response to a request from Denison (Australia) Pty Ltd. Denison have for some time been negotiating with the traditional owners of the area, through the Northern Land Council, for the right to mine uranium south of the uranium mine at J abiru. Denison declared that the able for their proposed mine. Denison asked the Federal Government to excise a further area from the Kakadu Park, thereby excluding any control over their mining lease by the ANPWS which presently manages the Kakadu Park under a lease from the traditional Aboriginal owners. On the 28th April, the letter from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume which advised that the Federal Government would implement Denison's request. At no time were the traditional owners of the area, the Kakadu Association (the Aboriginal owners of the entire area of the Park) nor the Northern Land Council invited to give an opinion about the application for the new lease, although the Northern Land Council were aware that a submission was to be made to the Federal Government. Indeed, for the owners of of the lease question was that Denison's application had been already implemented. The day after receipt of the letter by the Northern Land Council, a meeting was held at Patonga to discuss the issue. The meeting lasted two days and was attended by the traditional owners of the mine resentatives of the Gagadju Northern Land Council negotiating team and representatives of the Northern Land Council. The traditional owners, after considering various options, decided to ask the Northern Land Council to write to' the Minister and declare their opposition to the granting of the new lease. They demanded that the Minister revoke his decision until such time as the traditional owners had been fully consulted regarding the matter and until they had the opportunity of having from their own advisors as to possible effects the excision would have on the management of the Kakadu Park. They also resolved to immediately suspend all negotiations until further notice with Denison (Australia) Pty Ltd in respect of the Koongarra Project. They further demanded that Denison cease having any contact with the Aboriginal people of the area. The traditional owners expressed their absolute disappointment that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs regardless of the rhetoric about consultation by who went before them could again make decisions about what would happen to Aboriginal land. As the traditional owners ask 'How can it be that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs can give our land away to a mining company without asking what we think' this is not self determination, this is the same as always, white fellahs making their own decisions about what is good for Aboriginals. Further Enquiries: To be made through Gagadju Association, Mr Ross Hebblewhite. Phone 81 4228.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: KOONGARRA PROJECT
text: I suspect that if this was happening to any of the honourable member's constituents such as the farmers he would be heard to complain. I am not going to give lip service or support-no one on this side of the House the area, the very first they heard would give such support-to legislation which does not comply with the processes or the standards which the House has set itself and which interferes with the rights of owners of property. The Koongarra people are traditional Aboriginal owners. Although some members of the National site and surrounding areas, repAssociation, the members of the Country Party might choose to treat them as second class citizens with second class rights, that is not the view of the Opposition. Of course, the passage of this legislation is designed to do one more thing. The honourable member for the Northern Territory clearly gave away the intentions of the Government. Does anybody seriously believe that the honourable member does not think that mining will proceed? That was the basis of his whole speech. When this legislation goes through the Parliament all the pressure will be asserted on the traditional owners by the mining companies, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister. They will say: 'You are going to have mining; like it or leave it. Although we will make public statements saying we will not do anything without himself, his officers and those your approval, the only right you really have is to approve mining'. That is the position that this Government takes. That is what this legislation is about. The Opposition is totally opposed to this legislation because it does not comply with the processes which the House itself has established. It clearly involves a great breach of the legislative process. We are opposed to the legislation because traditional Aboriginal legal land owners are having their rights eroded in a way which constitutes a public scandal. Finally, we are opposed to it because it is simply an attempt to pressure traditional owners to give their approval to uranium mining. I will finish on this note and quote what I believe are some words of nobility by that great Australian author, Xavier Herbert, which I believe, ought to be constantly quoted in this House when we are dealing with Aboriginal affairs. He says: Until we give back to the blackman just a bit of the land that was his, and give it without provisos, without snatch it back, without complete generosity cession for the evil we have done him-until we do that, we shall remain what we have always out integrity, not a nation, but a community of thieves.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: KOONGARRA PROJECT
text: -At this early hour in the morning in the stealth with which we are putting through this important piece of legislation, it is important to consider two important aspects. First of an the Koongarra Project Area Bill deals with one of the major gems of our national heritage and a gem of world heritage. We are also dealing with a question of substance which is basic to one of the most serious problems, which, in fact, can end mankind. Uranium mining-Government members hate to be reminded of this-cannot be divorced from the interrelationship with the nuclear industry which, in due turn, is interrelated with nuclear weapons and in turn with nuclear war. What Government members always want to forget are the recommendations and findings of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry report set out at page 185. The report states: 3. The nuclear power industry is unintentionally ting to an increased risk of nuclear war. This is the most serious hazard associated with the industry. It does not matter whatever one does; one cannot divorce the peaceful uses from the warlike uses of nuclear industry. That is one aspect. Another aspect of the nuclear power industry is that it is sick and stagnant in the northern hemisphere. Later I will show the House certain figures to prove the fact that the nuclear industry economically is stagnant and sick. Forecast growth is falling sadly. I will show the House reports of Australian atomic energy interests on that aspect. The real price of uranium oxide, in fact, is only half the price it was five years ago. These are just some of the aspects. I want to emphasise and interrelate the serious aspects that we are now talking about in regard to a national park with the spread of nuclear weapons which the third finding and recommendation of the Fox report deals with. Of course, at the time of the Fox inquiry's examination we knew that India had got the bomb by stealth. Now we know that Israel has got the bomb by stealth. We know that South Africa has got the bomb by stealth. We know that Pakistan is well on the way to getting the bomb by stealth. We know that during the recent conflict in the Middle East, Israel thought that Iraq was on the way to getting the bomb by stealth. Some of the major statesmen in the world believe that within a short term-a decade-anything up to 20 nations in the world could have the bomb. In these early hours, when the newspapers have been put to bed, when we strings to are not on the air, we are discussing this of spirit in COIllegislation. been so far, a people withThis Bill is a disgraceful and cynical piece of legishtion. Its purpose is to short-circuit the normal procedures for altering the boundaries of a national park. They are reasonable procedures, but this Government is sweeping them aside so that it can alter the boundaries of the Kakadu National Park to suit a 100 per cent foreign owned uranium mining company, Denison (Australia) Pty Ltd. The reason for the Government's manipulation are blatant and cynical. At the federal election last October nearly 52 per cent of the electorate voted for two parties-the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats--which oppose the mining and export of uranium. Those parties, after 30 June, will have half the seats and therefore half the votes in the Senate. That is why this legislation is being pushed through in the stealth of the night. Under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act there has to be 60 days for public comcontribu- ment on proposed changes to national park boundaries. After that both Houses of Parliament have to support the change. This procedure is a reasonable safeguard to protect national parks which have been set aside for the benefit of generations to come. National parks should not be subject to short term interests and political manipulation by governments. This Government is manipulating in the interests of wealthy mining companies and foreign mining companies at that. That is why there should be 60 days for public comment and the support of both Houses of Parliament before any changes take place. The Government's action undermines those procedures. Its intention is to thwart the majority vote against uranium mining at the last election, which will be reflected in the Senate after 30 June. This Bill is an abuse of the parliamentary institution and an affront to the Australian people. It demonstrates this Government's scant regard for democracy. The Government certainly has no understanding of the democratic procedures or environmental procedures. The Government's fiddle becomes even more serious when one considers that it was this Government which nominated the Kakadu National Park to be part of the World Hertitage List. It is a national disgrace that this Government nominates the park as part of the World Heritage List and then in such a cavalier fashion brings this piece of legislation before the House. The Government's action opens up a Pandora's box for the future. Think about it. You are a Queenslander, Mr Deputy Speaker. Think about the implications of the same attitudes on the question of the Great Barrier Reef, of what can happen with the procedures that have come down under this piece of legislation. The Government has fiddled with the boundaries of national parks to suit the conveniences and expediencies of the day. It is a shameful and irresponsible precedent which poses a threat to our national parks everywhere. The Bill highlights once again the absurdity of the Kakadu National Park as declared by this Government. The Government has left a series of mining reservations in the middle of the Kakadu National Park area out of the park. These are at Ranger, Jabiluka and Koongarra. Uranium mining is to take place at these locations. This destroys the whole concept of a national park. I stress that one cannot isolate areas in the middle of a complex and fragile ecosystem. These artificial boundaries in no way change the interrelationships of the ecological system. The uranium mines are a threat to the sensitive and beautiful wetlands which are downstream and within the national park. This is particularly true for the Koongarra project which is upstream of the Woolwonga Wildlife Sanctuary and in the South Alligator River catchment area. As the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Tambling) knows, the interrelationship in those wetlands is very important because of the floods that occur, because of the Aboriginal people's relationship in having to fish in the way they do, particularly in the lagoons in the dry seasons. This is the saddest thing. This is why the second report of the Fox inquiry said that if we go ahead with mining we affect all the interrelationships which are set down in that second volume. This second volume of the Fox report has been torn up and thrown out because of the hypocrisy of this Government. The Government has by-passed and prostituted this document, which set down the guidelines if mining were to proceed. With the Koongarra in operation as well as the Ranger project, both the major river systems of the region-the East Alligator and the South Alligator-would suffer the environmental effects of uranium mining. The Fox report clearly intended that if the mining were to proceed it should be restricted to the East Alligator catchment for the time being. It is envisaged that the South Alligator catchment be protected. The second Fox report also stated that the Woolwonga area is valuable ecologically and that we should oppose in principle any mining development upstream, at least until it has been demonstrated by experience that it can take place without environmental damage, and 1 stress the word 'experience'. I challenge Government members to tell me what experience they can point to as an example for saying that this legislation should go forward. Again, I draw the attention of honourable members to the second Fox report, which stated that if the Government were to go ahead with uranium mining then quite clearly the development should be sequential. The report warned against the development of both areas. If development is carried out at Koongarra and at the same time at the Ranger project, two catchment areas will be affected. That shows the stupidity and blundering of this Government. The terribly sad things about the issue is that we do not know enough about this delicate environment. We were warned that we have to be aware of what is going on. We just cannot go ahead with these procedures. We are drawing on experience. The fact is that so many blunders have been made in the past. That is why this second report went into such detail, and that is why we are asking the Government to give consideration to this matter even at this late hour. Might I say that even the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), at the time he announced the Government's uranium decision, recognised the environmental sensitivity of Koongarra. On 25 August 1977 he stated: That deposit has particular environmental problems because of the sensitivity and fragility of the environment of the area and the location of the deposit upstream of a major wetlands area. That was said by the Prime Minister on 25 August 1977. I ask the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) to tell the House what has happened since the time the Prime Minister made his statement on 25 August 1977. What has changed? The fact is that nothing has changed. The Government is under pressure from the wealthy mining companies. That is the situation. This Government really represents corporate capital. It does not represent the Australian people and our national heritage, it represents corporate capital particularly that of foreign corporations. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as a Queenslander, and no doubt you are proud of it, to make sure that you express your views within your own party room. Unless you do, they will do more of this. You will find that next the Government will be into exploiting the mineral aspects of the Great Barrier Reef. As with so many of the Government's promises on uranium, it now seems that the interests of the mining companies will override environmental considerations. I think I have set the case clear on that situation. It is no good the Minister simply saying that there will be no problems because the company plans a 'no water release policy'. If there were a breach in the tailings dam at Koongarra the consequences for the wetlands in the South Alligator River could be very serious, and I give honourable members an example. There is a history of this sort of thing occurring in uranium mines. Only two years ago a modern tailings dam at the United States uranium mine at Church Rock in New Mexico burst, releasing radioactive water across Indian lands. The implications of this spill were so great that the water supply of southern California was contaminated. The consequences of such a spill occurring at Koongarra would be devastating for the Kakadu National Park. The Minister has said that his Department has examined the Koongarra environmental impact statement and the overall physical consequences of the proposal will fall within acceptable and manageable limits. That is a pretty vague statement which entails a considerable amount of judgment. Let them make the statement available for assessment and scrutiny by the Parliament. The statement has not been put before the Parliament or the public. Why does not the Minister make it available to the public? Let independent scientists examine it to see whether they agree with the Department's assessment. Let the public judge whether the limits of environmental damage are acceptable and manageable. USA Units orders Cancellations and deferrals JapanUnits ordered . West GermanyUnits ordered FranceUnits ordered These are judgments which should be made explicitly and in an open fashion, not behind the closed doors of a government department. After all, it is a part of the world heritage with which we are dealing, as well as a part of our national heritage. That is what is involved. The Minister has said that the Bill does not mean that the Government has approved the Koongarra project. That statement rings very hollow indeed. Why has the Government gone to such extraordinary lengths to thwart the will of the people if it has not made up its mind to give the go-ahead to this uranium project? It sounds like those hollow assurances of 1976, when the Fox inquiry was still under way. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) came into this House day after day and said: 'We have not made up our minds yet'. The fact is that the Government, and particularly the Deputy Prime Minister, are doing everything in their power to get the Koongarra project under way. In doing so, once again it has thrown out the key recommendations of the Fox report and gone back to one of its undertakings of 1977, as expressed in the Prime Minister's statement. It is a pity that the Government does not wake up to the real situation in the nuclear industry throughout the world. Up until the election of President Mitterrand, France was the only Western country where there had been any consistent growth in the nuclear industry. Now even that is in doubt. I am sure that the socialist government in France will eventually respond to people's questioning of and opposition to nuclear programs. Only last week President Mitterrand announced that a planned 6,000 megawatt nuclear power scheme in Brittany was to be cancelled. That is the pattern throughout the world. Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The microwave link planned to be established between Port Hedland-Broome-Derby by the end of 1982 and between Derby-Halls Creek-Kununurra by the end of 1983 will provide a reliable trunk system which will support the provision and continued development of telephone services throughout the region. (2) A repeater station on the Derby-Halls CreekKununurra microwave link will be located 10 km from Turkey Creek. (3) The microwave link in general, and the Turkey Creek repeater in particular, will be utilised in the provision of STD telephone services to the community at Turkey Creek. Further to the answers given above, my Department advises that, notwithstanding the installation of the microwave link to the Kimberley region, the proposed domestic communications satellite system may well prove to be the most effective means of providing adequate national television service to the North West of Western Australia generally and, in the context of this question, to the Turkey Creek area. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) Information on the number of people eligible for the age pension in each able. The eligibility requirement for age pensions differs from country to country. In addition, apart from Australia and New Zealand, all OECD countries have contributory systems as an element in their age pension schemes under which entitlement is related to a person's contributions (or an employer's on their behalf) during their working life and in most cases to past earnings. The OECD has produced a study ('Demographic Trends 1950-1990', OECD 1979) which gives an estimate of the labour force and number of persons 65 and over in each member country for 1975, and projections up to 1990-a copy of the study is available in the Parliamentary Library. Projections of the population aged for most countries including OECD members for the years 1975, 1980, 1985, 1990 and 2000 are contained in 'Labour Force Estimates and Projections, 1950-2000', International Labour Office, Geneva, second edition, 1977. It must be noted that these projections are subject to a number of reservations and limitations, and given differing eligibility criteria (including different age criteria between countries) it is not possible to assume that persons of a certain age and over will be those eligible for age pensions. Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Departmental instructions make it clear that phones are for official use. Local personal calls are to be kept to a minimum and use of phones for such calls is to be monitored by supervisors. All personal trunk calls are to be booked through the switch board and paid for on completion. (2) In the Department's Central Office calls on each extension are separately recorded on a metering device. This information is regularly monitored and provides a control on the use of telephones. STD facilities are only made available to officers who have a need for frequent use of this facility. In all other offices of the Department with the exception of Melbourne, the STD facility is only made available to senior officers. In Melbourne, the Department is not responsible for the P ABX and STD access has not yet been controlled. It is understood that action is in train to implement STD barring on this P ABX. (3) The individual metering arrangements referred to above enable the Department gree of use of telephones. Preliminary consideration was given to the use of additional monitoring devices but the department did not pursue the matter because of the technical limitations of the currently available equipment. Further STD barring is under consideration. (1) The exportation of birds native to Australia is only permitted in terms of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations: (i) to approved publicly operated zoos for zoological display purposes; (ii) to approved scientific institutions for bona fidc research; and (iii) as household pets subject to certain stringent (Question No. 908) conditions. The conditions relating to the export of household pets are as follows: (a) the exporter is departing from Australia with the intention of taking up permanent residence in another country; (b) he has been resident in Australia for not less than three years prior to departures; and (c) he has owned and kept the specimen as a household pet for not less than two years prior to departure. The concession may be allowed once only, either to an individual householder or to one member of a family unit, and normally may be granted in respect of one specimen of a species ordinarily kept as a household pet. (2) No, but Australia's export policy allows certain overseas scientific institutions to obtain from approved Australian institutions specimens of native birds for bona fide study and Birds: Smuggling research purposes. These specimens are available to trained (Question No. 989) ornithologists for serious scientific research work. The second Report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation dealing with trafficking in Fauna in Australia made a recommendation in favour of government controlled exports of inter alia wild trapped common and pest species of birds. After consideration of this recommendation the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM), which comprises the States and Federal conservation Ministers, decided that no action should be taken to relax the existing policy. (3) It is known that birds of species native to Australia, some of which by reason of their rarity or endangered status may be described as exotic, are available for sale in other countries. Where possible all information concerning such cases is investigated with a view to identifying the source of exportation and taking appropriate action. (5) In what censoring priority does the Government place (a) explicit sexual content, (b) physical violence content, (c) dangerous and reckless driving content and (d) profanity in (i) television programs and (ii) films.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: UCOR
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) Yes. (3) All imported television program material including cinema films for use in television, and those Australian programs produced outside the control of television stations are examined and classified by the Film Censorship Board in terms of Television Program Standards determined by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The standards contain provisions relating to the portrayal of violence in programs and set down a system of classifications ('G', 'PGR', and 'AO') based on the time of day of transmission and the expected composition of the audience at these times. Television stations are expected to observe these provisions of the Standards in the production and scheduling of Australian material. In order to ensure that all stations, commercial, national and multi-cultural, maintain a consistent approach to program classification a Classification Consultative Committee has been established consisting of representatives of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the Film Censorship Board, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the Special Broadcasting Service. The committee is designing a uniform censorship classification system to cover all Australian and imported television material and this will be incorporated in amended Standards being devised by the Tribunal. The classification of films for use in the cinema is the responsibility of the Film Censorship Board which is under the control of my colleague, Senator the Honourable Peter Durack QC., the Attorney-General. (4) Yes. (5) The Government has confidence in the work of the Film Censorship Board and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and does not set down priorities as to the view to be taken of various aspects of programming. (2) What action has been taken or is contemplated by the Government to protect Australians travelling or about to travel. Sir Phillip Lynch--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The following travel agencies operating in Australia are known to have collapsed during the last three years: (A) Licensed Travel Agents (NSW) Technology (i) Ta Khattar (Consolidated Travel Services) (Question No. 1614) (ii) M. and T. Fragakis (iii) AUS Student Travel Pty Ltd (iv) Kacar Entl'Orprises Pty Ltd (Contact Travel) (v) Adria Travel Agency Pty Ltd (vi) Milsons Point World Travel Pty Ltd (vii) Trail Finders Pty Ltd (viii) Comserve (No. 522) Pty Ltd (Paddington International Travel) (a) salaries and (b) other charges (B) Unlicensed Operators (NSW) (i) Travellers Facilities Ply Ltd (ii) M. Bartlett (Air Pacific) (iii) Port Royale Charters Pty Ltd (iv) See Australia First Pty Ltd (C) Agents in other States/Territories (i) Kings Travel (SA) (ii) Blue Sky Travel (ACT) (D) Australian Offices of Overseas Operators (i) Treasure Tours (ii) Transit Travel Pty Ltd (iii) Penn World Ltd (2) Regulation of the activities of travel agents operating in Australia falls within the responsibility of the States and Territories. The only State/Territory to have legislated to regulate the activities of travel agents is New South Wales through its Travel Agents Registration Board. Under the New South Wales Travel Agents Act (1973) all persons, firms or corporations carrying on the business of a travel agent are required to be licensed. Members of the public have access to the travel Environment agents compensation fund in the event of a licensed travel (Question No. 1621) agent failing to account for monies entrusted to the licensee or his employee. No other State or Territory is understood to be intending to introduce similar legislation at this time. In 1978 the Commonwealth Government considered the introduction of legislation to be administered in conjunction with the States, to regulate the activities of travel agents operating in Australia, but as a result of objections raised by the States and industry and following advice from the Travel and Tourist Industry Advisory Council, decided n'ot to proceed with the legislation. In deciding not to proceed with the legislation the Commonwealth had had regard to the degree of protection for the travelling public which already existed, including Commonwealth and State laws relating to protection of the consumer, the regulation of corporate bodies and crimes matters generally. Commonwealth and State Consumer Affairs Ministers reTravel Agencies cently reviewed the desirability of licensing travel agents and (Question No. 1627) decided that it should be left to each jurisdiction to take whichever action it felt appropriate. The Australian Federation of Travel Agents is currently investigating the possibility of establishing a self-regulatory consumer protection scheme. The objective is to design, fund and administer a traveller's protection scheme which would provide the public/travellers with security in the case of financial collapse experienced by member retail travel agents, tour wholesalers and general sales agents. Consular assistance from Australia '8 overseas missions and posts is of course available to Australians travelling abroad who find themselves stranded or in distress as a result of circumstances beyond their control including the collapse of travel agencies. Protective Security Review Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: What decisions have been made and what action taken on Mr Justice Hope's recommendation contained in his Protective Security Review that the organisational structure of fire safety officers should be thoroughly examined. text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (l) I do not understand the reference to 'proposed cuts in social service benefits'. The term 'people in genuine need' refers to people who are unable to provide for themselves from their own resources. (2) On 7 May 1981 revised guidelines in relation to medical evaluation for invalid pensions were issued to Commonwealth Medical Officers. The revised guidelines are: Medical Evaluation (a) Eligibility To be eligible for an invalid pension a person must be permanently incapacitated for work to the extent to not less than 85 per cent or must be permanently blind. (b) Assessment of permanence An incapacity is considered permanent if no fundamental or marked change for the better can be expected in a person's condition in the future. (c) Assessment of incapacity Incapacity is defined by the degree of permanent incapacity of a person compared with the capacity for work which that person would have had, but for his incapacity. and Commissions of Statutory Authorities under his jurisdiction. The comparison is to be made with regard to all work that could reasonably be regarded by the assessor (Question No.1 067) as being within the claimant's capacity. Assessment of incapacity is made having regard to the degree of the claimant's impairment which, together with relevant facts about the applicant such as age, sex, education, lack of skills and personal disabilities, constitutes incapacity. It is important to recognise that it is permanent incapacity and not permanent impairment that is relevant for invalid pension purposes. Permanent impairment-This is a purely medical condition. Permanent impairment is an anatomic or functional abnormality of loss after maximal medical rehabilitation has been achieved, which abnormality or loss the Commonwealth Medical Officer considers stable or non-progressive at the time evaluation is made. It is always a basic consideration in the evaluation of permanent incapacity. Permanent incapacity-This is not a purely medical condition. A person is permanently incapacitated or under a permanent incapacity when his actual or presumed ability to engage in gainful employment is reduced or absent because of impairment which, in turn, mayor may not be combined with other factors. While fluctuations in the labour market are to be disregarded in the assessment of the applicant's capacity for work, that capacity must be assessed in the light of work of kinds that (subject to such fluctuations) are available in Australia, regardless of whether or not they are available at places reasonably accessible to the applicant at his current place of residence. However, age, sex, education, lack of relevant skills and personal disabilities are factors to be taken into account, together with impairment, in determining the capacity of an individual applicant for work that is not so reasonably accessible. The fact that a severely handicapped applicant might be able to get work at a time of full or over-full employment because of the scarcity of labour would not disentitle him if he was unlikely to get work at any reasonable foreseeable time given the general level of demand for labour in Australia. Self-inflicted incapacity brought about for the purpose of obtaining a pension disqualifies a person from pension. (d) Employment considerations While it is not generally possible for a person engaged in employment to be considered as being permanently incapacitated for work all relevant factors should be considered where a person is engaging in some form of employment, including the nature of employment (part time, sheltered, therapeutic, token); whether employment is within the claimant's remaining capacity for work; whether employment is compatible with the claimant's medical condition; whether employment will continue. The Department of Social Security may request a review of medical entitlement if a pensioner commences work. (e) Other considerations A person who has lost the use of both arms or legs may be considered to be permanently incapacitated, independent of their personal and employment circumstances, even when engaged in some limited employment. A similar assessment may be made if a person has suffered some other permanent impairment which is as broadly disruptive of his capacity for work as the loss of both arms or legs would be. Mr Scott asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 April 1981: (I) Has the Minister's attention been drawll to a report on the problems of youth housing circulated to the media ill Adelaide on 23 March 1981 which reportedly represented the views of 30 organisations, including Commonwealth and State Government Departments and community service organisations such as Emergency Accommodation Services for Youth at the YWCA and Saint Vincent de Paul. (2) Is it a fact that in South Australia there are an estimated 6,000 homeless young persons. (3) Has the Government been approached by the South Australian Government for an increase in funding under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act. (4) Will the Government consider adopting the recommendations contained in the report by the South Australian Government Working Party on Youth Housing, particularly recommendations 5 (i), 5 (ii) and 5 (iii) which respectively relate to raising the rate of unemployment benefit, providing supplementary assistance to young unemployed persons living independently and increasing the unemployment rate for persons 16 and 17 years of age to that of the single adult rate if they have been living independently for a suitable qualifying period.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: PERCENTAGE OF CITY OFFICE SPACE LOCATED
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Yes. My attention has been drawn to a Press release with attached background material, dealing with the problems of youth housing, which was issued on 23 March 1981 by a South Australian organisation called 'Shelter'. This is an organisation whose members are individuals concerned about the problems of homeless people. Many of the members are employees of welfare organisations involved in providing accommodation services, and some are employees of Government Departments. These latter are members of the organisation in their capacity as private citizens, and are not representatives of their employing Departments. (2) A report called 'Survey of Youth Homelessness in Metropolitan Adelaide', December 1979, which was released by the Council for Homeless Persons (SA), estimated that there were 6,000 homeless young persons in Metropolitan Adelaide. Another report, entitled 'Youth Housing', which was published in June 1980 by the South Australian Council of Social Service, estimated that 9,000 young people seek housing assistance each year in Metropolitan Adelaide. It is difficult, however, to estimate accurately the homeless youth population. The estimates given above were calculated from the number of homeless young people who contacted some welfare accommodation agencies in a given survey period, usually one week. An overestimate of the population size will, of course, occur if a homeless young person approaches more than one accommodation agency during the survey period, whereas there will be an underestimate if a young person seeking temporary accommodation does not contact any welfare agency. In addition, the surveys did llot contact every possible agency which might have received requests for accommodation assistance. The government nevertheless accepts that these estimates point to a problem on a scale which warrants serious concern. The Commonwealth has therefore offered assistance to the States to provide additional facilities for emergency accommodation for young people up to 18 years. This assistance is provided through the Youth Services Scheme and is jointly Youth Housing cost shared with each State Government which administers its (Question No. 1068) Commonwealth funding component. Four South Australian projects providing emergency accommodation and support for youth currently receive funding under the Scheme. (3) There is no record of an approach by the South Australian Government for an increase in funding under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act. (4) The recommendations in the report of the South Australian Government Working Party on Youth Housing have been noted and will be taken into account by the Government in its current Review of Improved Opportunities for Youth and in the annual Budget context. text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Surplus or obsolete forms, letter heads and other proformas are used by Departmental staff as note and scribble pads. Bulk paper, e.g. computer print-out, is despatched to paper and pulp mills within the States for re-cycling. Waste paper is collected daily by contract cleaners engaged by the Department of Administrative Services and is disposed of in accordance with contract provisions. There are no formal arrangements for Offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service outside metropolitan areas for the re-cycling of paper. Offices would be expected to comply with local arrangements concerning disposal of waste paper. Recycling of Paper: Department of Veterans' Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: Has any action been taken by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to re-cycle paper; if so, what action. Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: In leased premises, the removal of unclassified waste paper is undertaken by cleaners employed by the Department of Administrative Services and recycling is usually arranged by the owners in conjunction with the Department of Administrative Services. In departmentally-owned hospitals and other institutions, arrangements exist with charitable organisations and private contractors for waste paper to be collected for recycling. Classified waste is normally burnt or shredded under Departmental control or supervision. Control of Plague Locusts Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 14 May 1981: (1) Is control of plague locusts now to be entirely a State responsibility (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1847). (2) What plans does the Government have for the Commonwealth employee currently associated with the Plague Locust Commission.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: PERCENTAGE OF CITY OFFICE SPACE LOCATED
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Control of plague locusts has always been a State responsibility. By agreement with the States, the Australian Plague Locust Commission, which consists of six Commissioners (two from the Commonwealth and one each from the contributing States) and a Director assisted by permanent staff, engages in operations designed to combat outbreaks or potential outbreaks of the Australian plague locust in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Queensland, which in the opinion of the Commission are likely to result in damage to ruralindustries in another State. (2) The general approach and procedures concerning staffing relating to the implementation of Government decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions have been detailed by the Public Service Board. These include the situation where a function is to be transferred to the States. Any change in Commission staffing arrangements will be in accord with these guidelines. text: -On 13 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2297) Mr Tuckey asked me as Minister for Communications the following question, without notice: I refer the Minister of Communications to the recent amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act which allow community groups to erect national television translators. Can the Minister advise the House of the number of applications that have been received as a result of this legislation? Can he further state when the residents of Howick and Condingup in the Esperance Shire might receive approval of their applications? The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Expressions of interest relating to the establishment of translators which may be licensed to relay national (ABC) television programs have been received for seven such services. The group which has expressed an interest in establishing a privately funded translator to relay national (ABC) television (Question No. 2319) programs to Howick and Condingup in the Esperance Shire is presently considering the options open to it. The most expeditious of these options would appear to be donation of the transmission facility to the Government'so that it will become part of the National Broadcasting Service at the time programming commences. Under these circumstances it would not be necessary for the group to obtain a licence for the translator and the project could proceed with a minimum of delay. Should the group decide to pursue the option of applying for a licence to operate the translator as a privately owned outlet of the National television service, it is unlikely that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would be able to grant a licence until well into 1982. This delay is entirely usual and is a result of the administrative processes involved in preparation and distribution of a draft planning proposal, preparation of a final planning proposal, the calling of applications for a licence and the actuallicence inquiry by the Tribunal. In addition to the time taken for administrative proc.esses, there are statutory periods set aside to allow interested parties to comment on draft planning proposals and to allow applications for the licence to be submitted to the Tribunal. text: On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 1092) Mr LES JOHNSON asked me 'Americanese'. The honoura question, without notice, concerning the Commonwealth census. The following is in answer to the honourable member's question: A circular has been sent to all Commonwealth Departments and Authorities seeking their co-operation in the conduct of the 1981 Census, and advising that public servants will be allowed to accept employment as temporary Census field officers whilst on leave from their regular employment and to retain the additional payment for the Census work. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has advertised widely for temporary field staff for the Census and it is open to anyone to apply. The ABS has also sought the assistance of the Commonwealth Employment Service in specifically drawing the attention of those registered with them to the availability of this work. However, despite the unemployment situation, in a number of localities response to the advertisement has been disappointing. Although the ABS has obtained the approval of the Public Service Board to employ public servants for this work, preference will be given, as far as practicable, to the recruitment of suitable people who are not already in employment.
